MAI means global warming : If the industrialized countries sign this agreement, they are condemning our planet to an era of uninsured risk.: [Final Edition]

Author: Hawkins, David

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/mai-means-global-warming-if-industrialized/docview/242892357/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: If the 29 industrialized countries of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development decide to sign on to MAI, those laws will condemn the Earth to an era of uninsured risk, heralded by floods in Manitoba and ice storms in Quebec. In what looks like a tactic to get MAI signed in May before the rest of the world wakes up, the Fraser Institute economists want scientists to collect an impossible body of evidence to prove a theory of global warming. If they sign MAI, we enter an era of increased emissions, global warming, catastrophic climate change, bankrupt insurance companies and the loss of weather-related insurance cover for both foreign corporate investors and local community taxpayers.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=MAI+means+global+warming+%3A+If+the+industrialized+countries+sign+this+agreement%2C+they+are+condemning+our+planet+to+an+era+of+uninsured+risk.&amp;author=Hawkins%2C+David&amp;issn=08321299&amp;title=The+Vancouver+Sun&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-04-14&amp;spage=D.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: David Hawkins is a consultant and the founding partner of Hampshire Hill Retreats, a think tank for independent business and sustainable growth. He can be reached at dahawki@hampshirehill.com
They may reject evidence of greenhouse gases, global warming and climate change, but lobbyists for the Multilateral Agreement on Investment live with us on a planet which obeys the laws of physics.
If the 29 industrialized countries of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development decide to sign on to MAI, those laws will condemn the Earth to an era of uninsured risk, heralded by floods in Manitoba and ice storms in Quebec.
Under MAI, a foreign corporation can sue governments if they pass laws limiting resource production from domestic corporate investments.
By joining MAI in May, Canada exposes all four levels of government to legal action for compensatory damages. Worse, a signatory state must give five years notice to withdraw, and then allow unregulated production rates of its domestic resources for a further 15 years.
Lobbyists at the Fraser Institute, the Vancouver-based corporate think-tank, justify this 20-year commitment to MAI with an error in logic.
They argue that industry production rates need not respect a theory of global warming because scientists cannot isolate and measure global temperature variations due to man-made factors.
But instead of collecting evidence for 20 years and then finding it is too late, we can prove global warming from first principles and take preventive action now.
A growing blanket of greenhouse gases is closing off the earth's atmosphere, allowing more of the sun's energy to enter than to escape.
The first law of thermodynamics tells us that energy is conserved so the atmosphere must get hotter. The second law tells us that the "disorder" of a closed system increases, so the earth must suffer more frequent and more extreme changes in its climate.
In what looks like a tactic to get MAI signed in May before the rest of the world wakes up, the Fraser Institute economists want scientists to collect an impossible body of evidence to prove a theory of global warming.
They say scientists must use physical laws to show the world that, if the blanket of greenhouse gases continues to grow, global warming, climate change and uninsured weather risks inevitably follow.
But confirmation of the laws is already staring us in the face.
The greenhouse gas blanket is growing thicker around the earth, trapping more heat. The first law of thermodynamics says the earth must be getting hotter, and the five years from 1992 to 1996 are the hottest on record, as noted by Wayne Grady, author of The Quiet Limit of the World.
The second law says the disorder of a closed atmospheric system must increase.
Designed to withstand the historic weather patterns for Canada, infrastructures in Manitoba and Quebec have crumbled under the impact of floods and ice storms into billion-dollar catastrophes for the insurance industry.
Scientists can now prove what corporate ideologists will deny for lack of evidence: MAI will accelerate resource production, with attendant greenhouse gases.
The incriminated gas blanket will get thicker, faster. The earth will get hotter, the climate more violent and there will not be enough money to fix things when they break.
Industrialized states are poised to guarantee foreign corporations at least 20 years unregulated production of their domestic resources, including fossil fuels.
If they sign MAI, we enter an era of increased emissions, global warming, catastrophic climate change, bankrupt insurance companies and the loss of weather-related insurance cover for both foreign corporate investors and local community taxpayers.
Weather news across North America and around the world gives us proof of global warming, climate change and the era of uninsured risk, so let's stop trying to prove a theory for rejection by the "free market."
Citizens and voters must tell their governments to reject MAI and switch substantial resources into energy conservation and the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions.
We will face MAI in May, at high noon under a hot sun.
Illustration Photo: David Hawkins ;

Warming would hit Prairies hard: Waterfowl most at risk if sloughs dry up prematurely: [Final Edition]

Author: Struzik, Ed

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/warming-would-hit-prairies-hard-waterfowl-most-at/docview/244654238/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Disease and habitat loss will take a major toll on the millions of birds and animals that make use of the Prairies if the climate warms as predicted, says a study commissioned by the World Wildlife Fund. The Prairies are home to hundreds of thousands of shallow potholes and wetlands that provide critical habitat for millions of shorebirds, ducks, and geese, which in turn are an important food source for predators. Droughts are a fact of life on the Prairies regardless of greenhouse gas emissions. A serious drought generally strikes the Prairies once every 30 to 50 years.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Warming+would+hit+Prairies+hard%3A+Waterfowl+most+at+risk+if+sloughs+dry+up+prematurely&amp;author=Struzik%2C+Ed&amp;issn=08281815&amp;title=Calgary+Herald&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-04-11&amp;spage=B.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   City: Science & Technology
Disease and habitat loss will take a major toll on the millions of birds and animals that make use of the Prairies if the climate warms as predicted, says a study commissioned by the World Wildlife Fund.
The year-long study commissioned scientists to use sophisticated computer modeling programs to simulate potential changes in the environment based on the rise in greenhouse gases.
Predictive studies on climate change have been done before, but this one was somewhat unique in that it focused on the impact on vegetation and habitat.
University of Toronto scientist Jay Markham says such changes can be predicted by looking at climactic conditions that favor different types of plants and then comparing them with the various climate scenarios in the future.
"Whichever scenario you use, and there are a number of them out there," says Markham, "the end result is that the Prairies end up being particularly hard hit."
Markham says he was initially surprised by the findings which he arrived at with Adam Malcolm of World Wildlife Fund International in Washington.
"I thought that we would see the tree line rising quickly up the Rocky Mountains," he says. "And that is the case. But the pace of change on the Prairies was most pronounced."
Looked at more closely, the results aren't so difficult to explain, says Malcolm.
The Prairies are home to hundreds of thousands of shallow potholes and wetlands that provide critical habitat for millions of shorebirds, ducks, and geese, which in turn are an important food source for predators.
Even under so-called normal conditions, the slightest variation in precipitation and temperatures can significantly alter the size of these wetlands in a given year.
"Many kinds of migratory birds take shelter in temporary marshes that form on the prairie early in the year," says Malcolm.
"As the climate warms, these marshes will dry up earlier. Farmers will be tempted to use these dry conditions to cultivate earlier. And this will force birds to fly farther north for acceptable nesting sites."
While prairie birds and animals are conditioned to adapt to, and rebound from years of drought, it is believed that many species have already been pushed to the brink over the past century by agricultural development and the more than 700 prairie dams and irrigation reservoirs that have obstructed or dried up waterways.
Any trend towards further warming will likely dry up many of these potholes and wetlands altogether, irrespective of the fact that global change may bring more precipitation, says Malcolm.
Droughts are a fact of life on the Prairies regardless of greenhouse gas emissions. A serious drought generally strikes the Prairies once every 30 to 50 years.
The most severe drought of the past 500 years occurred on the prairie between 1791 and 1800.
The last significant drought in 1988 led to net income losses for farmers that reached as high as 78 per cent in Saskatchewan. More than $1.3 billion in drought, crop insurance and special drought assistance was paid out to mitigate the damages that occurred that year.
The World Wildlife Fund study falls into line with many of the predictions of Environment Canada.
Scientists asked by the department to look at global warming scenarios are predicting warmer temperatures, generally drier conditions and less severe winters for the Prairies.
Some of those scientists warn that average potential crop yields on the Prairies may fall by 10 to 30 per cent unless new crop varieties are developed.
While good planning and the development of drought-resistant crops can mitigate the damage to agriculture, the same does not hold true for the natural habitat upon which birds and wildlife depend, says Tim Goos of Environment Canada.
"You may be able to plant a crop earlier or irrigate more in the hot month of August if you're a farmer worried about yields, but there's not much that can be done when the duck ponds dry up and the vegetation is scarce."

Secretarial: Chasing the dragon Life's anything but dull at Earthwatch, writes Gina Bryant

Author: Bryant, Gina

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/secretarial-chasing-dragon-lifes-anything-dull-at/docview/245220514/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: `I went to Komodo Island in August, with a group of teachers who had won fellowships,' 28-year-old Roscrow recalls. `We lived with the local villagers and each day worked with scientists, trapping the lizards and taking blood samples for DNA analysis. I was terrified before I went. Komodo dragons can be as much as three metres long and they are very fast runners. But, unless antagonised, they usually ignore you.' The dragons were caught in traps built by the volunteers and fitted with radio collars so they could be tracked through the forest. `It was disconcerting standing beside this hissing monster, rattling its head against the trap.' As fellowships officer, Roscrow organises the applications that flood in for the Millennium Fellowships Programme, handles enquiries and issues briefing packs. The programme, funded to the tune of pounds 1.4 million by the Lottery, gives teachers the chance to join field projects overseas during school holidays. Participants might study forests in Bohemia, devastated by acid rain, monitor climate change in Iceland, or help to save the endangered Komodo dragon.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Secretarial%3A+Chasing+the+dragon+Life%27s+anything+but+dull+at+Earthwatch%2C+writes+Gina+Bryant&amp;author=Bryant%2C+Gina&amp;issn=02613077&amp;title=The+Guardian&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-03-30&amp;spage=T.052&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Lynne Roscrow has an admin job with a difference. In her first year with the environmental charity Earthwatch Institute, she has been to a remote island in Indonesia to track the monster of the reptile world - the Komodo dragon.
`I went to Komodo Island in August, with a group of teachers who had won fellowships,' 28-year-old Roscrow recalls. `We lived with the local villagers and each day worked with scientists, trapping the lizards and taking blood samples for DNA analysis. I was terrified before I went. Komodo dragons can be as much as three metres long and they are very fast runners. But, unless antagonised, they usually ignore you.' The dragons were caught in traps built by the volunteers and fitted with radio collars so they could be tracked through the forest. `It was disconcerting standing beside this hissing monster, rattling its head against the trap.' As fellowships officer, Roscrow organises the applications that flood in for the Millennium Fellowships Programme, handles enquiries and issues briefing packs. The programme, funded to the tune of pounds 1.4 million by the Lottery, gives teachers the chance to join field projects overseas during school holidays. Participants might study forests in Bohemia, devastated by acid rain, monitor climate change in Iceland, or help to save the endangered Komodo dragon.
Last year, Earthwatch sent 185 lecturers, teachers, zoo education officers and country rangers to projects around the world. With 166 more volunteers receiving the news later this month that they have won a place, Roscrow has had a lot of people to look after.
`We've got an excellent `sign-up' database,' she says. `I can keep control of where everyone is going and when, their insurance details, travel costs and personal action plans.' She also has to sort out flight details for each person and confirm hotel bookings. Her busy office has even felt the effect of El Nino: `Last year, we had to cancel the field trip to Ecuador at the last minute and find everyone places on other projects.' Encountering a different culture in Indonesia had as much an impact on Roscrow as taking part in scientific research. `We were pushed to the limits in the field. It was hot, hard work, and you're surrounded by people who don't understand you. I learnt a lot about tolerance and team-building.' Back in the office, the experience is paying dividends. `I deal better with work colleagues, new situations and deadlines,' she says.
Roscrow, from Inverness, began her career with Our Price Records, where she was promoted to store manager. `I learnt organisational and management skills and a lot about customer care, but after eight years I was desperate for a break from retail.' She spent seven months travelling around the US. Back in Scotland, she signed up with a temp agency. `I arrived in jeans and they said they had just the job for me. It turned out to be very boring work in a grimy garage.' Already a keen member of Earthwatch, Roscrow sent in her CV to the organisation in the hope that there might be a job going. A month later, she was invited for interview and in February last year joined the charity's offices in Oxford.
The job is the first to offer her true satisfaction. `There's a hell of a lot of admin, and it's difficult trying to allocate the right people on to the right project. But to me, this is an admin job with a purpose. Even though I'm behind the scenes, I recognise the part I'm playing. I'm giving teachers a chance to be motivated and take that motivation back to the classroom.' For more details of the Earthwatch Millennium Fellowships or places on research projects, write to 57 Woodstock Road, Oxford, OX2 6HJ, or call 01865-311601.

Subject: Reptiles & amphibians

Location: Indonesia

People: Roscrow, Lynne

Company: Earthwatch

House panel OKs $8.5 million in farm aid // The money is earmarked for Minnesota's northwest, where five years of harsh weather and poor crops have taken a toll.: [METRO Edition]

Author: deFiebre, Conrad; Staff Writer11 Staff Writer

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/house-panel-oks-8-5-million-farm-aid-money-is/docview/426954202/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Emergency state assistance of $8.5 million for northwest Minnesota farmers struggling with five years of poor crops was approved Thursday by the House Ways and Means Committee. Only Minority Leader Steve Sviggum, R-Kenyon, dissented on a 20-1 vote to send to the House floor a bill sponsored by Rep. Jim Tunheim, DFL-Kennedy. Sviggum, a farmer in southeastern Minnesota, argued that the state cannot insulate farms from natural cycles of weather, crop disease and market prices. All of those factors have saddled wheat and barley farmers in Minnesota's remote northwest corner with catastrophic long-term losses that federal crop insurance has been inadequate to cover, said Sen. LeRoy Stumpf, DFL-Thief River Falls.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=House+panel+OKs+%248.5+million+in+farm+aid+%2F%2F+The+money+is+earmarked+for+Minnesota%27s+northwest%2C+where+five+years+of+harsh+weather+and+poor+crops+have+taken+a+toll.&amp;author=deFiebre%2C+Conrad%3BStaff+Writer&amp;issn=08952825&amp;title=Star+Tribune&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-03-27&amp;spage=03.B&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Emergency state assistance of $8.5 million for northwest Minnesota farmers struggling with five years of poor crops was approved Thursday by the House Ways and Means Committee.
Only Minority Leader Steve Sviggum, R-Kenyon, dissented on a 20-1 vote to send to the House floor a bill sponsored by Rep. Jim Tunheim, DFL-Kennedy. Sviggum, a farmer in southeastern Minnesota, argued that the state cannot insulate farms from natural cycles of weather, crop disease and market prices.
All of those factors have saddled wheat and barley farmers in Minnesota's remote northwest corner with catastrophic long-term losses that federal crop insurance has been inadequate to cover, said Sen. LeRoy Stumpf, DFL-Thief River Falls.
"This is an aberration," testified Rob Running, a farmer near Kennedy. "It's unrivaled by any other crop problem in the Northern Hemisphere over the last 10 years. It's affecting so many producers over such a long term."
Scab fungus and other wet-cycle diseases have beaten down yields of the small grains that are the area's economic mainstay. Meanwhile, worldwide bumper crops have hammered market prices for the same commodities, said Agriculture Commissioner Gene Hugoson.
Under Tunheim's bill, hard-pressed wheat and barley farmers in 11 counties could receive as much as $4,000 apiece to defray crop insurance premiums, which have been rising in cost and declining in coverage as yields have sagged. The counties covered are Beltrami, Clearwater, Kittson, Lake of the Woods, Mahnomen, Marshall, Norman, Pennington, Polk, Red Lake and Roseau.
Money for the assistance would come from the state's projected $1.9 billion budget surplus, but Hugoson said Gov. Arne Carlson hasn't yet decided whether to support the assistance plan.
"After the budget process is done, we'll see how it fits in," Hugoson said. "There's no guarantee the governor will sign, but he won't necessarily veto it, either. We're willing to work with the Legislature."
So far, research hasn't found a remedy for wheat scab, and it has spread to at least 12 states, Hugoson said.
"We have to look at more crop diversity up there, perhaps bringing livestock back into the area," he said. "We don't know whether it's a weather aberration or a climate change."
The assistance "won't make a difference whether people make it or not," Hugoson added. "But it would show people in the northwest corner that they're not forgotten."
Congress also is moving to help farmers. Senate and House versions of a broader appropriations bill would increase the Agriculture Department's lending authority. The loans are intended to keep farmers in business if they can't get credit from private lenders.
"This is not the complete answer, but it will at least enable people to continue to go on," Sen. Paul Wellstone, D-Minn., said Thursday.
- The Associated Press contributed to this report.

Title: House panel OKs $8.5 million in farm aid // The money is earmarked for Minnesota's northwest, where five years of harsh weather and poor crops have taken a toll.:   [METRO Edition ]

Publication title: Star Tribune; Minneapolis, Minn.

Pages: 03B

Number of pages: 0

Publication year: 1998

Full text:   Private police threaten rights EDITOR: What kind of a police state are we becoming if bondsmen can enter one's home without a warrant, and without checking to see if police had made the arrest already?

Wrong gases
EDITOR: I would like to point out a discrepancy between one of your headlines and the Associated Press news story that appeared on the front page on March 5.
The headline "Costs of ozone pact at $110 per home" was connected to a story about the costs that may be associated with compliance with the international agreement generally referred to as the Kyoto Protocol.
However, the Kyoto Protocol is not aimed at reducing ozone depletion ... (Its) goal is the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions.
Confusion between human-induced greenhouse warming and ozone depletion is common ... They are, however, distinctly different phenomena.
The concern with ozone is related to the prediction ... and the well-documented observation that certain man-made chemicals cause a depletion of ozone in the Earth's upper atmosphere. This has led to an international agreement, the Montreal Protocols, phasing out the production of a variety of ozone-depleting chemicals.
Carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas (a gas that absorbs the infrared radiation the Earth emits back to space) and is thus related to concerns about global climate change. Many scientists think that increasing carbon dioxide abundance in the lower part of the atmosphere will lead to an increase in the Earth's average temperature and ... the distribution of climatic conditions. ...
Hence, the headline should have been "Costs of carbon dioxide pact at $110 per home."
ARTHUR J. SPIVACK
Professor of Earth Sciences
UNCW
Wilmington
Money problem
EDITOR: Ever since their leaders, Bill and Al, got caught with their hands in the cookie jar of illegal money, the Dems have tried to switch the theme from the crime to the cause.
All we hear from them is that the great god money is ruining the country and making honest politicians into crooks. And how it is time to have real reform which translates to "let's pass another law that will be ignored, but will be good touchy feely Pabulum ...
Money is not the problem. Not knowing who is buying our politicians is the problem. That is easy to solve. Adopt the following rules that I first read a few weeks ago written by George Will.
No limit on contributions. No cash contributions, checks only. No money from any foreign source. No contributions later than one week prior to the election. Full disclosure to the media at least weekly with a complete summary one week prior to the election. Last, but not least, any violation voids the election and the money must be returned.
With that information we should be able to decide if we agree with who is making the contributions. At least then we will know our views will be considered. ...
JIM TORRANCE
Wilmington

What a hoot! I guess "Mouth and Throat Cancer Under the Stars" wouldn't sell.
ANDREA G. GARFINKEL
Wilmington

History shared
EDITOR: I'm writing in response to the Feb. 17 letter "White history." What a bold statement from a person who has not taken the time to look back in history to find out why.
For decades, white people have tried to reconvert my people: Not only do we have the month of February to celebrate black history, but in my opinion, black history is not recognized enough.
If it were left up to me, black history would be celebrated from January through December. My people are due that respect, and more.
Your race took my people's land away and made them slaves. ... You have had your history for years and decades. It's my people's turn to be noticed.
Black history should affect you in a positive way, not a negative way. Live and learn your history. When we look at it, we all are a part of the same history, like it or not.
AON'TONIO RIPLEY
Wilmington
DSS neglected
EDITOR: If I read your Feb. 23 report correctly, it seems that our Republican County Commissioners' only reason for scrimping on the DSS staff is a mindless, ideological knee-jerk reaction against increase in government.
Never mind that the social services professionals in Raleigh consider the caseload excessive. Never mind that state and federal funds would be provided to cover 75 percent of the needed staff. Never mind that the other 25 percent is already available from existing DSS funds. Never mind the human problems caused by extended delay in dealing with cases of abuse, neglect and troubled youth.
... In a growing county, it is reasonable to expect that required government services will also grow. If our Republican commissioners don't want to be problem-solvers, maybe they should do something else with their spare time.
CHARLIE WEST
Wilmington
(EDITOR'S NOTE: The writer is secretary of the New Hanover County Democratic Party.)

Margaret's mission in Antarctica: [1 Edition]

Author: Gardham, Magnus

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/margarets-mission-antarctica/docview/327355991/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Margaret Speedie sat on deck as a Russian explorer carefully put stitches in a gash in her lip. Her normally carefully-groomed hair was caked rigid with salt from days of sea-water showers, and as she looked up she saw icebergs floating past. Margaret - propelled by a nagging sense that there was more to life out there -won sponsorship from her firm to join Mission Antarctica, a programme set up to assess the amount of man-made junk spoiling the wilderness and gather support for an international clean-up operation. Backed by corporate sponsors, who stump up GBP 15,000 to send an employee, new teams will follow in Margaret's footsteps each summer. The aim is to plan a clean-up of the Russian Bellinghaussen base on King George Island in the year 2000.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Margaret%27s+mission+in+Antarctica&amp;author=Gardham%2C+Magnus&amp;issn=03075761&amp;title=Evening+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-03-23&amp;spage=14.27&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Margaret Speedie sat on deck as a Russian explorer carefully put stitches in a gash in her lip. Her normally carefully-groomed hair was caked rigid with salt from days of sea-water showers, and as she looked up she saw icebergs floating past.
For the West Lothian mother-of two who had never travelled further than Majorca it was a moment to cherish - despite the pain from her wound.
The 50-year-old insurance firm worker had been injured falling through a hatch on the ocean-going yacht she shared with six complete strangers.
Her adventure in the wilderness came after she joined explorer Robert Swan's Mission Antarctica expedition.
Intrepid though she is, Margaret doesn't fit the traditional image of a Polar explorer.
She lives in a small, modern terraced house in Bathgate with her machine operator husband Bobby. She is the kind of jolly mum who jokes that their son Barry, 23, and daughter Diane, 20, take as much looking after now as they did when they were two-year-olds.
And she has a job she enjoys, as a call centre operator with Edinburgh insurance giant Standard Life.
Things such as penguin colonies, yacht voyages and the effects of pollution on the polar ice caps have, until now, featured little in her life.
Still less the drastic first aid from Dr Misha Malakhov, a veteran polar explorer, after her fall through the deck hatch.
Margaret - propelled by a nagging sense that there was more to life out there -won sponsorship from her firm to join Mission Antarctica, a programme set up to assess the amount of man-made junk spoiling the wilderness and gather support for an international clean-up operation.
For three weeks, on board the 52ft yacht Pelagic, her life was turned upside down. Now, back home, she admits she still feels "not quite with it."
The thrown-together crew included Misha, skipper Hamish Laird and a member of the Scottish Polar Research Institute, Finlo Cottier. The Polar newcomers included computer company worker Peter Galesloot and colleague Gaynor Finlay, and Lisa Cusack, a private health firm worker from London.
Says Margaret: "When we first sat down together at Gatwick airport I thought, 'We are going to be OK.'
"It was obvious from the start there were no egos, which was a good basis for setting out on a trip like ours.
"I think it was a really special time for all of us. "What we have shared is something we will never forget.
"It was hard work but we had relaxing times. There were a lot of fun moments. There was no friction among the crew, no dirt to dish," says Margaret.
Their work started on King George Island, a barren, rocky "quarry" of place on the edge of Antarctica, where 30 years-worth of discarded exploration hardware litters the landscape.
Mission Antarctica hopes data collected by Margaret and the team will be used to organise a clean-up.
The Pelagic began its journey into Antarctica with a 12 hour sail through the Gerlache Straits to the rugged volcanic landscape of Deception Island, a former whaling station still dotted with the remains of huge vats used to boil up valuable blubber.
With Pelagic moored in a sheltered bay, trips ashore were by inflatable Zodiac dinghy.
"I used muscles I never though I had getting in and out of that dinghy," says Margaret.
"Everything seemed strange. We washed up in salt water so everything tasted of salt and we showered in salt water.
"My scalp was encrusted in salt. Meals came from a whole lamb that was strung up from the rigging." As they sailed further south, mooring at various remote points on the coast, signs of human activity on the continent were replaced by the sight of seals and penguin colonies.
The penguins displayed a side to their character that no David Attenborough documentary could - their smell.
For every group huddled in a circle there was an even bigger circle of stinking penguin droppings nearby.
And, as icebergs were sighted towering out of the water, the crew were introduced to what seasoned Antarctica hands knowingly call "Kodak country".
"The snow and ice are full of luminous neon colours. You need sunglasses or you are blinded by it all.
"Sometimes it felt a bit overwhelming that I was actually there. It was very emotional at times.
"We were sailing through ice- bergs, which was a peculiar feeling in such a small yacht, but we were glad we were able to get to areas where a bigger boat just could not have gone.
"You feel as if you are almost beamed into a different planet, it did not seem to be part of this world of ours.
"I can't describe it. It made a big impression on the whole team," says Margaret.
The crew were able to investigate a "ghost" survey station at Danco Point, abandoned by the British Antarctic Survey in the 1950s and still stocked with tinned food from the time.
Human contact was resumed at the journey's southernmost point Vernadsky base, a former British outpost now home to a Ukrainian scientific team. It offered creature comforts - a long hot shower and an evening out in the bar.
"I played pool for the first time in my life. I was hopeless," says Margaret.
Before they began the four-day sail back towards Cape Horn, the crew called at Port Lockroy - the world's most remote Post Office. They sent postcards home from the tiny base that is home to hundreds of thousands of penguins and just two scientists who are posted there every summer to study the birds.
For days e-mail communication with home was cut by a power failure, forcing the crew to abandon their hectic schedule of report- sending, but bringing them closer as a team.
As the 600-mile voyage back to Cape Horn and civilisation got underway, a feeling of anti-climax set in.
Margaret, who is booked into a string of talks for Standard Life, schools and community groups, will meet up with the crew again in London later this month to swap tales of their adventure.
"Whether it has changed me remains to be seen. "I still feel not quite with it," she adds.
Following in Scott's footsteps EXPLORER Robert Swan, 41, was the first man to walk to both North and South poles.
His life is the story of his obsession with the earth's last great wildernesses which began when he watched John Mills' famous film of Scott of the Antarctic as an 11-year-old boy.
Starting as a penniless student he spent seven years raising the cash to follow in Scott's footsteps.
He was 28 when he stood at the South Pole with two other explorers, having walked there using low-tech equipment that would have been recognised by members of Scott's ill-fated 1930 expedition. Four years later, in 1989, he led a seven-strong team on a walk to the North Pole.
Ever since then he has worked to give others the chance to experience the icy wildnernesses - and generate as much publicity about the potentially disastrous threats he believes they face from pollution and climate change.
His London-based company One Step Beyond has organised trips to both Poles for young people from around the world.
This year it launched Mission Antarctica - the programme that Margaret Speedie joined.
Backed by corporate sponsors, who stump up GBP 15,000 to send an employee, new teams will follow in Margaret's footsteps each summer. The aim is to plan a clean-up of the Russian Bellinghaussen base on King George Island in the year 2000.
A One Step Beyond spokeswoman said: "It is all about taking people from commerce and industry to this remote place to inspire them and to make as many people as possible aware of what is going on there."

People: Speedie, Margaret

Seeing red over Brown's green stance Debate

Author: SECRETT, CHARLES

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/seeing-red-over-browns-green-stance-debate/docview/245226339/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: LAST week's Budget was unforgivable. At a stroke, Gordon Brown broke the Government's manifesto promise to put "the environment at the heart of policymaking", and ground into the dirt his frequently repeated pledges to use the tax system to protect the environment, make the polluter pay and be fair to future generations. The tokenistic measures on public transport, cleaner fuels and energy efficiency will not combat climate change, end exhaust pollution that kills up to 24,000 people a year, nor reduce the damage done by quarrying, pesticides, water polluters or builders to the green belt. Elevating Sir Colin Marshall, former chairman of British Airways, to head a panel of industrialists to investigate energy taxes is like putting King Herod in charge of child care. Aviation lobbyists have fought long and hard to ensure that, as one of the worst contributors to climate change, the industry pays no green taxes.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Seeing+red+over+Brown%27s+green+stance+Debate&amp;author=SECRETT%2C+CHARLES&amp;issn=02613077&amp;title=The+Guardian&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-03-23&amp;spage=019&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: LAST week's Budget was unforgivable. At a stroke, Gordon Brown broke the Government's manifesto promise to put "the environment at the heart of policymaking", and ground into the dirt his frequently repeated pledges to use the tax system to protect the environment, make the polluter pay and be fair to future generations.
The tokenistic measures on public transport, cleaner fuels and energy efficiency will not combat climate change, end exhaust pollution that kills up to 24,000 people a year, nor reduce the damage done by quarrying, pesticides, water polluters or builders to the green belt.
Elevating Sir Colin Marshall, former chairman of British Airways, to head a panel of industrialists to investigate energy taxes is like putting King Herod in charge of child care. Aviation lobbyists have fought long and hard to ensure that, as one of the worst contributors to climate change, the industry pays no green taxes.
The problem is that Treasury ministers, at heart, don't believe green taxes work. Labour backbenchers mutter darkly about regressive impacts on the poor. The all-powerful Number 10 Policy Unit is actively antagonistic to environmental action, believing it anti-industry.
Greening the tax system makes sense. Much more sense than the traditional stupidity of penalising employment and earnings, which both economists and people like, through high taxes, while rewarding pollution and waste which everyone dislikes with very low or no taxes.
Green taxes work. When Sweden introduced a tax on acid rain pollution, emissions fell by over 30 per cent.
Until Gordon Brown taxes industrial and domestic fuels on carbon content, the Prime Minister cannot deliver his vital commitment to cut carbon dioxide emissions by 20 per cent by 2010. In our newly liberalised energy market, consumers may shop around for a clean, renewable supply.
Charges made on environmental damage provide an incentive for continuous commercial improvement. Business invests in technologies and management practices which reduce pollution and resource consumption. Operating costs fall, and companies become more efficient and competitive.
Domestic markets open up for environmental equipment, encouraging others to innovate and invent. With a secure base at home, UK firms can compete in the growing global market for environmental technologies. The OECD estimates that demand will be worth some $300 billion by 2000. Today, Japanese, American and German firms grab the lion's share.
It is fair that polluters should pay more. It is also right that consumers are rewarded for being environmentally virtuous. Belgium has cut VAT on energy-saving materials from 22 per cent to 6 per cent, and made drivers of gas-guzzlers pay pounds 1,000 more in road tax than fuel-efficient car owners.
Mr Brown trimmed a paltry pounds 50 off road tax for fuel-efficient drivers, and kept VAT at 17.5 per cent on energy-saving materials for home-owners. No incentive to go green there.
Backbench opposition to green taxes in the name of the poor is misguided. The present tax system guarantees that poor people suffer most from environmental degradation. Making polluters pay and targeting revenues is the best way of raising living standards and quality of life for the disadvantaged.
Friends of the Earth ran its Budget package of energy, pollution and resource taxes through a Cambridge Econometrics forecasting model used by the Treasury. Over 12 years, they generate revenues of pounds 27 billion and reduce climate change pollution by one third. Re-using the money to reduce industry's National Insurance contributions by 3 per cent generates 391,000 new jobs.
Sectors such as retailing, banking, hotels, insurance, food, electronics, textiles and communications, which account for 70 per cent of UK exports and 60 per cent of jobs, benefit the most.
The Government has other options on how to spend the polluter-pays money to meet economic and social as well as environmental goals. Why not ensure that the poor are protected from price increases on essentials like energy and water through a generously set base-use that is free, with extravagant use charged by the unit?
Or use carbon tax revenues on a home energy conservation programme targeting the 15 million people too poor to stay warm in winter - and end the scandal of 30,000 deaths annually from cold and damp while stimulating up to 50,000 jobs.
Opinion polls show that people are willing to pay environmental taxes, particularly when revenues are spent on further reducing environmental problems. Taxes that work, are moral and popular - what more does it take for Mr Brown to go green?
Charles Secrett is director of Friends of the Earth. These personal opinions do not necessarily reflect the policy of that organisation.

Subject: Environmental policy; Budgeting; Taxation; Government spending

Warming will kill birds, animals; Climate change will hit Prairies hard -- study; Bleak Forecast from the World Wildlife Fund: [Final Edition]

Author: Struzik, Ed

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/warming-will-kill-birds-animals-climate-change/docview/252505716/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Disease and habitat loss will take a major toll on the millions of birds and animals that make use of the Prairies if the climate warms as predicted, says a study commissioned by the World Wildlife Fund. Droughts are a fact of life on the Prairies regardless of greenhouse gas emissions. A serious drought generally strikes the Prairies once every 30 to 50 years. Judy Schultz, The Journal/ Climate change could be devastating on the vegetation and habitat of the Prairies/ 970506.SCH ;

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Warming+will+kill+birds%2C+animals%3B+Climate+change+will+hit+Prairies+hard+--+study%3B+Bleak+Forecast+from+the+World+Wildlife+Fund&amp;author=Struzik%2C+Ed&amp;issn=0839296X&amp;title=Edmonton+Journal&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-03-15&amp;spage=A.5&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Disease and habitat loss will take a major toll on the millions of birds and animals that make use of the Prairies if the climate warms as predicted, says a study commissioned by the World Wildlife Fund.
The year-long study commissioned scientists to use sophisticated computer modeling programs to simulate potential changes in the environment based on the rise in greenhouse gases.
Predictive studies on climate change have been done before, but this one was somewhat unique in that it focused on the impact on vegetation and habitat.
University of Toronto scientist Jay Markham says such changes can be predicted by looking at climatic conditions that favour different types of plants and then comparing them with the various climate scenarios in the future.
"Whichever scenario you use, and there are a number of them out there," says Markham, "the end result is that the Prairies end up being particularly hard hit."
Malcolm says he was initially surprised by the findings which he arrived at with Adam Markham of World Wildlife Fund International in Washington.
"I thought that we would see the treeline rising quickly up the Rocky Mountains," he says. "And that is the case. But the pace of change on the Prairies was most pronounced."
Looked at more closely, the results aren't so difficult to explain, says Malcolm.
The Prairies are home to hundreds of thousands of shallow potholes and wetlands that provide critical habitat for millions of shorebirds, ducks, and geese, which in turn are an important food source for predators.
Even under so-called normal conditions, the slightest variation in precipitation and temperatures can significantly alter the size of these wetlands in a given year.
"Many kinds of migratory birds take shelter in temporary marshes that form on the prairie early in the year," says Malcolm.
"As the climate warms, these marshes will dry up earlier. Farmers will be tempted to use these dry conditions to cultivate earlier. And this will force birds to fly farther north for acceptable nesting sites."
While prairie birds and animals are conditioned to adapt to, and rebound from years of drought, it is believed that many species have already been pushed to the brink over the past century by agricultural development and the more than 700 prairie dams and irrigation reservoir that have obstructed or dried up waterways.
Any trend towards further warming will likely dry up many of these potholes and wetlands altogether, irrespective of the fact that global change may bring more precipitation, says Malcolm.
Droughts are a fact of life on the Prairies regardless of greenhouse gas emissions. A serious drought generally strikes the Prairies once every 30 to 50 years.
The most severe drought of the past 500 years occurred on the prairie between 1791 and 1800.
The last significant drought in 1988 led to net income losses for farmers that reached as high as 78 per cent in Saskatchewan. More than $1.3 billion in drought, crop insurance and special drought assistance was paid out to mitigate the damages that occurred that year.
The World Wildlife Fund study falls into line with many of the predictions of Environment Canada.
Scientists asked by the department to look at global warming scenarios are predicting warmer temperatures, generally drier conditions and less severe winters for the Prairies.
Some of those scientists warn that average potential crop yields on the Prairies may fall by 10 to 30 per cent unless new crop varieties are developed.
While good planning and the development of drought-resistant crops can mitigate the damage to agriculture, the same does not hold true for the natural habitat upon which birds and wildlife depend, says Tim Goos of Environment Canada.
"You may be able to plant a crop earlier or irrigate more in the hot month of August if you're a farmer worried about yields, but there's not much that can be done when the duck ponds dry up and the vegetation is scarce."
Illustration Judy Schultz, The Journal/ Climate change could be devastating on the vegetation and habitat of the Prairies/ 970506.SCH ;

Term Insurance: [FINAL Edition]

Author: Kamen, Al

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/term-insurance/docview/408360142/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott's call last weekend to independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr to wrap things up sparked a Republican nervous breakdown. But Lott, after talking to cooler heads like House Speaker Newt Gingrich (R-Ga.), got back on message and blamed President Clinton for dragging things out. Still, Lott wasn't hallucinating: Starr may give some Republicans their fondest dream, a Clinton impeachment. But if Starr doesn't move quickly, he may also end up giving them their worst imaginable nightmare: 10 years of Al Gore as president. So if Clinton is forced out in the next few months, Gore takes over and can only run once. But if Clinton hangs in there until Jan. 20, 1999, there's not only the problem of Gore running as an incumbent, but also the risk that Gore could be president for more years than any president since FDR.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Term+Insurance&amp;author=Kamen%2C+Al&amp;issn=01908286&amp;title=The+Washington+Post&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-03-11&amp;spage=A.17&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott's call last weekend to independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr to wrap things up sparked a Republican nervous breakdown. But Lott, after talking to cooler heads like House Speaker Newt Gingrich (R-Ga.), got back on message and blamed President Clinton for dragging things out.
Still, Lott wasn't hallucinating: Starr may give some Republicans their fondest dream, a Clinton impeachment. But if Starr doesn't move quickly, he may also end up giving them their worst imaginable nightmare: 10 years of Al Gore as president.
Loop Fans will recall that the 22nd Amendment -- ratified in 1951 to stop any more Democratic presidents like Franklin D. Roosevelt from being elected to a third or fourth term -- says no one can be elected more than twice. And "no person who has held the office of President, or acted as President, for more than two years of a term to which some other person was elected president" can be elected more than once.
So if Clinton is forced out in the next few months, Gore takes over and can only run once. But if Clinton hangs in there until Jan. 20, 1999, there's not only the problem of Gore running as an incumbent, but also the risk that Gore could be president for more years than any president since FDR.
4% Think Gore Was Downsized
Meanwhile, Gore still has his work cut out for him. Even though he has taken credit for government downsizing -- 350,000 federal jobs have been eliminated since he took office -- it appears the public hasn't gotten the message yet.
A new survey conducted by the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press found that 35 percent of Americans think the number of people employed by the government has increased, while 27 percent think it has stayed the same over the last three years. Thirty-four percent have heard Gore's message, saying they believe the federal work force has decreased.
Accounting for Appointees
And speaking of Gore's great work cutting the number of jobs, here's a quick quiz: What types of jobs have not been cut?
Okay, maybe that was too easy. Yes, the number of political appointees has stayed pretty much where it's been the last 10 years.
In September 1987, there were 2,801 political appointees in the federal government. Last September there were actually a few more, 2,887. On the other hand, there were as many as 3,495 getting paid in September 1991.
Shell Shock
Interior Department folks deal with paper, not real wildlife. But on Monday morning, official Robert K. Hattoy walked into his office and found a gray pigeon sitting on the floor by his filing cabinet.
The bird, it turns out, was sitting on an egg and cooing at a second egg next to it. Seems Hattoy had left a window open on Friday and the bird made itself at home over the weekend.
Other departments might have dealt with the situation differently, but because this is Interior, getting rid of the bird and eggs was a delicate matter.
The Fish and Wildlife Service was called in and they moved the pigeon and eggs to safety. A relieved Hattoy said: "As a federal employee I was trying not to violate the Hatch Act." Well, sometimes you soar with eagles, other times . . .
Castro to Head EEOC
Funny thing happened on Labor Department official Ida Castro's way to the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee hearing today. Castro, a former New Jersey lawyer and law professor who's been acting head of the department's Women's Bureau, was to attend a hearing on her recent nomination to run the bureau.
Not gonna happen. Castro instead is going to be nominated shortly by Clinton to chair the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. At least it's the same committee.
Enough Chairs for a Quartet
Just when you thought the Securities and Exchange Commission was going to be getting up to full speed with all five players, commissioner Paul R. Carey is going to be off for the next few months. He has missed recent meetings and is in New York City getting treatments for a "curable" form of cancer, SEC Chairman Arthur Levitt said yesterday during a commission meeting. Carey, son of former New York governor Hugh L. Carey, is expected to be out at least 10 weeks, Levitt said.
The 1600 Club
John Yarowsky -- now in the White House counsel's office doing judicial nominations and other matters and former general counsel to House Judiciary -- is to be partner at Patton Boggs. Mark B. Childress -- now general counsel for the Environmental Working Group and former counsel to Senate Labor Committee -- becomes senior counsel for nominations, handling judicial and nonjudicial nominations.
White House staff secretary Todd Stern, who's really running the administration's climate change initiative, is going to be doing that job officially, working with CEQ, CEA, OSTP, NEC, NSC and other relevant executive agencies. Deputy staff secretary Phillip Caplan moves up to staff secretary.
Catching Up . . .
Clinton has nominated intellectual property lawyer Q. Todd Dickinson to be deputy assistant secretary of commerce and deputy commissioner of patents and trademarks. Peggy Ellis, director of government affairs at the Cato Institute, has moved in as director of congressional and public affairs at the Republican National Committee.
Linda Ricci, former senior producer for economics at "MacNeil/Lehrer NewsHour" and more recently in private PR work, is going public, taking over as OMB associate director for communications.

People: Bill Clinton; Albert Gore Jr.; Q. Todd Dickinson

Fresh water tops environmental agenda

Author: Paul Hanley, Environment

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/fresh-water-tops-environmental-agenda/docview/348485079/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Fresh water could be the key environmental issue of the future, according to the United Nation Environment Program's (UNEP) new executive director. Klaus Topfer, a former German environment minister, says that "The potential for conflict over the world's remaining freshwater resources is great. The decline in the supply of readily available freshwater raises the very real possibility of water wars' and this issue needs urgent political attention." As we all know, the Prairies are already sensitive to drought. Droughts occur every 30-50 years with great consequence. In the "Dirty '30s," for example, wheat yields declined 32 per cent, 200,000 farms failed and 300,000 people migrated from the southern prairies. In the 1988 drought, federal assistance alone cost $1.3 billion, but Saskatchewan net farm income still dropped by 78 per cent; about 10 per cent of farmers left the agriculture sector that year. Models indicate that global warming will result in higher temperatures and reductions in soil moisture for the prairies, and increased incidence of drought. In this scenario, average potential yields may fall by 10-30 per cent.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Fresh+water+tops+environmental+agenda&amp;author=Paul+Hanley%2C+Environment&amp;issn=08324174&amp;title=Star+-+Phoenix&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-03-03&amp;spage=C.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Fresh water could be the key environmental issue of the future, according to the United Nation Environment Program's (UNEP) new executive director. Klaus Topfer, a former German environment minister, says that "The potential for conflict over the world's remaining freshwater resources is great. The decline in the supply of readily available freshwater raises the very real possibility of water wars' and this issue needs urgent political attention."
An adequate supply of safe, clean water is considered the most important precondition for sustaining human life, for maintaining ecosystems that support all life, and for achieving sustainable development. Water demand is already being affected by the rise in population, the acceleration of per capita use, irrigation and power production. Meanwhile, supply is increasingly in question due to the global warming trend.
That is why freshwater politics and resources will be the focus of attention at several high level events this year. Environment ministers and senior government officials from around the world are currently focusing on this topic at the second meeting of the UNEP High-level Committee of Ministers and Officials in Nairobi. It will also be the focus of discussions at the forthcoming Commission on Sustainable Development meeting in New York in April.
Water supplies are a key concern of scientists researching the the impact of global climate change on the Canadian prairies. While water wars are unlikely in our context, significant economic and ecological disruptions are, according to Responding to Global Climate Change in the Prairies, a report published by Environment Canada.
As we all know, the Prairies are already sensitive to drought. Droughts occur every 30-50 years with great consequence. In the "Dirty '30s," for example, wheat yields declined 32 per cent, 200,000 farms failed and 300,000 people migrated from the southern prairies. In the 1988 drought, federal assistance alone cost $1.3 billion, but Saskatchewan net farm income still dropped by 78 per cent; about 10 per cent of farmers left the agriculture sector that year.
Models indicate that global warming will result in higher temperatures and reductions in soil moisture for the prairies, and increased incidence of drought. In this scenario, average potential yields may fall by 10-30 per cent.
According to the report, the option to increase irrigation may not be possible due to uncertain water supply. Crop choices and adaptation for drought has more potential, but only if accelerated R&D is supported.
Drought conditions also affect the northern forests. In 1988, insect infestations, higher seedling mortality and fire damage and suppression costs were key results. With global warming, we can expect significant shifts in forest productivity. "In general, the boreal forest is likely to decrease in area, biomass, and carbon stock, with a move toward younger age-classes and considerable disruption at its southern boundaries."
Other impacts of global waring in our region will include: increased energy consumption and decreased efficiency of power production as reservoir water temperatures increase; increased insurance premiums and health care costs; lower wildfowl populations as potholes dry up; and decreasing tourism potential as, for example, recreational fishing deteriorates.
Ironically, global warming could also cause increased precipitation, with more storms and greater stress on dams and water control structures, meaning more flooding.
In addition to efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in order to reduce global warming, there are a number of mitigation efforts that can be made to ease the impact of climate change when it occurs.
- In agriculture, more research on moisture management and drought tolerance is needed.
- Forests can be managed to reduce fire impacts, replanting with more adaptive species, and better logging practices can be adopted to conserve soil and water resources.
- In the energy field, conservation and efficiency measures reduce demand, making future stress on energy supplies more manageable.
- The insurance industry can reduce investment in companies contributing to greenhouse gas emissions, and lobby for higher energy efficiency standards in building codes.
Finally, more measures are needed to increase the ability of regions and municipalities to share water resources equitably, based on a river basin approach.

Insurance firms count cost of global warming: [1 Edition]

Author: CHRISTOPHER CAIRNS Environment Correspondent

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/insurance-firms-count-cost-global-warming/docview/326707760/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Premiums in the worst hit areas of the country - for example, parts of the storm-lashed south-west England -are already beginning to increase. The ABI confirmed that some properties with a particularly bad record of flood damage are being considered uninsurable and owners can be denied policies. Leading insurers told the previous government that it believed climate change - exacerbated, if not caused by human activity - was to blame for a fourfold increase in domestic insurance costs over the past 30 years. "Our climate is definitely changing, bringing more extreme weather, particularly during wetter and warmer winters," said Andrew Dlugolecki, the group assistant general manager for underwriting at General Accident and a committee member of the United Nations Environment Programme Insurance and Sustainable Growth Initiative. Richard Dixon, the head of research at Friends of the Earth Scotland, said: "It is absolutely crucial to have the insurance industry in this country talking the same language as environmentalists and recognising the threats of climate change.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Insurance+firms+count+cost+of+global+warming&amp;author=CHRISTOPHER+CAIRNS+Environment+Correspondent&amp;issn=03075850&amp;title=The+Scotsman&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-02-23&amp;spage=7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: STORM-damaged households in Britain received record payouts from insurance companies last year, figures will reveal later this month.
Returns from the industry for 1997 are still being collected but the Association of British Insurers predicts that the total of weather-related claims will top the GBP 500 million paid out in 1996 - itself twice the amount for 1995. The continued surge in the costs of storms, floods and the increasing frequency of freak weather will undoubtedly be raised with Government ministers - the insurance industry is already the leading business sector pressing for urgent action to tackle the causes of global warming.
"The total for 1997 will be worse than for the previous year principally because of the storms early last year, but not because of extreme cold weather," an ABI source said. "This year does not look as if it is likely to get any better - we have already had to pay out around GBP 300 million for the storms over Christmas and New Year." Figures obtained from Direct Line, the Royal Bank of Scotland subsidiary, confirm the upward trend in weather-related insurance payouts.
Last year the company, which has about a million domestic customers UK wide, paid GBP 27 million on claims of weather damaged property - damaged roofs, burst pipes and floods.
"This represents an 8 per cent increase on the previous year's figure. However, there were significant differences experienced between different types of claim," said a spokeswoman, Gill Murphy. "Storm-related claims were almost a third higher than in the previous year - largely due to January's storms - while burst pipe claims were down by around a third compared to the previous 12 months.
"It is extremely difficult to make any accurate predictions over future trends in weather-related claims. However, a great deal of volatility is inevitable due to changing weather patterns."
Premiums in the worst hit areas of the country - for example, parts of the storm-lashed south-west England -are already beginning to increase. The ABI confirmed that some properties with a particularly bad record of flood damage are being considered uninsurable and owners can be denied policies. Leading insurers told the previous government that it believed climate change - exacerbated, if not caused by human activity - was to blame for a fourfold increase in domestic insurance costs over the past 30 years. "Our climate is definitely changing, bringing more extreme weather, particularly during wetter and warmer winters," said Andrew Dlugolecki, the group assistant general manager for underwriting at General Accident and a committee member of the United Nations Environment Programme Insurance and Sustainable Growth Initiative. Richard Dixon, the head of research at Friends of the Earth Scotland, said: "It is absolutely crucial to have the insurance industry in this country talking the same language as environmentalists and recognising the threats of climate change.
"They are the first sector of commerce to see that climate change is going to alter completely the way they do business and people can see it can no longer be dismissed as the rantings of extremists." It has been argued that Scottish firms are already feeling the effects of climate change, including ski resorts grinding to a halt for lack of snow.

Green issues top list: poll: [Final Edition]

Author: Spears, Tom

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/green-issues-top-list-poll/docview/433248078/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: "The environment is coming back as a top-of-mind issue," Doug Miller, president of Environics, told an Ottawa conference on climate change yesterday. The trend cuts across age groups, sexes and geographic regions. Sixty per cent of Canadians believe cuts to greenhouse-gas emissions (carbon dioxide from burning fuel) would hurt the economy today, he said. "That's a gut feeling of Canadians," he said. "What it suggests is that the Clinton administration's approach would resonate very favourably here. ... That is that we have to buy some insurance against future costs" by reducing our pollution, especially the "greenhouse gases" that threaten our climate.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Green+issues+top+list%3A+poll&amp;author=Spears%2C+Tom&amp;issn=03841294&amp;title=The+Gazette&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-02-18&amp;spage=A.15&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Another "great green wave" is swelling in Canadian public opinion, just like the wave that made the environment the top issue of the late 1980s, says the head of a major polling firm.
"The environment is coming back as a top-of-mind issue," Doug Miller, president of Environics, told an Ottawa conference on climate change yesterday. The trend cuts across age groups, sexes and geographic regions.
And he said the public is demanding environmental protection today, despite its possible economic costs, to prevent environmental damage in the future.
"People have zero tolerance for further risk," Miller said. "They're saying: Let's err on the side of environmental caution, even if we have to pay an economic price."
Sixty per cent of Canadians believe cuts to greenhouse-gas emissions (carbon dioxide from burning fuel) would hurt the economy today, he said.
But 84 per cent believe doing nothing to reduce these emissions would hurt the economy in the future.
"That's a gut feeling of Canadians," he said. "What it suggests is that the Clinton administration's approach would resonate very favourably here. ... That is that we have to buy some insurance against future costs" by reducing our pollution, especially the "greenhouse gases" that threaten our climate.
Seventy-three per cent of those surveyed said they would choose environmental protection ahead of economic progress. That's up from 67 per cent six years ago.
"The important thing is that it's because they believe the two (a clean environment and a healthy economy) go together," Miller says. "They don't think it's a trade-off."
Miller was speaking at a conference on climate change organized by a federal advisory group, the National Round Table on the Environmental and the Economy.
Environics surveys Canadian opinions on a wide variety of environmental issues twice a year, and has done so for 10 years. A survey of this type, covering 1,500 adults, is considered accurate within 2.5 percentage points 19 times out of 20.
Miller said the growing wave has been evident for more than a year, and was confirmed by Environics' latest survey, just two weeks ago.
It's still under the surface, but growing, he said. He expects it to hit fully within four years, bringing a second era in which Canadians place the environment ahead of all other issues.
Why the change?
For one thing, the environment never really went away as an issue. People stopped listing it as their most important issue, he said, but still held on to it as a central element of faith.
By far the greatest issue on Canadians' minds is the quality of the air - not just where we live, but globally.
The thinning ozone layer is our top worry. "The ozone hole is as powerful an image to Canadians as the picture of the Earth from space."
Number two, but catching up, is climate change. But here there's still a lot of confusion.
"People believe the atmosphere is coming unravelled," Miller said. "Beyond that they don't have a lot of understanding what's going on."
Fo instance, a lot of people used to believe the thinning ozone layer was somehow causing the climate to change. That misunderstanding clung for years, but has finally started to disappear.
Then there's the recent Kyoto conference on reducing the gases that cause global warming. Asked two weeks ago what happened, 67 per cent cent either knew nothing about it or knew "very little." Another eight per cent were't sure what Canada had done, but believed our country did badly at the conference.
Just two per cent knew Canada had promised to cut greenhouse gas emissions such as carbon dioxide.
Still, he said, we're learning. We did measureably better on a series of questions about how climate change works. And 45 per cent said driving a car is the most environmentally damaging thing they do.
"We're calling the automobile the next blue box, the next area of focused public concern."

`Great green wave' grows: [Final Edition]

Author: Spears, Tom

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/great-green-wave-grows/docview/244622344/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Sixty per cent of Canadians believe cuts to greenhouse gas emissions (carbon dioxide from burning fuel) would hurt the economy now, he said. However, 84 per cent believe doing nothing to reduce emissions would hurt the economy in the future. "That's a gut feeling of Canadians," he said. "What it suggests is that the Clinton administration's approach would resonate very favorably here . . . That is that we have to buy some insurance against future costs" by reducing our pollution, especially the "greenhouse gases" that threaten our climate. Full text: Another "great green wave" is swelling in Canadian public opinion, just like the wave that made the environment the top issue of the late 1980s, says the head of a major polling firm.
"The environment is coming back as a top-of-mind issue," Doug Miller, president of Environics, told an Ottawa conference on climate change Tuesday.

"People have zero tolerance for further risk," Miller said. "They're saying: Let's err on the side of environmental caution even if we have to pay an economic price."

Miller said the growing wave has been evident for more than a year, and was confirmed by Environics' latest survey two weeks ago.
It's still under the surface, but growing, he said. He expects it to hit fully within four years, bringing a second era in which Canadians place the environment ahead of all other issues.

Canadians think green, poll reveals: 73% choose protection of the environment over economic progress: [Final Edition]

Author: Spears, Tom

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/canadians-think-green-poll-reveals-73-choose/docview/240149587/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: "That's a gut feeling of Canadians," he said. "What it suggests is that the Clinton administration's approach would resonate very favourably here. ... That is that we have to buy some insurance against future costs" by reducing our pollution, especially the "greenhouse gases" that threaten our climate. Even when corporations made genuine progress, Mr. [Doug Miller] says, "Canadians keep moving the yardsticks. They want greater efforts and therefore corporations keep falling behind." The thinning ozone layer is the top worry. "The ozone hole is as powerful an image to Canadians as the picture of the Earth from space."

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Canadians+think+green%2C+poll+reveals%3A+73%25+choose+protection+of+the+environment+over+economic+progress&amp;author=Spears%2C+Tom&amp;issn=08393222&amp;title=The+Ottawa+Citizen&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-02-18&amp;spage=A.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Another "great green wave" is swelling in Canadian public opinion, just like the one that made environment the top issue of the late 1980s, the head of a major polling firm says.
"The environment is coming back as a top-of-mind issue," Doug Miller, president of Environics, told an Ottawa conference on climate change yesterday.
The trend cuts across age groups, sexes and geographic regions. And he said the public is demanding environmental protection today, despite its possible economic costs, to prevent environmental damage in the future.
"People have zero tolerance for further risk," Mr. Miller said. "They're saying: Let's err on the side of environmental caution even if we have to pay an economic price."
Sixty per cent of Canadians believe cuts to greenhouse gas emissions (carbon dioxide from burning fuel) would hurt the economy today, he said.
But 84 per cent believe doing nothing to reduce these emissions would hurt the economy in the future.
"That's a gut feeling of Canadians," he said. "What it suggests is that the Clinton administration's approach would resonate very favourably here. ... That is that we have to buy some insurance against future costs" by reducing our pollution, especially the "greenhouse gases" that threaten our climate.
Seventy-three per cent of those surveyed said they would choose environmental protection ahead of economic progress. That's up from 67 per cent six years ago.
"The important thing is that it's because they believe the two (a clean environment and a healthy economy) go together," Mr. Miller says. "They don't think it's a tradeoff."
Mr. Miller was speaking at a conference on climate change organized by a federal advisory group, the National Round Table on the Environment and the Economy.
Environics surveys Canadian opinions on a variety of environmental issues twice a year and has done so for 10 years. A survey of this type, covering 1,500 adults, is considered accurate within 2.5 percentage points 19 times out of 20.
Mr. Miller said the growing trend has been evident for more than a year, and was confirmed by Environics' latest survey just two weeks ago.
It's still under the surface, but growing, he said. He expects it to hit fully within four years.
Why the change? For one thing, the environment never went away as an issue. People stopped listing it as their most important issue, he said, but still held on to it as a central element of faith.
Corporate hucksterism upset people. Starting about six years ago, the public slowly became fed up with too many "green" products that cost more than regular ones, but brought dubious benefits.
Even when corporations made genuine progress, Mr. Miller says, "Canadians keep moving the yardsticks. They want greater efforts and therefore corporations keep falling behind."
By far the greatest issue on Canadians' minds is the quality of the air -- not just where we live, but globally.
The thinning ozone layer is the top worry. "The ozone hole is as powerful an image to Canadians as the picture of the Earth from space."
No. 2, but catching up, is climate change. But here there's still a lot of confusion.
"People believe the atmosphere is coming unravelled," Mr. Miller said. "Beyond that they don't have a lot of understanding of what's going on."
For instance, a lot of people used to believe the thinning ozone layer was somehow causing the climate to change. That misunderstanding hung on for years, but has finally started to disappear.
