`A TIME TO BUILD THE AMERICA WITHIN OUR REACH': [THIRD EDITION]

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/time-build-america-within-our-reach/docview/403937344/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: For 209 years it has been the president's duty to report to you on the state of the union. Because of the hard work and high purpose of the American people, these are good times for America. We have more than 14 million new jobs, the lowest unemployment in 24 years, the lowest inflation in 30 years, incomes are rising and we have the highest home ownership in history. Crime has dropped for a record five years in a row, and the welfare rolls are at their lowest levels in 27 years. Our leadership in the world is unrivaled. Ladies and gentlemen, the state of our union is strong. We must not go back to unwise spending or untargeted tax cuts that risk reopening the deficit. Last year, together we enacted targeted tax cuts so that the typical middle class family will now have the lowest tax rates in 20 years. My plan to balance the budget next year includes both new investments and new tax cuts targeted to the needs of working families: for education, for child care, for the environment. . . . And because of these actions, I have something to say to every family listening to us tonight: Your children can go on to college. If you know a child from a poor family, tell her not to give up, she can go on to college. If you know a young couple struggling with bills, worried they won't be able to send their children to college, tell them not to give up, their children can go on to college. If you know somebody who's caught in a dead-end job and afraid he can't afford the classes necessary to get better jobs for the rest of his life, tell him not to give up, he can go on to college. . . .

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=%60A+TIME+TO+BUILD+THE+AMERICA+WITHIN+OUR+REACH%27&amp;author=&amp;issn=07431791&amp;title=Boston+Globe&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-01-28&amp;spage=A.14&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   STATE OF THE UNION ADDRESS
Following are excerpts from President Clinton's State of the Union Address last night:
Mr. Speaker, Mr. Vice President, members of the 105th Congress, distinguished guests, my fellow Americans: . . .
For 209 years it has been the president's duty to report to you on the state of the union. Because of the hard work and high purpose of the American people, these are good times for America. We have more than 14 million new jobs, the lowest unemployment in 24 years, the lowest inflation in 30 years, incomes are rising and we have the highest home ownership in history. Crime has dropped for a record five years in a row, and the welfare rolls are at their lowest levels in 27 years. Our leadership in the world is unrivaled. Ladies and gentlemen, the state of our union is strong.
But with barely 700 days left in the 20th century, this is not a time to rest. It is a time to build -- to build the America within our reach. . . .
Rarely have Americans lived through so much change in so many ways in so short a time. Quietly, but with gathering force, the ground has shifted beneath our feet as we have moved into an information age, a global economy, a truly new world.
For five years now, we have met the challenge of these changes as Americans have at every turning point in our history, by renewing the very idea of America, widening the circle of opportunity, deepening the meaning of our freedom, forging a more perfect union. . . .
We have moved past the sterile debate between those who say government is the enemy and those who say government is the answer. My fellow Americans, we have found a third way. We have the smallest government in 35 years, but a more progressive one. We have a smaller government but a stronger nation. Even better days ahead
We are moving steadily toward an even stronger America in the 21st century -- an economy that offers opportunity, a society rooted in responsibility, and a nation that lives as a community. . . .
When I took office, the deficit for 1998 was projected to be $357 billion, and heading higher. This year, our deficit is projected to be $10 billion, and heading lower. . . . The federal deficit, once so incomprehensively large that it had 11 zeros, will be simply zero. . . . I will submit to Congress, for 1999, the first balanced budget in 30 years. . . .
And if we hold fast to fiscal discipline, we may balance the budget this year -- four years ahead of schedule. . . .
We must not go back to unwise spending or untargeted tax cuts that risk reopening the deficit. Last year, together we enacted targeted tax cuts so that the typical middle class family will now have the lowest tax rates in 20 years. My plan to balance the budget next year includes both new investments and new tax cuts targeted to the needs of working families: for education, for child care, for the environment. . . .
If we balance the budget for next year, it is projected that we'll then have a sizeable surplus in the years that immediately follow.
What should we do with this projected surplus? I have a simple four-word answer: Save Social Security first. . . .
Tonight I propose that we reserve 100 percent of the surplus -- that's every penny of any surplus -- until we have taken all the necessary measures to strengthen the Social Security system for the 21st century. . . .
Let us say to all Americans watching tonight, whether you're 70 or 50, or whether you just started paying into the system, Social Security will be there when you need it. . . .
In an economy that honors opportunity, all Americans must be able to reap the rewards of prosperity. Because these times are good, we can afford to take one simple, sensible step to help millions of workers struggling to provide for their families. We should raise the minimum wage. . . .
Last year, from this podium, I said that education has to be our highest priority. I laid out a ten-point plan to move us forward and urged all of us to let politics stop at the schoolhouse door. Progress on education
Since then, this Congress . . . and the American people have responded . . . -- expanding public school choice, opening the way to 3,000 charter schools, working to connect every classroom in the country to the information superhighway, committing to expand Head Start to a million children, launching America Reads, sending literally thousands of college students into our elementary schools to make sure all our 8-year-olds can read.
Last year I proposed -- and you passed -- 220,000 new Pell Grant scholarships for deserving students. Student loans, already less expensive and easier to repay -- now you get to deduct the interest. Families all over America now can put their savings into new, tax-free education IRAs. And this year, for the first two years of college, families will get a $1,500 tax credit -- a Hope Scholarship that will cover the cost of most community college tuition. And for junior and senior year, graduate school, and job training, there is a lifetime learning credit. . . .
And because of these actions, I have something to say to every family listening to us tonight: Your children can go on to college. If you know a child from a poor family, tell her not to give up, she can go on to college. If you know a young couple struggling with bills, worried they won't be able to send their children to college, tell them not to give up, their children can go on to college. If you know somebody who's caught in a dead-end job and afraid he can't afford the classes necessary to get better jobs for the rest of his life, tell him not to give up, he can go on to college. . . .
We must make our public elementary and secondary schools the world's best as well -- by raising standards, raising expectations and raising accountability. . . .
Every parent already knows the key: good teachers and small classes. Tonight, I propose the first ever national effort to reduce class size in the early grades. . . . My balanced budget will help to hire 100,000 new teachers who have passed the state competency tests. Now with these teachers . . . we will actually be able to reduce class size in the first, second and third grades to an average of 18 students a class all across America.
If I've got the math right, more teachers teaching smaller classes requires more classrooms. So I also propose a school construction tax cut to help communities modernize or build 5,000 schools.
We must also demand greater accountability. When we promote a child from grade to grade who hasn't mastered the work, we don't do that child any favors. It is time to end social promotion in America's schools. . . . Let's shape global economy
As we enter the 21st century, the global economy requires us to seek opportunity not just at home, but in all the markets of the world. We must shape this global economy, not shrink from it. . . . This is a great opportunity for America. I know there is opposition to more comprehensive trade agreements. . . . I believe that the opposition is rooted in two fears: first, that our trading partners will have lower environmental and labor standards, which will give them an unfair advantage in our market and do their own people no favors, even if there's more business; and second, that if we have more trade, more of our workers will lose their jobs and have to start over.
I think we should seek to advance worker and environmental standards around the world. . . . I have made it abundantly clear that it should be a part of our trade agenda. . . .
This year I will send legislation to Congress, and ask other nations to join us, to fight the most intolerable labor practice of all -- abusive child labor.
We should also offer help and hope to those Americans temporarily left behind with the global marketplace or by the march of technology, which may have nothing to do with trade. . . . That's why we must do more . . . to help workers who lose their jobs for whatever reason. . . .
I ask the Congress to continue its bipartisan work to consolidate the tangle of training programs we have today into one single GI Bill for Workers, a simple skills grant so people can, on their own, move quickly to new jobs, to higher incomes and brighter futures. . . .
I will also renew my request for the fast track negotiating authority necessary to open more new markets and create more new jobs, which every President has had for two decades. . . .
You know, whether we like it or not, in ways that are mostly positive, the world's economies are more and more interconnected and interdependent. Today, an economic crisis anywhere can affect economies everywhere. Recent months have brought serious financial problems to Thailand, Indonesia, South Korea and beyond.
Now why should Americans be concerned about this?
First, these countries are our customers. If they sink into recession, they won't be able to buy the goods we'd like to sell them. Second, they're also our competitors, so if their currencies lose their value and go down, then the price of their goods will drop, flooding our market and others with much cheaper goods, which makes it a lot tougher for our people to compete. And finally, they are our strategic partners. Their stability bolsters our security. . . . Value work, not welfare
The American economy remains sound and strong, and I want to keep it that way. But because the turmoil in Asia will have an impact on all the world's economies, including ours, making that negative impact as small as possible is the right thing to do for America, and the right thing to do for a safer world. . . . A strong nation rests on the rock of responsibility. A society rooted in responsibility must first promote the value of work, not welfare. We could be proud that after decades of finger-pointing and failure, together we ended the old welfare system. . . .
We still have a lot more to do, all of us, to make welfare reform a success: providing child care, helping families move closer to available jobs, challenging more companies to join our Welfare to Work Partnership, increasing child-support collections from deadbeat parents who have a duty to support their own children. I also want to thank Congress for restoring some of the benefits to immigrants who are here legally and working hard. And I hope you will finish that job this year. . . .
A hundred and sixty million of our fellow citizens are in managed care plans. These plans save money, and they can improve care. But medical decisions ought to be made by medical doctors -- not insurance company accountants.
I urge this Congress to . . . write into law a consumer bill of rights that says this: You have the right to know all your medical options, not just the cheapest. You have the right to choose the doctor you want for the care you need. You have the right to emergency room care wherever and whenever you need it. You have the right to keep your medical records confidential. . . .
Millions of Americans between the ages of 55 and 65 have lost their health insurance. Some are retired. Some are laid off. Some lose their coverage when their spouses retire. After a lifetime of work, they're left with nowhere to turn. So I ask the Congress, let these hard-working Americans buy into the Medicare system. . . .
Next, we must help parents protect their children from the gravest health threat that they face: an epidemic of teen smoking spread by multimillion dollar marketing campaigns. I challenge Congress: Let's pass bipartisan, comprehensive legislation that will improve public health, protect our tobacco farmers, and change the way tobacco companies do business forever. . . .
Child care is the next frontier we must face to enable people to succeed at home and at work. . . . So here's my plan: Help families to pay for child care for a million more children; scholarships and background checks for child-care workers, and a new emphasis on early learning; tax credits for businesses that provide child care for their employees; and a larger child-care tax credit for working families. . . . If you pass my plan, what this means is that a family of four with an income of $35,000 and high child-care costs will no longer pay a single penny of federal income tax. . . .
A society rooted in responsibility must provide safe streets, safe schools, and safe neighborhoods. . . . I can report to you tonight that . . . violent crime is down, robbery is down, assault is down, burglary is down for five years in a row all across America.
Now, we need to finish the job of putting 100,000 more police on our streets. Again, I ask Congress to pass a juvenile crime bill that provides more prosecutors and probation officers to crack down on gangs and guns and drugs and bar violent juveniles from buying guns for life.
And I ask you to dramatically expand our support for after school programs. . . . Federal courts need help
Police, prosecutors, and prevention programs -- good as they are, they can't work if our court system doesn't work. Today there are large numbers of vacancies in our federal courts. Here is what the Chief Justice of the United States wrote: "Judicial vacancies cannot remain at such high levels indefinitely without eroding the quality of justice." I simply ask the United States Senate to heed this plea and vote on the highly qualified nominees before you, up or down. . . . We must exercise responsibility not just at home but around the world. On the eve of a new century, we have the power and the duty to build a new era of peace and security. But make no mistake about it; today's possibilities are not tomorrow's guarantees. America must stand against the poisoned appeals of extreme nationalism. We must combat an unholy excess of new threats from terrorists, international criminals and drug traffickers. . . .
Within days, I will ask the Senate for its advice and consent to make Hungary, Poland, and the Czech Republic the newest members of NATO. . . . By taking in new members and working closely with new partners, including Russia and Ukraine, NATO can help to assure that Europe is a stronghold for peace in the 21st century.
Next, I will ask Congress to continue its support for our troops and their mission in Bosnia. . . . This Christmas, Hillary and I traveled to Sarajevo with Senator and Mrs. Dole and a bipartisan congressional delegation. We saw children playing in the streets where, two years ago, they were hiding from snipers and shells. The shops were filled with food. The cafes were alive with conversation. The progress there is unmistakable; but it is not yet irreversible. . . .
I ask Congress to join me in pursuing an ambitious agenda to reduce the serious threat of weapons of mass destruction. . . . Together we must also confront the new hazards of chemical and biological weapons, and the outlaw states, terrorists, and organized criminals seeking to acquire them.
Saddam Hussein has spent the better part of this decade . . . developing nuclear, chemical, and biological weapons and the missiles to deliver them.
The United Nations weapons inspectors have done a truly remarkable job finding and destroying more of Iraq's arsenal than was destroyed during the entire gulf war. Now, Saddam Hussein wants to stop them from completing their mission. I know I speak for everyone in this chamber, Republicans and Democrats, when I say to Saddam Hussein, `You cannot defy the will of the world,' and when I say to him, `You have used weapons of mass destruction before; we are determined to deny you the capacity to use them again.' . . . Let's get square with the UN
Finally, it's long past time to make good on our debt to the United Nations. . . .
Everyone knows elections have become too expensive, fueling a fund-raising arms race. This year, by March the 6th, at long last the Senate will actually vote on bipartisan campaign finance reform proposed by Senators McCain and Feingold. Let's be clear: A vote against McCain-Feingold is a vote for soft money and for the status quo. I ask you to strengthen our democracy and pass campaign finance reform this year.
But at least equally important, we have to address the real reason for the explosion in campaign costs -- the high cost of media advertising. . . . I will formally request that the Federal Communications Commission act to provide free or reduced-cost television time for candidates who observe spending limits voluntarily. The airwaves are a public trust, and broadcasters also have to help us in this effort to strengthen our democracy. . . .
Like every taxpayer, I'm outraged by the reports of abuses by the IRS. We need some changes there: new citizen advocacy panels, a stronger taxpayer advocate, phone lines open 24 hours a day, relief for innocent taxpayers. . . . Tonight I ask the Senate: Follow the House; pass the bipartisan package as your first order of business. . . .
A nation that lives as a community must value all its communities. For the past five years, we have worked to bring the spark of private enterprise to inner city and poor rural areas with community development banks, more commercial loans into poor neighborhoods, cleanup of polluted sites for development. . . . We should also give poor families more help to move into homes of their own, and we should use tax cuts to spur the construction of more low-income housing. . . . A clean water challenge
I ask you to join me in launching a new Clean Water initiative, a far-reaching effort to clean our rivers, our lakes, and our coastal waters for our children.
Our overriding environmental challenge tonight is the worldwide problem of climate change, global warming, the gathering crisis that requires worldwide action. . . . I propose $6 billion in tax cuts, in research and development, to encourage innovation, renewable energy, fuel-efficient cars, energy-efficient homes. . . . We have always found a way to clean the environment and grow the economy at the same time. And when it comes to global warming, we'll do it again. . . .
We're becoming more and more and more diverse. . . . I've launched this national initiative on race to help us recognize our common interests and to bridge the opportunity gaps that are keeping us from becoming one America.
Let us begin by recognizing what we still must overcome. Discrimination against any American is un-American. We must vigorously enforce the laws that make it illegal. I ask your help to end the backlog at the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. . . .
We should also recognize that the greatest progress we can make toward building one America lies in the progress we make for all Americans, without regard to race. When we open the doors of college to all Americans, when we rid all our streets of crime, when there are jobs available to people from all our neighborhoods, when we make sure all parents have the child care they need, we're helping to build one nation. . . . Make science serve humanity
With shared values and meaningful opportunities and honest communications and citizen service, we can unite a diverse people in freedom and mutual respect. We are many; we must be one. . . .
As important as scientific progress is, we must continue to see that science serves humanity, not the other way around. We must prevent the misuse of genetic tests to discriminate against any American, and we must ratify the ethical consensus of the scientific and religious communities, and ban the cloning of human beings. . . .
I ask all Americans to support our project to restore all our treasures so that the generations of the 21st century can see for themselves the images and the words that are the old and continuing glory of America, an America that has continued to rise through every age against every challenge, a people of great works and greater possibilities, who have always, always, found the wisdom and strength to come together as one nation, to widen the circle of opportunity, to deepen the meaning of our freedom, to form that more perfect union.
Let that be our gift to the 21st century.
God bless you, and God bless the United States.
Illustration Caption: President Clinton: "This is not a time to rest; it is a time to build." / AP PHOTO

Meacher signals wider use of green taxation: [London edition]

Author: Boulton, Leyla

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/meacher-signals-wider-use-green-taxation/docview/248612076/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: The government plans to make more extensive use of green taxation to protect the environment, Michael Meacher, the environment minister, warned yesterday. Mr Meacher told a seminar organised by the Institute for Public Policy Studies : "Until you hit people's pockets, a lot of people won't take [the environment] seriously." But Mr Meacher stressed the government had no intention of increasing companies' and individuals' overall tax burden. Instead, it believed that new taxes to discourage pollution and the waste of natural resources should be accompanied by a cut in national insurance contributions to "bear down on unemployment".

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Meacher+signals+wider+use+of+green+taxation&amp;author=Boulton%2C+Leyla&amp;issn=03071766&amp;title=Financial+Times&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-01-28&amp;spage=15&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The government plans to make more extensive use of green taxation to protect the environment, Michael Meacher, the environment minister, warned yesterday.
He said the government, agreed that "green taxes were the only measures likely to have sufficient impact to change [people's] behaviour in many circumstances".
Mr Meacher told a seminar organised by the Institute for Public Policy Studies : "Until you hit people's pockets, a lot of people won't take [the environment] seriously."
Without such measures, he said, the government would be unable to implement its ambitious strategy for curbing fossil fuel consumption, which is linked to climate change.
Gordon Brown, the chancellor, has undertaken to consider green taxes for possible inclusion in the March Budget.
But Mr Meacher stressed the government had no intention of increasing companies' and individuals' overall tax burden. Instead, it believed that new taxes to discourage pollution and the waste of natural resources should be accompanied by a cut in national insurance contributions to "bear down on unemployment".
He laid down four other conditions for green taxation, modelled on the pioneering landfill tax introduced in October 1996:
* Government should explain clearly what the environmental goals of a given tax are.
* Some of the revenues raised should be "earmarked" for purposes that have widespread support, such as "cutting payroll taxes or improving public transport".
* Government should give the public and business plenty of advance warning and consult widely on whatever it is proposing.
* Government should use some of the money raised to help people and industry adapt to the tax at the same time as they cut pollution and waste.
Mr Meacher conceded that the Treasury did not accept the principle of "hypothetication" - earmarking some revenue raised for specific purposes, such as environmental protection.
Although there would be a continuing need for regulations, for instance to ban hazardous substances, he said, "green fiscal measures must be a main instrument" to achieve environmental protection.
Until then, it would remain "cheaper for many companies to adopt capital intensive and highly polluting processes rather than less polluting processes which entail high levels of employment", he said.
Mr Meacher added that Sweden's success in taxing emissions of sulphur dioxide and oxides of nitrogen to tackle air pollution was particularly encouraging. But the government was keen to ensure green taxes did not hurt the poor. Copyright Financial Times Limited 1998. All Rights Reserved.

LETTERS TO THE EDITOR: [ALL EDITION]

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/letters-editor/docview/270570416/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: In 1993 aquiculture produced more than 16 million tons of fish, and the capacity has expanded during the past decade to an annual rate of 10 percent by quantity and 14 percent by value. In 1993 fish farms produced 22 percent of the food fish consumed in the world, and 90 percent of the oysters sold. Prefer salmon? Norwegian salmon farms alone produce 400 million pounds per year. Interestingly, when Green Peace founder Patrick Moore walked away from the group 10 years ago, he believed he was wrapping things up, not jumping ship. Now he is enduring catcalls of "eco-Judas." This is because he wished to return to his native British Columbia to raise salmon. Put me down as one who is skeptical of the politically correct environmental emergencies. So far as I am concerned, except for my own orange and grapefruit trees, I consider other trees as some farmer's cash crop. Fixation on the preservation of the old growth forests is puzzling. If people are really concerned about the need to remove CO2 from the atmosphere they need to replace the old trees with fast-growing young trees. Don't these two statements just say it all! I trained at the University of Michigan and Harvard. Their two main hospitals were headed at the time by physicians. I remember as a lowly resident physician at Massa chusetts General Hospital, one of the most prestigious medical institutions in the world, that I could speak with Dr. John Knowles, the "CEO" (although then known as the chief administrator) at any time. If I had a concern about patient care, he was there to address it. Contrast this with trying to speak with Michael Covert. One is lucky as a staff physician if he can get an appointment in a week. Then, of course, he would have to travel downtown to the high-rent Hollywood 20 complex where the executive offices are. This in itself is a mystery, as there are thousands of empty square feet of potential office space on the main campus of Memorial Hospital. Perhaps the bottom liners on the hospital board should address that issue.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=LETTERS+TO+THE+EDITOR&amp;author=&amp;issn=26414503&amp;title=Sarasota+Herald+Tribune&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-01-25&amp;spage=4.F&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Science can fix many problems
The "Cast a wider net" editorial Jan. 17 concentrates only on the dark side without any mention of the fact that aquiculture is already feeding most of Europe from its fish farms, which are not polluted. Genetic engineers have already designed fish for better flavor and color, as well as for faster growth, improved disease resistance and other traits.
Two species of silver carp and grass carp already rank among the most consumed fish worldwide. A specially bred tilapia known as the aquatic chicken takes only six months to reach its harvestable size of about a pound and a half.
In 1993 aquiculture produced more than 16 million tons of fish, and the capacity has expanded during the past decade to an annual rate of 10 percent by quantity and 14 percent by value. In 1993 fish farms produced 22 percent of the food fish consumed in the world, and 90 percent of the oysters sold. Prefer salmon? Norwegian salmon farms alone produce 400 million pounds per year. Interestingly, when Green Peace founder Patrick Moore walked away from the group 10 years ago, he believed he was wrapping things up, not jumping ship. Now he is enduring catcalls of "eco-Judas." This is because he wished to return to his native British Columbia to raise salmon.
This is no reason not to take ocean pollution seriously. But. . . . as a recovering cancer patient I can't afford to fan the flames of technophobia. Although I make constant use of my computer, my affliction was not brain cancer but colon cancer. Nor was it caused by radiation from our electric blanket. It had to be my mother's genes, for that was what she died of.
Put me down as one who is skeptical of the politically correct environmental emergencies. So far as I am concerned, except for my own orange and grapefruit trees, I consider other trees as some farmer's cash crop. Fixation on the preservation of the old growth forests is puzzling. If people are really concerned about the need to remove CO2 from the atmosphere they need to replace the old trees with fast-growing young trees.
American forests now provide the largest harvests in history, and there is more forest land than in 1920. How can this be? Land once devoted to farming wheat and corn can be used more profitably to raise trees.
Finally, what man has polluted, man can clean up. The technology is certainly there. Not too long ago Lake Erie was dying. Today it's alive and well. If the technophobes would stop crying doom, designer microbes would be cleaning up sewage everywhere. The rub is that they'd rather have the issue as a weapon to fight growth. We have plenty of water all around us and there's no reason not to have sufficient fresh water to fill our swimming pools, keep our lawns green and shower for as long as we like.
Charles R.E. Hasek
Sarasota
A time for astronaut economics
John Glenn is going back into space and I'm anxious to hear his report regarding what Mother Earth looks like 30 years later. When he went the first time, the Cold War had things divided between democracy and communism. Today, as futurist-economist Hazel Henderson puts it: "We are united under the new politic - economism."
In Beyond Growth, the Economics of Sustainable Development, Herman Daily talks about fellow economist Kenneth Bouldings' colorful distinction between cowboy economics and astronaut economics. The cowboy of the infinite West lives off of limitless resources with no need to recycle or conserve anything. The astronaut in a small spaceship lives off of tight material cycles, efficient energy use and immediate feedback.
I wonder what sort of feedback we'll get from Sen. Glenn about our spaceship and its atmospheric dump for the products of combustion? Is the blue planet becoming a brown planet?
In a report to the Presidents Council for Sustainable Developments: "Making Sense While Making Money," Amory and Hunter Lovins, co-directors of the Rocky Mountain Institute, write, "Climate change is not the inevitable price of progress, but rather an unnecessary artifact of the uneconomically wasteful use of resources."
They estimate that simply by implementing cost-effective, energy-efficiency measures - that is, measures that pay a better-than-market rate of return - we could eliminate more than half of the threat of global climate change. Another quarter of the problem can be abated by sustainable farming and forestry methods that are about as profitable as current methods, and the rest will disappear thanks to the already mandated replacement of CFCs with new substitutes.
So, if the cost of protecting the atmosphere actually creates jobs, creates wealth, reduces overhead and delivers reinvestable time, isn't this the deal of the century?
Closer to home, the debate rages around the benefits of a "new" fuel called Orimulsion vs. good old liquid petroleum. This reminds me of the scene of the tourist swimming in Big Pass and the cracker fisherman drifting by in his boat, pointing next to the swimmer and asking . . . "Hey, Buddy . . . Uh . . . Is that a shark or a barracuda?"
John Lambie
Sarasota
Physicians, not bottom lines, should run health care
A couple of articles in the Herald-Tribune recently get to the heart of the health care crisis. One was in reference to Columbia-HCA. The upshot was that Dr. Thomas Frist, the CEO, was turning around this albatross created by Richard Scott. He was doing this by downsizing the company and changing its mandate from bigger profits to better patient care. Dr. Frist, a physician and son of the founder of HCA, hopefully has an entirely different ethic than his predecessor, Mr. Scott, an entrepreneur.
A second article was in reference to the appointed replacement for the position on the Sarasota Memorial Hospital Board vacated when Catherine Bowls resigned. (It is regretful that the most patient-oriented and independent member of the board resigned.) The appointee is quoted as saying, "I do not know anything about health care, but I do know the bottom line." A couple of days prior to this, the chairman of the board, in explaining further cuts in staff at Memorial, said, "It's a business."
Don't these two statements just say it all! I trained at the University of Michigan and Harvard. Their two main hospitals were headed at the time by physicians. I remember as a lowly resident physician at Massa chusetts General Hospital, one of the most prestigious medical institutions in the world, that I could speak with Dr. John Knowles, the "CEO" (although then known as the chief administrator) at any time. If I had a concern about patient care, he was there to address it. Contrast this with trying to speak with Michael Covert. One is lucky as a staff physician if he can get an appointment in a week. Then, of course, he would have to travel downtown to the high-rent Hollywood 20 complex where the executive offices are. This in itself is a mystery, as there are thousands of empty square feet of potential office space on the main campus of Memorial Hospital. Perhaps the bottom liners on the hospital board should address that issue.
The care of patients has to be returned to physicians. It has to be taken away from businessmen and entrepreneurs, who know nothing about taking care of sick people, and only know and care about the bottom line. Hospitals, hospital boards, medical insurance decisions and political policy regarding medical care need input from physicians.
To be sure, doctors sometimes exhibit bottom-line tendencies. If people are paying their own bill or have point-of-service insurance, the high fees that doctors charge are an atrocity. The reason is to make up for the equally atrocious low fees of the HMOs and various government programs. This is called cost shifting and is not the solution. The answer is fair fees from the insurers and government agencies.
In spite of remarkable advances in medical technology and drugs, the quality of medical care in this country is on a downward spiral. Until it is realized that the real bottom line in medicine is compassionate, affordable and available care, it will continue to deteriorate. Until the monies are redirected away from the HMO and insurance executives, stockholders and outrageous hospital CEO salaries, toward the care of sick people, we will continue to witness a disgraceful and dangerous deterioration of medical care.
Allen S. Lewis, M.D.
Nokomis
Save something of Earth's resources for tomorrow
My hat is off to the local fishermen who attended a Legislature meeting earlier this month! They conducted themselves very well and made many good points. They all seem to be very hard-working and independent.
I wonder how many of us would be out trying to make a buck at 3 a.m. or trudging across Charlotte Harbor through a squall line to earn a living? All of them deserve our respect . . . and I don't blame them for not wanting a ban on netting in the canals.
I sailed for years out of the home of one of the largest fishing fleets on the East Coast: Point Judith, R.I. That's the place that all of the power squadrons use for their tests because if the sea doesn't get you, then the fog and currents will; it's where men are made out of boys overnight. I've seen men pulling in their nets with decks awash in a foot of white water in seas that one would think were made by the devil himself. I've seen them come back to port covered with ice inches thick . . . just wondering how they made it back.
It takes some special people to do this kind of work.
The recent meeting reminded me of some of the debates back home.
There were many discussions back in 1969 or '70 as to whether or not to open Salt Pond (that's just upstream from where the trawlers were berthed) to recreational and commercial scalloping that season. It appeared to be a bountiful year for these succulent morsels for which the area has been known. The commercial fishermen were arguing for no limits and the recreational ones were arguing for no commercialization. It's not often that one finds a fisherman who is against fishing. This was a fairly small pond and easily scalloped. As it turned out, the recreational scalloper was allowed two bushels (I think) a day and the commercial scalloper, many more. I can remember that fall day when scallop season opened. A person could have walked from shore to shore, there were so many boats out there.
I dredged my two burlap bags full early in the morning and went home to chuck them. They were so good and sweet that every once in a while I rinsed one off and ate it raw.
That was the last season we had it so good. The next year there weren't enough scallops out there even for the recreational fisherman. The bottom cover was gone from all the dredging. . . . The pond never fully recovered.
The Grand Banks have a similar story. The fishermen fought any kind of limits. Now there's so few fish out there many fishermen are talking about a complete ban so the stock can recover.
I can understand why the fishermen want to net in the canals. They admit it's much easier to net there than out in the harbor. Well, I think they've done quite a good job: I no longer hear schools of mullet jumping, just one loner here or there. So maybe if such a ban occurs, it just might extend fishermen's livelihood at least a few more years. That is if the stock can recover.
As I sat there in the meeting last Thursday, I sensed a lot of resentment from the fishermen for those of us who live in the isles. But I think we have more in common than many think. We are here, in the isles, because we love the salt water just as they do. Many of us come from hard-working families, too.
Mason P. Wilson Jr.
Burnt Store Isles
Punta Gorda
Animal rights and people's
The uproar from the animal rights people about destruction of the raccoons which have become such pests on Lido Key reminds me of a book that was written about 50 years ago by Eric Hoffer entitled The True Believer. He pointed out the harm that can come from single-issue zealots who become gung-ho over issues like vegetarianism, nudism, UFOs, vivisection, etc.
All over the world various animals become pests when their natural predators or their natural habitat is destroyed by increases in the number of humans. In Australia, house cats have become feral and have caused the extinction of nine native animal species. A member of the Australian parliament has suggested that these millions of cats be destroyed and that all house cats be neutered.
We also live in a rural area up north where residential development has been encroaching on the habitat needed by the wildlife. A few years ago we put out salt blocks to attract the deer to our property. Suddenly we have too many deer and they either eat or trample everything we grow. Raccoons have become so numerous that they have become a terrible nuisance. Twice they have entered our house during the winter through the fireplace damper and furnace flue. The raccoons smelled the bird seed stored in my garage and almost tore off the door trying to get at it. An obviously sick raccoon entered our garage in broad daylight and was shot by our county animal control people. It is like living under siege!
The animal rights folks almost universally object to vivisection where animals are used for medical experiments. I feel strongly about this, as I lost a sister who died at 8 months; she was born a "blue baby." Twenty years later my first child was born and she, too, was a blue baby. The doctor said she could die at any moment or could survive to age 12 or 13. There was a chance that her heart valve could close by itself, which it did when she was about 4 months old. The doctor told us at that time (1942) that experiments were being conducted on dogs that might enable doctors to correct such a condition.
If animal-rights advocates had had their way, experiments on the hearts of dogs would never have been allowed and blue babies might routinely die today. Also, those thousands who have benefited from by-pass surgery and transplants might be doomed if the anti-vivisectionists had been in charge.
Donald G. Teeling
Siesta Key
Senator explains choice of office
Recent reports have speculated that I may be considered as Jeb Bush's running mate. The fact that - after only three years of public service - statewide speculation exists that I may be well-suited for this post is both remarkable and humbling. As I entered public life three years ago, my goal was to represent my constituents to the best of my ability. I fought hard for the issues the citizens of my district supported. Little was written of the success our district enjoyed, however, the rest of the state took notice.
A recent article poorly construed the analogy relating the choice of lieutenant governor to the winning of an Oscar nomination. I do not consider public service as a prize; it is a duty and a commitment. Further, I have not sought this position as I have told the reporter, but rather I am seeking the office of secretary of state. I believe that my education, background and experience better equip me to serve the citizens of Florida in this position. The policy responsibilities of this office well fit the work that I have done in the Florida Senate.
I look forward to having a great legislative session and a successful campaign for secretary of state. I hope to bring Southwest Florida something that we have not previously enjoyed: representation on the Florida Cabinet.
Lastly and most importantly, I would like to thank the citizens of my district who have been active participants in government and made me a better public official. I may not be a slick career politician like the writer thinks that Jeb needs, but I get results and I think people prefer outsiders who are willing to make a difference, over lifelong politicians.
Katherine Harris
State Senator
District 24

Blowing hot and cold: Making sense of the global warming debate: [Final Edition]

Author: Chambers, Allan

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/blowing-hot-cold-making-sense-global-warming/docview/269893353/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Western Fuels, to its credit, is the most upfront of the bankrollers of the campaign to discount global warming. Its annual reports contain details of its efforts to enlist and fund such well- known "skeptics" on global warming as Patrick Michaels, Robert Balling and Fred Singer. Typically, a recent survey among climate scientists in Germany, the U.S. and Canada found a majority believe climate warming has started and that public policy to limit greenhouse gas emissions is a prudent response. Such special-interest lobbying has been a feature of global- warming politics for years in the U.S., where some segments of the energy industry regularly trot out everyone from the privately funded think tank to that old specimen -- the industry-funded scientist -- to "prove" global warming is a hoax.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Blowing+hot+and+cold%3A+Making+sense+of+the+global+warming+debate&amp;author=Chambers%2C+Allan&amp;issn=11899417&amp;title=The+Spectator&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-01-24&amp;spage=B.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: If you need a plumber, you call a plumber. But if your concern is global warming, do you call a scientist, a paid lobbyist or a propagandist?
And what do you do if the deadly serious science of global warming contains enough uncertainties that there is a slight chance the hack, the propagandist or the legitimate skeptic is right?
You could begin, says Rob Macintosh of the Pembina Institute, by lopping off the extremists whose agendas, ideologies or profit motives colour their approach to an issue that cries out for understanding but is beset by misinformation, deliberate or misguided.
On the one end, you could lop off the environmental end-of-the- worlders, says Macintosh, executive director of the Alberta-based institute, which specializes in research and policy involving energy and the environment.
And, at the other end, you could dispense with the right-wing extremists who argue just as ferociously that the general consensus on global warming among the world's public and private-sector scientists is a leftist plot -- "junk science," as their well funded Web sites proclaim.
It is easier said than done. The environmental movement may be in disarray, but its fringe element still makes itself heard. And its extremist counterpart on the right-wing fringe has never been so flush with money or so loud.
Financing much of that debate are certain energy-sector companies -- the Western Fuels Association, a giant coalition of coal companies in the United States, is a good example -- that stand to make less money if the world decides to control fossil-fuel emissions to reduce greenhouse gases.
Western Fuels, to its credit, is the most upfront of the bankrollers of the campaign to discount global warming. Its annual reports contain details of its efforts to enlist and fund such well- known "skeptics" on global warming as Patrick Michaels, Robert Balling and Fred Singer.
Other companies have not been so forthcoming.
But journalists and other researchers in the U.S. have discovered, through Internal Revenue Service reports, that the Global Climate Coalition has spent millions of dollars to downplay global warming on behalf of its 50-plus industry members that include the American Petroleum Institute.
SKEPTICS
By now, it is possible to attach a long list of company grants to the "research" offered by most of the self-styled global warming skeptics.
Michaels, for example, has received funding from Western Fuels, the German Coal Mining Association, Edison Electric and Cyprus Minerals.
Balling's sources of funding include the British Coal Association and the Kuwait Foundation for the Advancement of Science. Singer, a veteran industry scientist, gets money from a host of companies.
It would be a simple matter if the only challengers of the working hypothesis of global warming were a few hidebound energy companies. They could be dismissed as self-interested parties pursuing the tobacco industry's old strategy of lining up in-house scientists in a war of disinformation that's only intended to delay profit losses.
But it is more complicated than that.
First, there are some independent scientists who are genuine skeptics on global warming issues.
Their work has produced revisions in theory in areas as diverse as the role of cloud vapour in producing greenhouse gases and in the adequacy of computer models in forecasting how much the Earth's mean temperatures will rise as a result of a predicted doubling of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere in the next century.
Such findings are jumped on by industry-sponsored global warming opponents as proof that climate change is a hoax, a claim that ignores the fact that the modifications in the theory, combined with a growing body of climatic evidence, is reducing the number of genuine skeptics.
Typically, a recent survey among climate scientists in Germany, the U.S. and Canada found a majority believe climate warming has started and that public policy to limit greenhouse gas emissions is a prudent response.
The survey supports other surveys by the United Nations' Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, including one that puts the number of global warming skeptics at between 3.5 and five per cent of the world scientific community.
But there is another factor that clouds the scientific debate and perhaps threatens to hijack it -- the well funded U.S. right-wing "think tanks" that see the global warming issue as a leftist environmentalist plot to destroy the world economy.
Their publications, and the work of their scientists, rarely make it into the primary research journals of the mainstream scientists. But they dominate the Internet, which isn't peer reviewed, to the extent that an indiscriminating reader might entertain their claim to be "half" the debate or "the other side" of the issue.
It is a claim to which newspapers are especially vulnerable, given their traditional concern with printing both sides of an issue. Scientists, however, argue that the many streams of thought on global warming have produced a genuine consensus based on real evidence and that it's misleading to accept the claim of a few lobby- scientists and ideologues that they are the "other side" in the debate.
This conjunction of industry funding, ideology-driven think tanks and conservative politics has been a fixture of the U.S. scene. But it is also making inroads in Canada, as evidenced by the Vancouver- based Fraser Institute which is now part of the lecture circuit for the band of skeptics who grace the Web sites of the American think tanks.
The Fraser Institute devoted much of a recent magazine to "a few things you should know about global warming," including an article by Michaels that concludes the "greenhouse scare" is over.
If he can prove that, scientists say, he should run for president of the world. They add that the first scientist who can present evidence showing human activity is not responsible for climate change would be hailed everywhere. Unfortunately the evidence points in the other direction.
A problem for some of the skeptics is that many in the scientific community haven't heard of them, in part because their work is published by organizations like the Independence Institute and Web sites like Junk Science -- and not in the peer-reviewed primary science journals.
"In most scientific journals," says David Schindler, a University of Alberta scientist with a history of publishing ground-breaking research that became mainstream science, "if you put together an argument that's new and novel and that no one accepts, if it's well argued the journal will accept and publish it."
Genuine scientists, not biased in favour of any "truth," will then explore the evidence for the argument. There are, he adds, "scientists so biased that they can't get anything into print."
Schindler says science is vulnerable to distortion by self- interested industries, politicians and ideologues because scientific work involves probabilities and uncertainties, rather than absolute truths.
He notes that scientists reviewing the reports to the UN panel on climate change include Nobel Prize winners and the acknowledged experts.
"The majority of those people reviewing the IPCC data are the best folks we have and they admit they can't predict these things with 100 per cent accuracy."
He says that uncertainty gives those with another agenda the opportunity to wage disinformation campaigns.
In the global warming debate, for example, a few million dollars spent by a heavily polluting industry to prove global warming is "junk science" might cast enough doubt to allow the industry to avoid pollution curbs for another decade.
Such special-interest lobbying has been a feature of global- warming politics for years in the U.S., where some segments of the energy industry regularly trot out everyone from the privately funded think tank to that old specimen -- the industry-funded scientist -- to "prove" global warming is a hoax.
In Canada, it is a more muted fight. One reason, perhaps, is that the public interest is better defined. Special interests, even in an energy-dominated province like Alberta, face a broader front of public skepticism than in the U.S.
But there is another factor. The Canadian energy companies, perhaps more attuned to their broader self-interest, recognize the strong impact global warming could have on other industries and have chosen to temper their positions accordingly.
It is one thing, for example, for an ideology-driven think tank in Washington or Virginia to launch a broadside against environmental lefties.
Schindler notes research evidence suggesting a warming of the Earth's temperature will have a severe impact on farming on the Prairies in the form of warmer and drier weather.
CONTROLS
It could also have a drastic impact on northern forests, a possibility that has persuaded the forest industry -- and its many scientists -- to undertake serious work in emission control and other mitigative measures.
But the insurance industry is perhaps the most worried.
Insurance companies have paid billions of dollars in settlements as a result of recent unusual weather patterns -- a predicted symptom of global warming, many scientists say -- and don't want to be stuck holding the bill.
"We're watching with great interest," says Alan Wood, Alberta spokesperson for the Insurance Bureau of Canada. "We have to look at our dollars and cents. If there is global warming occurring, we'd be fools not to prepare."
While he wishes the skeptics were right, he doesn't believe anyone can afford to stick their head in the sand. "It's a typical interest-group situation" with many of the skeptics, he says. "It's the same as the tobacco industry, the fur lobby. If they're wrong, the potential tragedy is enormous."
Such thinking may serve to temper the U.S-style debate that organizations like the Fraser Institute have tried to import to Canada.
The institute is seeking credibility as a voice of business, but risks alienating its audience with ideological arguments against environmentalists who ignore the everyday reality of companies just outside the institute's walls.
It is one thing to accuse an environmental extremist of perpetrating a hoax. But is the Fraser Institute prepared to launch the same attack on George Weyerhaeuser Jr., president of forestry giant Weyerhaeuser Canada Ltd.?
Weyerhaeuser, who is not regarded as an anti-market lefty, said in a recent speech that "the substantial increase of human-produced greenhouse gas emissions during this century, combined with increased global average temperatures and a higher frequency of climatic disturbances, raises the possibility that humanity is disrupting the natural equilibrium.
"Despite the uncertainty surrounding the issue of global climate change," he said, "there is good reason to adopt a precautionary approach, given the potentially catastrophic ecological and economic impacts."
The precautionary approach accurately describes the position of most of the Canadian energy industry -- coal excepted -- which has embraced the concept of voluntary emission controls. In some cases - - Suncor and TransAlta are good examples -- they have won the respect of environmental activists with technological improvements that will see the rate of increase of Alberta emissions begin to slow in the next 10 years despite a large increase in energy production.
David Manning, president of the Canadian Association of Petroleum Producers, says the industry has taken the position that global warming represents a credible possibility and a risk that must be managed.
But, he adds, the industry is against forced controls on emissions.
He expects some of its members will push for a more careful look at the evidence for and against global warming if controls are threatened.
THE ROAD TO KYOTO
The recent international treaty on curbing greenhouse gas emissions has roots that stretch back nearly 100 years:
- 1898 -- Swedish scientist Svante Ahrrenius warns that carbon dioxide emissions could contribute to global warming.
- 1958 -- Charles Keeling, a scientist at an observatory in Hawaii, reports that concentrations of carbon dioxide are rising.
- 1979 -- A world climate conference considers possible human impacts on climate. It called on governments to "foresee and prevent potential man-made changes in climate that might be adverse to the well-being of humanity."
- 1980s -- Throughout the decade, scientists around the world express growing concern about the impact of human activity on climate change. Papers presented at numerous conferences (Villach 1985, Toronto 1988, The Hague 1989) explored the possible link between human pollution and climate.
- 1988 -- Jim Hansen, director of NASA's Goddard Institute for Space Studies, testifies in the U.S. Senate that the scientific evidence suggests carbon dioxide emissions were warming the planet. His testimony touched off a policy debate.
Political leaders of the day, including British prime minister Margaret Thatcher, call soon afterwards for the creation of an international body of scientists to investigate the issue.
In the United States, research into the issue is supported on a non-partisan basis by Republican presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush.
- 1988 -- The United Nations creates the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, at the request of member countries, to assess the state of knowledge about climate change, its potential impacts and possible strategies of response.
- 1990 -- The IPCC releases its first assessment report. This report, reviewed by scientific experts around the world, found broad scientific evidence of climate change. A world climate conference recommends a framework treaty on climate change, calling the issue "a common concern of mankind."
Negotiations on a world treaty are authorized by the UN General Assembly.
- 1992 -- A framework convention on climate change is signed by most of the world's countries in Rio de Janeiro, calling among other things for voluntary controls on greenhouse gas emissions.
- 1995 -- A second assessment report by the IPCC surveys the state of scientific knowledge worldwide and concludes "the balance of evidence suggests that there is a discernible human influence on global climate."
- 1997 -- A conference at Kyoto, Japan, produces commitments by most countries of the world, including Canada, to reduce their emissions by specific amounts by the year 2010.
Credit: The Edmonton Journal

Title: Blowing hot and cold: Making sense of the global warming debate:   [Final Edition ]

Opportunity after the knocks: [1 Edition]

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/opportunity-after-knocks/docview/332475243/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: These transient events have rubbed off something more permanent. Somewhat to its collective surprise - and thanks in no small measure to the city's retail, leisure, and arts entrepreneurs - Glasgow has a new buzz about it. It's become a city more and more outsiders want to experience. That has helped to encourage more service companies to bring fresh investment and jobs to Glasgow: first, call-centre activity; now, companies capitalising on the trend to outsource professional business services. And, at last, as the old business boundaries become more and more fluid, Glasgow is no longer regarded as a no-go area for manufacturing investment. Large serviced industrial sites, once the preserve of the new towns, are being prepared at Cambuslang, Cardonald, Robroy-ston, and Springhill. The planners are confident they will quickly fill. That happy outcome, more than any statistical sophistry over short-term trends in employment levels in the city, will prove that Glasgow has begun to claw back employment after the heavy losses of the past 20 years. But if more jobs do return, will the people follow? What a regenerated Glasgow needs above all else is a more balanced population mix and a more resilient local tax base. Bluntly, Glasgow needs to appeal to more middle-class families once more as a place to live. Precisely the kind of people who take full advantage of Glasgow's retail and leisure infrastructure - and a healthy slice of the available jobs too - but who currently live outwith its boundaries because the schools there are better and the quality of life is thought superior. They could be reintroduced to city living by redesignating the main dormitory areas around Glasgow as an integral part of the municipal city.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Opportunity+after+the+knocks&amp;author=&amp;issn=&amp;title=The+Herald&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-01-23&amp;spage=22&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: WHITHER Glasgow? This week The Herald has tried to dissect and analyse the many challenges and dilemmas facing Scotland's biggest city. Its current strengths and weaknesses. The fresh opportunities it seeks to embrace. And the familiar threats - witness the ongoing loss of population reflected in the latest official figures, projecting a drop below half a million before long - it strives to counter. What shines through the perceptions of Glaswegians we've asked to reflect on the state of their city today is their enduring affection for a metropolis they see as one of the more friendly and open-hearted places on earth.
But while Glasgow has smiled on better than most through the many adversities it has suffered in recent decades, the city and its citizens will need more than a proven ability to grin and bear it if Glasgow is to have a credible sense of civic purpose and direction that will ensure it prospers well into the new millennium. Glasgow needs a set of clearly attainable objectives and a civic leadership - inside and outside the City Chambers - with the vision, commitment, and drive to deliver them. Glasgow also needs recognition, endorsed well beyond its own boundaries, of the key role it has played and must, in our view, continue to play in the economic, social, and cultural life of Scotland as a whole.
For much of the post-war period Scotland's strategists and planners have effectively colluded in Glasgow's gradual decline and decay. Jobs went with the crumbling of the traditional manufacturing base. People followed, abandoning the Clydeside slums for a back and front door and a garden in the new towns. The replacement jobs, many of them exploiting the newer silicon technologies, were directed to equally greenfield campuses next door. That was what the hi-tech tyros of San Jose demanded. That was what the negotiators in Locate in Scotland were happy to offer. Even when successive governments felt they could ignore Glasgow's plight no longer, the regeneration initiatives they devised - like the Gear scheme and the Castlemilk initiative - were housing, not employment, led. Glasgow was never designated an enterprise zone, although its jobs haemorrhage in the eighties and early nineties swamped those of Clydebank, Greenock, and Motherwell combined. In the era of the Scottish Development Agency and Strathclyde region, Glasgow grew to expect preferential treatment on the grounds that the city faced more than its proportionate share of Scotland's problems.
In the era of the Scottish Enterprise network and unitary local authorities, Glasgow is just one of 20 or 30 supplicants queuing up for a slice of the available cake. So, while equivalent English cities coming to terms with a post-industrial future have enjoyed the pump-priming investment of urban development corporations, Glasgow, the would-be tourist destination of choice, is forced to contemplate closing galleries and museums to save money. And Glasgow, the one- time workshop to the world, where the ability to make things defined who you were, is left to contemplate its economic future as the West of Scotland's main service base, a place where half of Scotland might choose to shop, attend a football match or concert, or buy an insurance policy.
The city still managed to flourish its profile from time to time, with the fondly-remembered garden festival of 1988 and the year-long festival as European City of Culture in 1990. Next year there's to be a reprise of the exclamation-mark approach to civic policy, when Glasgow becomes City of Architecture and Design.
These transient events have rubbed off something more permanent. Somewhat to its collective surprise - and thanks in no small measure to the city's retail, leisure, and arts entrepreneurs - Glasgow has a new buzz about it. It's become a city more and more outsiders want to experience. That has helped to encourage more service companies to bring fresh investment and jobs to Glasgow: first, call-centre activity; now, companies capitalising on the trend to outsource professional business services. And, at last, as the old business boundaries become more and more fluid, Glasgow is no longer regarded as a no-go area for manufacturing investment. Large serviced industrial sites, once the preserve of the new towns, are being prepared at Cambuslang, Cardonald, Robroy-ston, and Springhill. The planners are confident they will quickly fill. That happy outcome, more than any statistical sophistry over short-term trends in employment levels in the city, will prove that Glasgow has begun to claw back employment after the heavy losses of the past 20 years. But if more jobs do return, will the people follow? What a regenerated Glasgow needs above all else is a more balanced population mix and a more resilient local tax base. Bluntly, Glasgow needs to appeal to more middle-class families once more as a place to live. Precisely the kind of people who take full advantage of Glasgow's retail and leisure infrastructure - and a healthy slice of the available jobs too - but who currently live outwith its boundaries because the schools there are better and the quality of life is thought superior. They could be reintroduced to city living by redesignating the main dormitory areas around Glasgow as an integral part of the municipal city.
But we doubt whether the new model Labour Party, which fine tunes every policy to the heartbeat of middle Britain, has the stomach for such a head-on fight. So we are not holding our breath. The government could, instead, allow cities like Glasgow to keep more of the business rates raised within their area, an option implicit in New Labour's hotly-contested desire to return to councils the power to levy their own business tax. And if government is serious about protecting the environment and combating climate change, it may, in time, set the cost of commuting between cities and the countryside at a level which reflects the real costs involved. For now there is little evidence of that objective in John Prescott's apparent determination to build thousands of houses in the English greenbelt. But were they ever to materialise, such policy thrusts would clearly benefit Glasgow.
In the shorter term, if the city is to win back more affluent residents, it will have to play a more subtle game of its own devising. It will have to encourage the building within the city of more houses and neighbourhoods with compelling middle-class appeal. Some good progress is being made through the brownfield sites housing initiative to tempt more owner-occupiers to stay within Glasgow's boundaries. But more ambitious schemes are needed. The late Victorian dynamism which created a Pollokshields or a Jordanhill is probably beyond us today.
But opportunities are emerging to think on a bigger scale. For example, the planned closure of Ruchhill Hospital creates a large residential opportunity just north of Glasgow's cosmopolitan West End. Glasgow has had more than its fair share of knocks. But Glasgow still has a great deal going for it. That positive agenda is the one to which we should all now devote our energies and our creativity.

'Inadequate' sea defences threaten east coast: [London edition]

Author: Adams, Christopher

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/inadequate-sea-defences-threaten-east-coast/docview/248622150/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Much of the east coast is at risk of serious flooding because of inadequate sea defences and the willingness of planning authorities to approve development of low-lying areas according to Willis Corroon , the insurance broker. In a report published yesterday, the company said that sea walls would need substantially greater investment if they were to be effective. Many were constructed or refurbished in the 1950sfollowing a disaster that swamped the east, drowning 300 people, during the night of January 31 1953.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=%27Inadequate%27+sea+defences+threaten+east+coast&amp;author=Adams%2C+Christopher&amp;issn=03071766&amp;title=Financial+Times&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-01-23&amp;spage=08&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Much of the east coast is at risk of serious flooding because of inadequate sea defences and the willingness of planning authorities to approve development of low-lying areas according to Willis Corroon , the insurance broker.
In a report published yesterday, the company said that sea walls would need substantially greater investment if they were to be effective. Many were constructed or refurbished in the 1950sfollowing a disaster that swamped the east, drowning 300 people, during the night of January 31 1953.
The report said, however, that public grants for refurbishment have been decreasing in real terms. This had resulted in reliance on private sector involvement, a trend which may mean spending is ultimately inadequate.
Also, natural flood defences, such as salt marshes, have been reclaimed for agricultural and leisure development.
"Existing sea defences have been designed for certain return periods. But the design parameters may be changing as rises in mean sea levels, increasing storminess and a sinking land mass point to increasing risk of extreme high water levels," said the broker's report.
Most at risk is the east coast of England between the river Humber and Thames estuary. This stretch of coast already has a history of flooding and tidal surges measured at London Bridge have steadily increased.
Global warming may play a role in the bigger surges. The International Panel on Climate Change has estimated that global sea levels are rising by about 6cm every decade because of the thermal expansion of the oceans.
Willis said the increased concentration of housing and other developments on land at risk of flooding would push up the cost of insurance claims.
Britain has not suffered an inundation since 1953, but the cost of wind damage has been rising.
The hurricane which struck southern England in 1987 caused £1.6bn of damage, and the gales which swept across the country earlier this month cost £300m.
The Department of Transport and Environment said development of coastal areas was subject to a government policy designed to minimise the risk of flooding to homes and limit the need for expensive engineering works.
It said the degree of risk involved was carefully considered and that policy was kept under constant review. After the storm, Page 14 Copyright Financial Times Limited 1998. All Rights Reserved.
