Enough evidence of global warming to cause concern: [Final Edition]

Author: Weld, Madeline

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/enough-evidence-global-warming-cause-concern/docview/240151717/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Yet Mr. [John Robson] engages in boldfaced denial ("the evidence that the world is getting warmer is feeble, while the evidence that humans are causing it to get warmer is non-existent") and seeks to discredit scientific attempts to study global warming in general, mainly by attacking "models." As an example of how unreliable science really is, Mr. Robson mocks previous scientific concerns about "global cooling." The change in focus of scientific concerns from global cooling to global warming is actually an example of the scientific method in action. In 1971, when a renowned atmospheric scientist called Stephen Schneider expressed concerns about cooling, the contribution of greenhouse gases other than carbon dioxide was not recognized. The climatological community was more concerned about possible cooling of the planet by particulate pollution than about carbon dioxide- induced warming. The cooling effect of particulate matter was recently demonstrated by the eruption of Mount Pinatubo, which caused a transient cooling in 1992-94, even though the 1990s were overall the hottest decade.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Enough+evidence+of+global+warming+to+cause+concern&amp;author=Weld%2C+Madeline&amp;issn=08393222&amp;title=The+Ottawa+Citizen&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-01-23&amp;spage=A.17&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The Citizen's deputy editorial page editor has seen fit to loudly proclaim his wilful ignorance on global warming, not once, but on two occasions ("The Kyoto treaty is worse than useless," Dec. 12 and "My, but we've had a lot of weather lately," Jan. 16).
Evidently, John Robson doesn't read the Citizen very carefully, or else disregards what it prints, because most of the data cited below comes from its pages:
l Last year was the warmest year on record since record-keeping began 130 years ago.
l On a global basis, the 10 warmest years in the last 130 years have all occurred since 1980 and the five warmest since 1990.
l The earth's temperature has risen half a degree Celsius over the last 140 years. Canada's temperature is one degree warmer since 1985.
l The rate of melting of ice caps on mountains in the tropics and subtropics has greatly accelerated in recent decades.
l The freezing level in the Earth's atmosphere (the height where air temperature reaches 0 degrees Celsius) has been gaining altitude since 1970 at a rate approaching five metres each year.
l A six-year study in the Mackenzie Basin has confirmed that the northern permafrost of the region has retreated about 100 kilometres during the last century, and there has been an increase in the depth of the so-called active layer that thaws and melts intermittently. Meteorological records in the region, some of which go back to the 1890s, show average temperatures have risen about one degree C in the last century.
l As a result of the industrial revolution, the atmosphere contains 40 per cent more carbon than its natural level.
l Insurance industry payouts for weather-related damage reached $48 billion U.S. in the 1990s (as of mid-1996), compared to $16 billion for the 1980s.
l In 1996, total property damage in Canada due to weather came to about $ 1.5 billion.
l Before 1987, insured losses from any single natural disaster never exceeded $1 billion; since then 18 natural disasters of at least $1 billion have occurred around the world.
l The intergovernmental Report on Climate Change has noted that the annual insured cost of windstorms worldwide has exploded from $500 million during the 1960s to $11 billion in the early 1990s.
l Canadian health experts note the rate of deaths from malignant melanoma, the deadliest form of skin cancer, rose 42 per cent for men and 25 per cent for women between 1980 and 1990. More and more young people in their 20s and 30s are seen with skin cancers usually found in older people.
Yet Mr. Robson engages in boldfaced denial ("the evidence that the world is getting warmer is feeble, while the evidence that humans are causing it to get warmer is non-existent") and seeks to discredit scientific attempts to study global warming in general, mainly by attacking "models."
As an example of how unreliable science really is, Mr. Robson mocks previous scientific concerns about "global cooling." The change in focus of scientific concerns from global cooling to global warming is actually an example of the scientific method in action.
In 1971, when a renowned atmospheric scientist called Stephen Schneider expressed concerns about cooling, the contribution of greenhouse gases other than carbon dioxide was not recognized. The climatological community was more concerned about possible cooling of the planet by particulate pollution than about carbon dioxide- induced warming. The cooling effect of particulate matter was recently demonstrated by the eruption of Mount Pinatubo, which caused a transient cooling in 1992-94, even though the 1990s were overall the hottest decade.
We now know that carbon dioxide is not the only greenhouse gas. Methane, nitrous oxide and chlorofluorocarbons (CFSs) are also involved in trapping some of the sun's energy near the Earth's surface. When this fact was recognized, the concerns of the climatological community shifted to global warming.
The fact that scientists refocused their concerns does not reflect a failure on the part of science, it illustrates how science works: When new information is acquired, old ideas sometimes change. (For more information on global warming see Paul and Anne Ehrlich, The Betrayal of Science and Reason, 1996, Island Press).
Despite the fact that climate patterns are complex in themselves, and sorting out the effects of human activity is not as simple as Mr. Robson would like it to be, the vast majority of serious scientists believe that the evidence on global warming (some of it cited above) is sufficient to warrant concern.
Most scientists and most thinking laypeople believe that it is wise to take action, and irresponsible to do nothing to reverse deleterious trends. As the Ehrlichs say in their book, you don't have to know the number of grains of sand on a beach to be able to observe that erosion is occurring.
Unfortunately Mr. Robson's misinformation is likely to influence a significant number of people, who, like himself, lack a grasp of the scientific method.
For such people, the evidence for global warming will never be conclusive enough, just as the evidence for declining fish stocks was never conclusive enough for our government.
By the time we have "enough" information, we may be experiencing some of the catastrophic predictions, such as the flooding of low- lying areas due to rising sea levels or serious losses of previously fertile land.
By that time of course, Mr. Robson may be dead or have lived out most of his life.
I wonder if he ever troubles himself with thoughts of what sort of a world his grandchildren might inhabit.
Madeline Weld,
President,
Global Population Concerns,
Ottawa

Future Car: [ALL 01/21/98 Edition]

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/future-car/docview/405624531/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Long before last December's global warming conference in Kyoto, we started urging people to stay cool about what's required to buy some cautionary insurance for Mother Earth. One tells you millions will lose jobs and prices will skyrocket because of the cost of converting factories, vehicles, and buildings to curb greenhouse gas emissions. The other side warns you of drowning in Indonesia, fried crops in Iowa, huge storms, forest decline, and pestilence. We've pointed out that the electric power industry has already learned a lot about cutting CO2 emissions. (Some 45 million tons of gases cut in North America.) The more agile firms can now reverse the standard wastage statistic: one-third of fuel produces electricity; two-thirds is wasted. They can now reach 70 percent efficiency.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Future+Car&amp;author=&amp;issn=08827729&amp;title=The+Christian+Science+Monitor&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-01-21&amp;spage=20&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Long before last December's global warming conference in Kyoto, we started urging people to stay cool about what's required to buy some cautionary insurance for Mother Earth.
Don't be panicked by either side.
One tells you millions will lose jobs and prices will skyrocket because of the cost of converting factories, vehicles, and buildings to curb greenhouse gas emissions. The other side warns you of drowning in Indonesia, fried crops in Iowa, huge storms, forest decline, and pestilence.
Both are based on static projections: (1) That the cost of CO2 emission-cutting will remain high. (2) That the private sector will stand still and governments will bicker for years.
We've pointed out that the electric power industry has already learned a lot about cutting CO2 emissions. (Some 45 million tons of gases cut in North America.) The more agile firms can now reverse the standard wastage statistic: one-third of fuel produces electricity; two-thirds is wasted. They can now reach 70 percent efficiency.
But what about the headline subject of this editorial: cars? Their numbers are expected to grow by tens of millions as Chinese, Indians, and Brazilians begin to lead versions of Western lifestyles. So more efficiency on the road is a must - in terms of resources as well as climate change.
We've noted with interest recent announcements by Honda, Toyota, and Saab of new super-efficient engines. One of Honda's (scheduled for late 1998) gets 70 miles per gallon. Another, under development, uses three catalyzers to reduce emissions to about 1/10th what the world's most stringent restrictions (California's) allow.
That's important, because California has hit a setback in selling consumers zero-emission electric cars. Prices are still too high and trips between chargings to short to woo many buyers. GM's two-seat, battery-powered EV-1 found only 300 buyers in a year, well short of the goal of 1,200. State officials are considering whether to add "hybrids," with a small gas engine twinned with an electric motor.
For such cars to become standard, they will have to be reliable enough and cheap enough to attract mass buyers. That means Western consumers buying enough to bring about economies of scale. Then versions for mass markets in developing lands.
None of this is simple. But it's encouraging that major car firms are pouring big money into research on even more thrifty (and alternative-powered) future cars.

The global warming storm; Making Sense of the Science and Politics of Climate Change; THE LONG ROAD TO KYOTO: [Final Edition]

Author: Stories by Allan Chambers, Journal Staff Writer

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/global-warming-storm-making-sense-science/docview/252485983/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Western Fuels, to its credit, is the most up-front of the bankrollers of the campaign to discount global warming. Its annual reports have detailed its efforts to enlist and fund such formerly obscure but currently well-known "skeptics" on global warming as Patrick Michaels, Robert Balling and Fred Singer. Typically, a recent survey among climate scientists in Germany, the United States and Canada found that a majority believe climate warming is already under way, and that public policy to limit greenhouse gas emissions is a prudent response. The survey supports other surveys by the United Nations' Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), including one that places the number of global warming skeptics at between 3.5 and 5 per cent of the world scientific community. In fact, there has been so little recorded warming, he says, that it is now incumbent on global warming scientists to explain why the climate hasn't warmed up as much as they thought it would.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=The+global+warming+storm%3B+Making+Sense+of+the+Science+and+Politics+of+Climate+Change%3B+THE+LONG+ROAD+TO+KYOTO&amp;author=Stories+by+Allan+Chambers%2C+Journal+Staff+Writer&amp;issn=0839296X&amp;title=Edmonton+Journal&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-01-18&amp;spage=F.1.FRO&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Feature on global warming See related stories F4, "Attacking the messengers", F5, "Assessing the skeptics"
If you need a plumber, you call a plumber. But if your concern is global warming, do you call a scientist, a paid lobbyist or a propagandist?
And what do you do if the deadly-serious science of global warming contains enough uncertainties -- as every reputable scientist knows -- that there is a slight chance the hack, the propagandist or the legitimate skeptic might be right?
You could begin, says Rob Macintosh of the Pembina Institute, by lopping off the extremists whose agendas and ideologies -- or profit motives -- colour their whole approach to an issue that cries out for understanding but is beset by misinformation, deliberate or misguided.
On the one end you could lop off the environmental end-of-the- worlders "who say the insects will march forward and trash the place," says Macintosh, executive director of the institute, which specializes in research and policy involving energy and the environment.
On the other end, he says, you could dispense with the right- wing extremists who argue just as ferociously that the general consensus on global warming among the world's public and private- sector scientists is actually a leftist plot -- "junk science," as their well-funded websites proclaim.
It is easier said than done. The environmental movement may be in disarray, but its fringe element still makes itself heard. And its extremist counterpart on the right-wing fringe has never been so flush with money or so loud.
Financing much of that debate are certain companies in the energy sector -- the Western Fuels Association, a giant coalition of coal companies in the United States is a good example -- who stand to make less money if the world decides to control fossil-fuel emissions in an effort to reduce greenhouse gases.
Western Fuels, to its credit, is the most up-front of the bankrollers of the campaign to discount global warming. Its annual reports have detailed its efforts to enlist and fund such formerly obscure but currently well-known "skeptics" on global warming as Patrick Michaels, Robert Balling and Fred Singer.
Other companies have not been so forthcoming. Still, journalists and other researchers in the United States have discovered, through Internal Revenue Service reports, that the Global Climate Coalition has spent millions of dollars to downplay global warming on behalf of its 50-plus industry members (including the American Petroleum Institute).
By now, it is possible to attach a long list of company grants to the "research" offered up by most of the self-styled global warming skeptics. (Michaels has received funding from Western Fuels, the German Coal Mining Association, Edison Electric, Cyprus Minerals. Balling's sources of funding range more exotically to include the British Coal Association and even the Kuwait Foundation for the Advancement of Science. Singer, a veteran industry scientist, gets money from a whole host of companies, from ARCOL to Unocol).
It would be a simple matter if the only challengers of the working hypothesis of global warming were a few hidebound energy companies. They could be dismissed as self-interested parties pursuing the tobacco industry's old strategy of lining up in-house scientists in a war of disinformation intended solely to delay profit losses.
But it is more complicated than that. First, there are some independent scientists who are genuine skeptics on global warming issues. Their work has produced revisions in theory in areas as diverse as the role of cloud vapour in producing greenhouse gases, and in the adequacy of computer models in forecasting how much the earth's mean temperatures will rise as a result of a predicted doubling of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere in the next century.
Such findings are jumped on by the industry-sponsored global warming opponents as final proof that climate change is a hoax -- a claim that ignores the fact that the modifications in the theory, combined with a growing body of climate evidence, serves to reduce the number of genuine skeptics.
Typically, a recent survey among climate scientists in Germany, the United States and Canada found that a majority believe climate warming is already under way, and that public policy to limit greenhouse gas emissions is a prudent response. The survey supports other surveys by the United Nations' Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), including one that places the number of global warming skeptics at between 3.5 and 5 per cent of the world scientific community.
But there is another factor that further clouds the scientific debate, and perhaps even threatens to hijack it. That is the entry by well-funded, primarily U.S. right-wing "think tanks" who see the global warming issue as an opportunity to push their campaign against government regulation and what many of them perceive as a leftist environmentalist plot to destroy the world economy.
Their publications, and the work of their scientists, rarely make it into the primary research journals of the mainstream scientists. But they do dominate the Internet, which isn't peer-reviewed, to the extent that an undiscriminating reader might entertain their claim to be "half" the debate or "the other side" of the issue.
It is a claim to which newspapers are especially vulnerable, given their traditional concern with printing "both sides" of an issue. Mainstream scientists, however, argue that the many streams of thought on global warming have produced a genuine consensus based on real evidence, and that it is misleading -- at best -- to accept the claim of a few lobby-scientists and ideologues that they are the "other side" in the debate.
The ideologues who attack global warming as a leftist, "Big Government" and "Big Environment" plot may have little scientific standing -- none, in fact. But 20 minutes on the Internet will produce a slew of them, all feverishly quoting one another: the Hoover Institute, the Competitive Enterprise Institute, the Committee for a Constructive Tomorrow, the Independence Institute, the Cato Institute, the "Junk Science" website, the Global Climate Coalition, The Science and Environment Policy Project, Sovereignty International, the Eagle Forum, the George C. Marshall Institute.
This is just a small list, but you get the picture. What they have in common is their funding, which comes from private sources; their politics, which is right-wing; and their science, which is suspect to most scientists.
Still, it has produced a harangue of the extremes, reflected recently in the little side-stage skirmishes between environmental fringe groups and right-wing fringe groups at the Kyoto conference on climate change, which were then duly reported from their hotel- room modems back to their websites.
In this harangue, it is almost possible to forget that the science behind global warming is the working reality for most of the world's scientists, and tacitly or openly accepted by most industry (which has to make a go of it on the planet, like the rest of us).
It is just a "so-called consensus," claims Jerry Taylor, the affable but hardly moderate director of natural resources studies at the Cato Institute, one of the more respected right-wing think tanks.
The United Nations-sponsored IPCC report, when you go through it, can account for only a half degree Fahrenheit of warming since the Second World War and hardly supports the conclusion in the report that "the balance of evidence" suggests a human role, he says.
In fact, there has been so little recorded warming, he says, that it is now incumbent on global warming scientists to explain why the climate hasn't warmed up as much as they thought it would.
The Cato Institute's main global warming researcher is Patrick Michaels, the frequent recipient of research money from the coal industry. In the past, Michaels has also edited a journal, funded by Western Fuels, that Michaels once described (in less than scientific language) as "an antidote to the vision of apocalypse promoted by the professional environmental community and the United Nations."
The question of funding is irrelevant, Taylor contends, because the data winds up in public journals where it can be tested. If the data is there, it doesn't matter if "Satan himself" is paying for the research.
In fact, the research of the "skeptics" rarely shows up in the peer-reviewed literature at all. When it is considered for publication, it is usually rejected on scientific grounds, according to numerous scientists who have testified to this effect before public bodies. More typically, the work of the "skeptics" is funded by special interests in industry, printed by a right-wing think tank and then hailed on op-ed pages by right-wing commentators.
A typical example is Fred Singer, one of the most well-known skeptics, whose name is rarely seen in the research journals (except in letters to the editor), but who has received substantial industry funding, runs a webpage and research institute that campaign fiercely against global warming on scientific-ideological grounds, and will soon have a new book out on the subject -- published by the right-wing Independence Institute in Oakland, Calif.
This ready conjunction of industry funding, ideology-driven think tanks and conservative politics has been a fixture of the U.S. scene for years. But it is also making inroads in Canada, as evidenced by the Vancouver-based Fraser Institute which is now part of the lecture circuit for the band of skeptics who grace the websites of the American tanks.
The Fraser Institute, for example, devoted much of a recent magazine to "a few things you should know about global warming," including an article by Michaels that concludes the "greenhouse scare" is over.
If he can prove that, mainstream scientists say, he should run for president of the world. The first scientist able to present actual evidence showing that human activity is not responsible for climate change would be hailed everywhere, they say. Unfortunately the evidence points in the other direction.
A problem for some of the skeptics is that many in the mainstream scientific community haven't heard of them, in part because their work is published mainly by organizations like the Independence Institute and websites like Junk Science -- but not in the peer- reviewed primary science journals.
"In most (scientific) journals," says David Schindler, a University of Alberta scientist with a long history of publishing ground-breaking research that became mainstream science, "if you put together an argument that's new and novel (and) that no one accepts, if it's well-argued the journal will still accept and publish it." Genuine scientists, not biased in favour of any "truth," will then explore the evidence for the argument.
There are, he adds, "scientists out there so biased that they can't get anything into print."
Schindler says the whole discipline of science is vulnerable to distortion by self-interested industries, politicians and ideologues because the very nature of scientific work involves probabilities and uncertainties, rather than absolute truths.
The scientists reviewing the reports to the UN panel on climate change include Nobel prize winners and the acknowledged experts in their fields, he notes.
"My philosophy is there's some people you would go to if you want things done right, and there's some people you would avoid.
"I would say the majority of those people reviewing the IPCC data are the best folks that we have, and they freely admit that they can't predict these things with 100 per cent accuracy. No scientist ever claims that."
It is that uncertainty -- in terms of absolute knowledge -- at the heart of all science that gives those with another agenda the opportunity to wage disinformation campaigns, he says.
In the global warming debate, for example, a few million dollars spent by a heavily polluting industry to prove that global warming is "junk science" might cast enough doubt to allow the industry to avoid pollution curbs for another decade, he says.
Such special-interest lobbying has been a feature of global- warming politics for years in the United States, where some segments of the energy industry regularly trot out everyone from the privately funded think tank to that old specimen -- the industry- funded scientist -- to "prove" that global warming is a hoax.
In Canada it is a more muted fight, at least until now. One reason, perhaps, is that the public interest is better defined. Special interests, even in an energy-dominated province like Alberta, face a broader front of public skepticism than in the United States.
But there is another factor too. The Canadian energy companies, perhaps more attuned to their broader self-interest, recognize the strong impact that global warming could have on other industries working right next door to them, and have chosen to temper their own positions accordingly.
It is one thing, for example, for an ideology-driven think tank in faraway Washington or Virginia to launch a broadside against environmental lefties. But evidence stemming from mainstream research suggests a warming of the earth's temperature will have a severe impact on farming on the Prairies in the form of warmer and drier weather -- not unlike the impact of the warm weather seen earlier this winter, Schindler notes.
It could also have a drastic impact on northern forests, a potentiality that has persuaded the forest industry -- and its many scientists -- to undertake serious work in emission control and other mitigative measures.
But the industry that is perhaps most worried these days is the insurance industry, which has paid out billions of dollars in settlements as a result of recent unusual weather patterns -- a predicted symptom of global warming, according to many scientists -- and don't want to be stuck holding the bill.
"We're watching with great interest," says Alan Wood, Alberta spokesperson for the Insurance Bureau of Canada. "We have to look at our dollars and cents. If there is global warming occurring, we'd be fools not to prepare."
While Wood wishes the skeptics were right, he doesn't believe anyone can afford to stick their head in the sand. "It's a typical interest-group situation" with many of the skeptics, he says.
"It's the same as the tobacco industry, the fur lobby ... If they're wrong, the potential tragedy is enormous."
Such thinking may serve in the end to temper the U.S-style debate that organizations like the Fraser Institute have tried to import into Canada. The institute is seeking credibility as a voice of business, but risks alienating its own audience with ideological arguments against environmentalists that ignore the everyday reality of companies just outside the institute's walls.
It is, after all, one thing to accuse an environmental extremist of perpetrating a hoax. But is the Fraser Institute prepared to launch the same attack on George Weyerhaeuser Jr., president of forestry giant Weyerhaeuser Canada Ltd.?
Weyerhaeuser, who is not regarded as an anti-market lefty, stated in a recent speech that "the substantial increase of human-produced greenhouse gas emissions during this century, combined with increased global average temperatures and a higher frequency of climatic disturbances, raises the possibility that humanity is disrupting the natural equilibrium.
"Despite the uncertainty surrounding the issue of global climate change," he said, "there is good reason to adopt a `precautionary' approach, given the potentially catastrophic ecological and economic impacts."
The precautionary approach accurately describes the position of most of the Canadian energy industry -- coal excepted -- which has embraced the concept of voluntary emission controls. In some cases - - Suncor and TransAlta are good examples -- they have won the respect of environmental activists with technological improvements that will actually see the rate of increase of Alberta emissions begin to slow in the next 10 years, despite a large increase in energy production.
The industry has taken the position that global warming represents a credible possibility and a risk that must be managed, says David Manning, president of the Canadian Association of Petroleum Producers.
But, he adds, the industry is against forced controls on emissions, and he anticipates that some of its members will be pushing for a more careful look at the evidence for and against global warming if controls are threatened.
All of these considerations are unlikely to still the emissions from the fringe groups, especially those on the right whose websites daily proclaim new "conclusive proof" that global warming is a hoax.
In fact, the fury on the fringes is just beginning to heat up as governments around the world begin to debate measures to control fossil-fuel emissions.
The arguments tend to come so fast and furiously that a new one is placed on the plate even before the last one is dispelled.
* New satellite data proves the Earth isn't warming (No, it proves -- depending on questionable mathematical calculations -- that there has been a slight cooling a mile above the Earth and beyond).
* The Earth has gone through other periods of warming and cooling, Medieval warm spells and Little Ice Ages (Yes, but not in conjunction with carbon dioxide levels whose concentrations are higher now than at any time in the last 160,000 years, according to ice-core data, and which are projected to double again in the next 100 years).
* It was so cold in December 1995 that the evidence for warming can be discredited (In fact, 1995 was the warmest year since systematic instrumental records began to be kept in the 19th century).
And so on. A true skeptic would be advised to consider the source of the information.
"I'm not surprised to see this kind of stuff," says Schindler, whose research on lakes years ago was greeted by industry-sponsored research "proving" that algae produces phosphorus, rather than the other way around.
"It's just that when you look very closely versus the other scientific evidence, I know where I would put my money on who's likely to be right."
If you go to a scientific conference on global warming, he says, "you don't hear these arguments (from the skeptics). These folks don't turn up, or if they do turn up they're too embarrassed to open their mouths."
"I would bet that a lot of these people, deep down, think they're not going to win this argument."
Don't tell that to Jerry Taylor of the Cato Institute. "Within the course of another 10 or 15 years, we'll move on to another hysteria and global warming will be forgotten," he says.
THE LONG ROAD TO KYOTO
The recent international treaty on curbing greenhouse gas emissions has roots that stretch back nearly 100 years:
* 1898 -- Swedish scientist Svante Ahrrenius warns that carbon dioxide emissions could contribute to global warming.
* 1958 -- Charles Keeling, a scientist at an observatory in Hawaii, reports concentrations of carbon dioxide were rising.
* 1979 -- A world climate conference considers possible human impacts on climate. It called on governments to "foresee and prevent potential man-made changes in climate that might be adverse to the well-being of humanity."
* 1980s -- Throughout the decade, scientists worldwide express a growing concern about the impact of human activity on climate change. Papers presented at numerous conferences (Villach 1985, Toronto 1988, The Hague 1989) explored the possible link between human pollution and the climate.
* 1988 -- Jim Hansen, the director of NASA's Goddard Institute for Space Studies, testifies in the U.S. Senate that the scientific evidence suggested carbon dioxide emissions were warming the planet. His testimony touched off a policy debate.
Political leaders of the day, including British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, call for the creation of an international body of scientists to investigate the issue. In the U. S., research into the issue is supported on a non-partisan basis by Republican presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush.
* 1988 -- The United Nations creates the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), at the request of member countries, to assess the state of knowledge about climate change, the potential impacts and possible strategies of response.
* 1990 -- The IPCC releases its first assessment report. This report, reviewed by scientific experts around the world, found broad scientific evidence of climate change. A world climate conference recommends a framework treaty on climate change, calling the issue "a common concern of mankind." Negotiations on a world treaty are authorized by the UN General Assembly.
* 1992 -- A framework convention on climate change is signed by most of the world's countries in Rio de Janeiro, calling for voluntary controls on greenhouse gas emissions.
* 1995 -- A second assessment report by the IPCC surveys the state of scientific knowledge worldwide and concludes "the balance of evidence suggests that there is a discernible human influence on global climate."
* 1997 -- A conference at Kyoto, Japan, produces commitments by most countries of the world, including Canada, to reduce their emissions by specific amounts by the year 2010.
Illustration AP/ Illustrating lightning over Santa Barbara, California (CP) ; Nasa Photo/ Illustrating the earth as seen from outer space (CP) ; Southam News, The Windsor Star/ As governments worldwide begin looking at how to meet emissions targets set at Kyoto, the fury on the fringes of the debate is heating up (P) ;

Natural disasters part of trend

Author: Speirs, Rosemary

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/natural-disasters-part-trend/docview/348454492/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: This week, after a series of quick visits to eastern Ontario communities, Premier [Mike Harris] flew off to Mexico to join the Team Canada trade mission, presumably convinced the worst was over. Quebec's [Lucien Bouchard], with Montreal's south shore still in darkness, stayed home to display the solidarity he's been urging on Quebecers. [Jean Chretien], after flying into some of the worst-hit areas of Quebec and Ontario by helicopter, was pondering whether the situation was now stable enough for him to fly south. Even as Chretien was out reassuring victims that federal pockets are open, Opposition Leader Preston Manning made a speech in Brampton urging business leaders to keep pressure on the Liberals to make debt reduction their priority. Manning presumably didn't mean to imply that the storm victims should be left to their own devices, but he's a doubter on global warming and opposed to big spending to pay for the switch to a less polluting economy. North America has always experienced peaks of destructive weather, but the latest trend looks more like a plateau - suggesting a fundamental shift toward a more extreme climate. Researchers say we're experiencing more intense El Ninos, the recurring warm air masses from the tropical oceans. According to Environment Canada, the latest El Nino produced the warm flow of air which, after hitting colder air masses over eastern Canada, caused the Montreal ice-storm.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Natural+disasters+part+of+trend&amp;author=Speirs%2C+Rosemary&amp;issn=08324174&amp;title=Star+-+Phoenix&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-01-17&amp;spage=C.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: OTTAWA With freezing temperatures now gripping eastern Ontario and Quebec communities already deprived of heat and light, the bill for Canada's worst ice storm ever is steadily mounting. Authorities calculate the cost of restoring normalcy at almost $2 billion in Quebec alone.
But the real question facing Prime Minister Jean Chretien, Mike Harris and Lucien Bouchard isn't just about paying disaster relief. It's whether the job ahead is bigger than simply restringing those snapped hydro lines.
We may just have had the warning that our climate is turning more destructive and hydro lines strung on poles and metal pylons are simply going to be too vulnerable in future. Shouldn't we be planning now to put those lines underground? Shouldn't we be providing backup systems for when the electricity is shut off again?
Scientists simply don't have enough data to tell us whether we are experiencing the first stages of climate change. But there's an eerie parallel to the extreme weather that their models forecast for us, as so-called greenhouse pollution gradually warms the Earth's atmosphere.
The worst ice storm in Canadian history may be the best warning we'll get that the need to make decisive cuts in carbon dioxide emissions is pressing. And so is protective action like underground hydro lines and flood dikes to help us weather the early turbulence of climate change. The costs of not doing so will be even more enormous.
This week, after a series of quick visits to eastern Ontario communities, Premier Harris flew off to Mexico to join the Team Canada trade mission, presumably convinced the worst was over. Quebec's Bouchard, with Montreal's south shore still in darkness, stayed home to display the solidarity he's been urging on Quebecers. Chretien, after flying into some of the worst-hit areas of Quebec and Ontario by helicopter, was pondering whether the situation was now stable enough for him to fly south.
On Monday, the PM assured Quebecers and rural Ontarians that "you are not alone." The armed forces and federal disaster relief would be there for them until normalcy was restored.
Even as Chretien was out reassuring victims that federal pockets are open, Opposition Leader Preston Manning made a speech in Brampton urging business leaders to keep pressure on the Liberals to make debt reduction their priority. Manning presumably didn't mean to imply that the storm victims should be left to their own devices, but he's a doubter on global warming and opposed to big spending to pay for the switch to a less polluting economy.
Manning's nay-saying adds to the political challenge facing Environment Minister Christine Stewart and Energy Minister Ralph Goodale, the two federal ministers charged with reducing Canada's emissions of greenhouse gases. In advance of next month's budget, they are pressing Finance Minister Paul Martin to introduce more incentives to encourage industry and individuals to switch to less polluting technologies.
Stewart's case before cabinet - and in persuading the doubters such as Manning would be much stronger if Environment Canada's scientists could say for sure that the spate of storms, floods and forest fires that have hit the country in the last couple of years are the harbingers of global warming. In the absence of such proof, neither Chretien nor any other prominent politician wants to risk ridicule, or be accused of alarmism.
Yet, the government's advisers have pulled together some very unnerving data which, if not conclusive proof of the scientific kind, certainly point to a trend.
Figures compiled by the insurance industry show a dramatic increase in global losses from weather-related disasters - from $3.4 billion for the entire 1980s to $20.2 billion for the first three years of the 1990s alone.
North America has always experienced peaks of destructive weather, but the latest trend looks more like a plateau - suggesting a fundamental shift toward a more extreme climate. Researchers say we're experiencing more intense El Ninos, the recurring warm air masses from the tropical oceans. According to Environment Canada, the latest El Nino produced the warm flow of air which, after hitting colder air masses over eastern Canada, caused the Montreal ice-storm.
Actual scientific proof of the connection between global warming and the weather extremes we're experiencing may not be available for a couple of decades. Then, our children stand to inherit conditions of which this week's storm is only a foretaste.
Two days ago, the Canada-U.S. International Joint Commission released its interim report on last spring's Red River flood, warning that "this is no time for complacency . . . the flood of 1997 or an even larger one could happen any year." The commission recommends 40 "prudent steps" to prepare for possible future floods in the Red River basin.
This isn't alarmism. It's considered advice that treating each disaster as a freak, to be mopped up afterward, is no longer enough.
(c) 1998 Toronto Star Syndicate

People: Chretien, Jean; Manning, Preston

MAINE STORM LOSSES COULD REACH $75M: [THIRD EDITION]

Author: Ackerman, Jerry

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/maine-storm-losses-could-reach-75m/docview/403932621/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: As many as 50,000 Maine businesses and homeowners are expected to file claims for ice damage from last week's storm, insurers said yesterday, and more snow and ice today could drive that number up. One insurer, Maine Mutual Fire Insurance Co. of Presque Isle, Maine, said it expects claims by its policyholders will exceed its own reserve fund, requiring it to make its own claim for catastrophic coverage it buys from reinsurance carriers. Across the Northeast, from upstate New York to easternmost Maine, the insurance industry earlier had predicted about $100 million in losses to homes, cars, stores, and other property, including perishable foods.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=MAINE+STORM+LOSSES+COULD+REACH+%2475M&amp;author=Ackerman%2C+Jerry&amp;issn=07431791&amp;title=Boston+Globe&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-01-16&amp;spage=E.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   As many as 50,000 Maine businesses and homeowners are expected to file claims for ice damage from last week's storm, insurers said yesterday, and more snow and ice today could drive that number up.
While each claim appears to be relatively small, averaging about $1,500, together they could represent a loss of as much as $75 million shared among several dozen insurers.
One insurer, Maine Mutual Fire Insurance Co. of Presque Isle, Maine, said it expects claims by its policyholders will exceed its own reserve fund, requiring it to make its own claim for catastrophic coverage it buys from reinsurance carriers.
Insurers said claims in New Hampshire and Vermont, where damage was more isolated, were much lower than in Maine.
Across the Northeast, from upstate New York to easternmost Maine, the insurance industry earlier had predicted about $100 million in losses to homes, cars, stores, and other property, including perishable foods.
That didn't include the cost of restoring electric service, which most utilities will have to shoulder themselves; repairs to roads and other public facilities; or for flood damage, which is paid through a federal insurance program.
In Canada, where about 800,000 people still were without electricity last night, losses could exceed $1.4 billion, the Associated Press reported, including damage to farms and repairs to the Hydro Quebec electric system.
Forecasts yesterday of another storm had Maine insurers wary that losses could rise more. "The thermometer is wavering and there is a lot more that could happen if there are more freeze-ups," said George Gould, vice president for claims at Commercial Union York Insurance Co. in Portland.
That company, a subsidiary of Commercial Union Insurance Co. of Boston, is the largest casualty underwriter in Maine, with about one-eighth of all homeowner policies and a quarter of business casualty insurance.
State Farm Insurance Cos., the second-largest underwriter of home insurance in Maine, said it expects about 8,000 claims for homes and 1,000 claims for auto damage in the four states hit by the storm, with a potential payout of $11.7 million. About 5,500 claims are expected by State Farm in Maine.
Larry Shaw, president and chief executive of Maine Mutual, with 7 percent of all homeowner policies in the state, said 750 claims were filed as of yesterday. He said that number may double after property owners get out to survey their damage.
"A lot of people are still without power, or just trying to survive," Richard Sawyer, president of Acadia Insurance Co. of Westbrook, Maine, said. "The last thing they are going to think about is filing an insurance claim."
Acadia, a subsidiary of the W.R. Berkley Corp. of Stamford, Conn., is Maine's third-largest business casualty underwriter, according to the Boston-based Alliance of American Insurers.
Maine Mutual said it hired adjusters from Alabama to help assess the damage. Other larger insurers said reinforcements were coming from their offices in other states.
The Insurance Information Institute, a Washington-based lobby and public information office, said the industry as a whole should have no difficulty covering the losses. "We had $2 billion in damage from a series of snowstorms a few years ago and had no trouble dealing with that," a spokesman said.
Still, the insurance industry can't forget the $130 billion in losses caused by a barrage of floods, hurricanes, and other storms between 1990 and 1995 -- a siege of natural disasters that has caused some top insurance executives to consider a global climate change as the possible cause of such severe weather.
"The talk in the industry is that no one has ever even considered an ice storm of this magnitude," Shaw, the president of Maine Mutual, said. "When you think of this on a global basis, and the reach of this storm into Quebec and New York, the reinsurance industry is likely to see a real impact."

Maine Storm Losses Could Reach $75m

Author: Ackerman, Jerry

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/maine-storm-losses-could-reach-75m/docview/403919003/se-2?accountid=10226

____________________________________________________________

Ice storm evidence global warming here

Author: Speirs, Rosemary

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/ice-storm-evidence-global-warming-here/docview/348431454/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: [Jean Chretien]'s cabinet was almost the only part of the federal government still on the job Friday. Four days of freezing rain turned Ottawa's streets into a shambles of broken trees and downed hydro wires, causing the mayor to proclaim the capital a disaster area. Banks and federal departments told their employees to stay home and Defence Minister Art Eggleton called out the armed forces. Already, the Insurance Bureau of Canada said the costs of the ice storm will exceed even that of last May's Winnipeg flood. Henry Hengeveld, federal science adviser on climate change, said Friday: "We cannot blame the ice storm on global warming. The ice storm is caused by El Nino (the recurring current of warm air flowing from the tropical oceans). But what is causing this very unusual El Nino? The science community is very puzzled." For Canadians who had happily anticipated a warmer winter this year, the disastrous reality is coming as a shock. The massive influx of warm air from the south sliding over Ottawa and Montreal has brought repeated storms of freezing rain, instead of the snowfall that would have occurred if the temperatures had been only a couple of degrees lower. "This is the nasty side of what we can expect more often as we get into a warmer climate," Hengeveld said.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Ice+storm+evidence+global+warming+here&amp;author=Speirs%2C+Rosemary&amp;issn=08324174&amp;title=Star+-+Phoenix&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-01-16&amp;spage=D.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: OTTAWA Climate experts are hesitating to blame the worst ice storm in recorded history on global warming. But members of Jean Chretien's federal cabinet are privately conceding that this is more than a freak of nature.
It is weather of our own making.
We've had a year of evidence. Last winter's floods in Quebec's Saguenay region, the rising of the Red River around Winnipeg in the spring, out-of-season forest fires in Alberta early this winter and now a crushing ice storm across the east of the continent. Common sense is forcing even the cabinet's doubters to admit climate patterns are changing and the so-called greenhouse effect is upon us.
At Friday's cabinet meeting, Environment Minister Christine Stewart took a ribbing from fellow ministers who told her she's going overboard to convince the public she's right that we have to change our gas-guzzling ways. "Enough already, you've made your point," one minister told her.
Chretien's cabinet was almost the only part of the federal government still on the job Friday. Four days of freezing rain turned Ottawa's streets into a shambles of broken trees and downed hydro wires, causing the mayor to proclaim the capital a disaster area. Banks and federal departments told their employees to stay home and Defence Minister Art Eggleton called out the armed forces. Already, the Insurance Bureau of Canada said the costs of the ice storm will exceed even that of last May's Winnipeg flood.
In Environment Canada's Toronto offices, federal meteorologists said there's no direct proof that this particular ice storm is the result of global warming. While scientists have built models able to measure the global effects of climate change, they don't yet have the capacity to prove the connection to specific disasters.
Climate change experts, however, have been forecasting just such a pattern of turbulent weather as greenhouse gases build in the atmosphere trapping heat at the Earth's surface.
Henry Hengeveld, federal science adviser on climate change, said Friday: "We cannot blame the ice storm on global warming. The ice storm is caused by El Nino (the recurring current of warm air flowing from the tropical oceans). But what is causing this very unusual El Nino? The science community is very puzzled."
Since meteorologists began recording weather this century, this is the largest El Nino yet. Some scientists argue that El Ninos will be bigger and warmer during the next decades of climate change as the surface temperatures of the tropical oceans rise.
"I would say the scientific community is not in consensus," Hengeveld said. "But the suggestion is that El Ninos will be more intense during global warming. And that suggestion has not been refuted."
For Canadians who had happily anticipated a warmer winter this year, the disastrous reality is coming as a shock. The massive influx of warm air from the south sliding over Ottawa and Montreal has brought repeated storms of freezing rain, instead of the snowfall that would have occurred if the temperatures had been only a couple of degrees lower. "This is the nasty side of what we can expect more often as we get into a warmer climate," Hengeveld said.
For Stewart, the question now is whether Canadians will accept the evidence before their eyes or will continue to deny what is happening.
Combatting global warming means cutting the polluting greenhouse emissions pouring from our industrial smokestacks and vehicle tailpipes. Those who are reluctant to pay for pollution control or make the shift to renewable energy sources point to the lack of hard scientific proof as an excuse for inaction.
It is this wall of indifference, or outright denial, that Stewart and Energy Minister Ralph Goodale hope to penetrate in a series of meetings with provincial ministers, municipal officials and industry groups that starts later this month.
The two federal ministers will be asking all the players to buy into Canada's target, announced in Kyoto last month, for cutting greenhouse gases by nearly 20 per cent over the next 13 years.
Like many other Ottawa homeowners, or residents of Montreal's south shore, I had a broken tree lying in my driveway this weekend, where my car and teenage son were standing only minutes before the huge limbs came crashing down. I don't need definitive scientific evidence about global warming. Anyone with eyes can see that we've already procrastinated until it's almost too late.
(c) 1998 Toronto Star Syndicate

People: Chretien, Jean; Stewart, Christine; Hengeveld, Henry

Man's greed fuels global bonfire: [Main/Lifestyle, , 2* Edition]

Author: Paul Brown Note: (STF) - The breakdown of the rule of law has helped make 1997 the worst ever year for sending forests all over the world up in smoke. Paul Brown reports.

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/mans-greed-fuels-global-bonfire/docview/269172515/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: FOREST fires deliberately lit by man in many parts of the world have made 1997 the worst year in recorded history for destruction of the natural environment, a report released recently says. The biggest and most numerous fires were in Brazil, where they raged along a 16,000km front, and still burn. Second came Indonesia, where months of haze put 40,000 people in hospital. But Papua New Guinea, Colombia, Africa, Australia and southern Europe have had large areas devastated, too. Greece, Spain, Italy and France have all suffered, according to the World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) report, entitled The Year the Earth Caught Fire.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Man%27s+greed+fuels+global+bonfire&amp;author=Paul+Brown+Note%3A+%28STF%29+-+The+breakdown+of+the+rule+of+law+has+helped+make+1997+the+worst+ever+year+for+sending+forests+all+over+the+world+up+in+smoke.+Paul+Brown+reports.&amp;issn=&amp;title=New+Straits+Times&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-01-14&amp;spage=10&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: FOREST fires deliberately lit by man in many parts of the world have made 1997 the worst year in recorded history for destruction of the natural environment, a report released recently says.
The biggest and most numerous fires were in Brazil, where they raged along a 16,000km front, and still burn. Second came Indonesia, where months of haze put 40,000 people in hospital.
But Papua New Guinea, Colombia, Africa, Australia and southern Europe have had large areas devastated, too. Greece, Spain, Italy and France have all suffered, according to the World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) report, entitled The Year the Earth Caught Fire.
Although the droughts in the Amazon and Southeast Asia caused by the change in monsoon patterns brought about by the strong El Nino in the Pacific are partially to blame, human greed is the main cause.
The breakdown of law and order in many countries has escalated the destruction.
Although some countries, including Indonesia, claim that lighting fires is banned, much of the damage there is on government-funded projects.
Forest fires have always been a hazard of lightning during hot periods or drought, and in some cases they help the environment by creating clearings and healthy regeneration, the reports says.
But the risks are increased by human activities such as selective logging, drainage and pollution-related climate change.
Most accidental fires result from losing control over fires started for land clearance, charcoal burning and cooking. Some begin from transport and dropped cigarettes.
But this year the main causes have been land clearance for farms or plantations, timber speculation, insurance crime and even vandalism.
"The widespread breakdown of the rule of law is a critical factor in fire abuse," the report says.
The data are backed by satellite information analysed by the Woods Hole Institute in the United States and Edinburgh University.
Researchers all agree that the destruction is continuing. Some peat fires in Indonesia are expected to burn for years. Although damped down by rains, they are likely to break out again in the dry season.
Claude Martin, director-general of WWF said: "These fires were not an act of God. They were deliberately set, as they have been for many years, to clear forests for other purposes, and sometimes to cover up for timber poaching and land theft.
"It is also increasingly clear that the guilty parties are not just small farmers, as has been assumed, but most of the damage is being done by plantation and timber companies. This is not just an emergency, it is a planetary disaster."
Barita Manullane, from Indonesia, where two million hectares of forest have been lost this year, said government-sponsored rice-growing projects were chiefly to blame.
He is in charge of a project to save the Orang Utan and said the swamp forests where they survive, were being drained and deliberately burned, even though it was in his view impossible to grow rice there.
"The peat has now caught fire and despite the rains coming, burns on. I cannot see how they can ever put them out. Many of the animals are dead or driven from the trees by the haze."
Fires in Brazil have increased by 50 per cent compared to last year. Loggers, cattle farmers and peasants have taken advantage of the dry season to clear land. An average 599 new fires a day were reported, making 24,549 fires in a period of 41 days.
In Brazil's Atlantic rain forest one of the rarest mammals in the world, the golden lion tamarind, is threatened by deliberate burning.
In Colombia there have been 7,000 forest fires, including 37 in protected areas, and 16,000ha of national parks have been burnt.
Papua New Guinea is suffering its worst drought of 50 years and speculators have burned thousands of square kilometres of forest and grassland, leaving millions on the edge of starvation.
An international relief effort is under way but loss of vegetation is expected to affect the climate.
Most recently, Australia has suffered forest and scrub fires, which have penetrated the suburbs of Sydney.
Kenya's famous Imenti Forest around Mount Kenya has been burned by illegal settlers as bribed forest officials turn a blind eye.
Tanzania, Senegal and the Congo have had large forest fires.
Rwanda's relic cloud forest was threatened in the Nyungve Montane Forest Reserve, where several square kilometres were left burning for weeks with no attempt to put them out.
Michael Tene, an attache at the Indonesian embassy in London, said: "We regret the fires which we are trying to stop, but we do not have the means.
"We are not a stupid people. We want the forests but at the same time we have to feed 200 million people and so we need rice, too."
Illustration Caption: File picture ... Malaysian firemen helping to put out forest and peat fires in Desa Sekumbong, Jambi, Indonesia, last year.

____________________________________________________________

And the forecast is more to come

Author: Geoffrey Lean, Environment Correspondent

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/forecast-is-more-come/docview/312698031/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: MORE tornadoes will hit Britain as global warming takes hold, scientists and insurance chiefs believe. And the "twister" that tore apart the seaside town of Selsey, West Sussex, on Wednesday night is likely to make insurance more expensive. But Britain was not the only country to experience extreme weather last week. In Canada, the country's worst ice storm on record has wreaked havoc across five eastern provinces - shutting down airports and trains and cutting power to 3 million people - 40 per cent of the population - in Quebec.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=And+the+forecast+is+more+to+come&amp;author=Geoffrey+Lean%2C+Environment+Correspondent&amp;issn=09519467&amp;title=The+Independent&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-01-11&amp;spage=2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: MORE tornadoes will hit Britain as global warming takes hold, scientists and insurance chiefs believe. And the "twister" that tore apart the seaside town of Selsey, West Sussex, on Wednesday night is likely to make insurance more expensive.
But Britain was not the only country to experience extreme weather last week. In Canada, the country's worst ice storm on record has wreaked havoc across five eastern provinces - shutting down airports and trains and cutting power to 3 million people - 40 per cent of the population - in Quebec.
Hundreds of Montreal residents abandoned their homes to take shelter in community centres and schools with generators. The government deployed more than 4,000 soldiers to help with relief efforts.
At least 10 deaths in Canada were blamed on the storm, and more freezing rain on Friday spread misery from the Canadian capital, Ottawa, in eastern Ontario, across southern Quebec to the Atlantic provinces.
Back in Britain, scientists warned that the tornado that hit Selsey was caused by unusually warm seas in the English channel and an intense thunder storm. Both factors are expected to become more common due to the man-made climatic change that scientists believe is under way.
The official inter-governmental panel on climate change predicts that seas will get warmer and the weather stormier world-wide as the world heats up.
Dr Terence Meaden, founder of the Tornado and Storm Research Organisation, said winter tornadoes tended to start over the sea, which is warmer than land, and that Britain, as an island, was particularly vulnerable.
Insurers are also waking up to the possibility of increased tornado- related pay-outs. Andrew Dlugolcki of General Accident said last week's tornado would be likely to affectpremiums even though the amount of damage - pounds 10m - was tiny by the standards of natural disasters.
Residents in Selsey have been warned about cowboy builders.Several incidents where people have handed over large sums of money for relatively small repairs are being investigated by police.
But Britain has not finished with weather extremes - this weekend appears to have provided a taste of spring, with warm sunshine under blue skies. Forecasters called it "a rare treat".

LETTERS TO THE EDITOR: [CITY EDITION]

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/letters-editor/docview/254059955/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: I wonder why the Dayton Daily News Editorial Board does not understand that men will do almost anything to restore their hair (`Male nightmare question arises,' Dec. 29). Granted, it seems like a big gamble to risk one's virility in exchange for a head full of hair. But sometimes appearance is more important than reality - just ask the women who are willing to risk their health with breast implants. Or ask the doctors who perform cosmetic procedures and the makers of cosmetics, false nails and eyelashes, breast forms and hosiery. We are a society obsessed with appearance. Of course, I've had women tell me baldness is no big deal; I've overheard some of these same women critique the appearance of other men. I've seen surveys that indicate that a sizable minority of women is not concerned with a man's hairline; these surveys also showed that a sizable majority of female respondents is not attracted to a balding pate. Truth be told: Short, fat and bald are the worst things to be.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=LETTERS+TO+THE+EDITOR&amp;author=&amp;issn=08970920&amp;title=Dayton+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-01-10&amp;spage=9.A&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   In our society, appearance means more than reality
I wonder why the Dayton Daily News Editorial Board does not understand that men will do almost anything to restore their hair (`Male nightmare question arises,' Dec. 29). Granted, it seems like a big gamble to risk one's virility in exchange for a head full of hair.
But sometimes appearance is more important than reality - just ask the women who are willing to risk their health with breast implants. Or ask the doctors who perform cosmetic procedures and the makers of cosmetics, false nails and eyelashes, breast forms and hosiery. We are a society obsessed with appearance.
Of course, I've had women tell me baldness is no big deal; I've overheard some of these same women critique the appearance of other men. I've seen surveys that indicate that a sizable minority of women is not concerned with a man's hairline; these surveys also showed that a sizable majority of female respondents is not attracted to a balding pate. Truth be told: Short, fat and bald are the worst things to be.
I would agree that science has had little to offer balding men. We are still at the `snake oil' stage of remedies, with no permanent, safe and affordable solution yet offered.
My suggestion is that cloning techniques be utilized to reproduce unlimited supplies of hair plugs and that the procedure to implant them become as commonplace - and affordable - as a trip to the dentist.
Robert P. Troxell Centerville
Dayton must take bold steps
to restore city's liveability
The Jan. 6 editorial `City's posture on baseball begs question' was, unfortunately, right on target. The editorial writer's foresight was depressing but all too true.
Dayton is dying fast and has become a very undesirable place to live in. We have falling property values and poor basic services - in particular, law enforcement and code enforcement. We have horrible schools, and there's nothing but hope on the horizon.
The city can live again. It will take a few bold and very unpopular moves. Let's start with some very aggressive policing. The city streets are a great place to start, since there's no traffic enforcement. There's a ton of money waiting to be collected. The booming auto stereos also would be a good source of revenue. Let's not forget how much all the impounded cars would bring if we had someone enforcing the state insurance laws.
I have never lived in a city where the police presence on the streets is so nonexistent. People can walk the streets at three in the morning or three in the afternoon with their 40-ouncers and go unchecked. We need beat cops who have the `Not on my beat attitude' and a political system that will support them.
If we are going to save Dayton, we have to clean up the streets. I'm not referring to litter, either. For revenues downtown, open an area designated as a `Combat Zone.' Here would be the strip clubs and other controversial forms of entertainment. Then we would have revenues downtown, and many of the undesirables who drag down our neighborhoods would have a place to congregate and sell their wares. The majority of the problems would be in a concentrated area. That would cut down on the manpower requirements for vice squads and allow the aggressive posture around the rest of the city that it needs.
To get this city liveable again, it's going to take guts and a `show-me-the-money' attitude.
Citizens are ready to live with controversial and unpopular moves if it means the neighborhoods and main thoroughfares would be safe again. ...
Chuck A. Boudrow Dayton
Scientists in `irrelevant' fields
know plenty about climate
I must question Rowland Nethaway's use of a report by a Washington business group, the Citizens for a Sound Economy Foundation, to attack the credentials of thousands of scientists who recently expressed their concern over global climatic disruption (`U.S. should base its position on facts rather than dogma,' Dec. 15).
The CSE report judged that only scientists in a handful of fields can legitimately be considered experts on climate change. Almost 100 disciplines, including ecology, forestry, botany and biology, were ruled out as irrelevant. Yet it is researchers in precisely these areas who are most aware of the wide-ranging, day-to-day impacts of climate change. ...
The scientists' statement represents the most significant political statement by a highly qualified and diverse group of scientists since the groundswell of opposition from the scientific community to the nuclear threat. It demonstrates consensus among diverse interests and makes clear that climate change affects untold aspects of our lives.
It is the height of irony that CSE should even write about the climate-change debate going on within the science community. CSE is funded by a long list of fossil-fuel companies. Many of these companies have underwritten the handful of skeptics in the scientific field who, working largely outside the peer-reviewed literature, have attempted to reposition global warming as a theoretical phenomenon rather than fact.
John Passacantando Alexandria, Va.
Mr. Passacantando is executive director of Ozone Action, a nonprofit environmental organization based in Washington, D.C., that is dedicated to atmospheric protection.

Nature snaps its fingers: Ice storm brings us together - and reminds us who's boss: [Final Edition]

Author: Abley, Mark

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/nature-snaps-fingers-ice-storm-brings-us-together/docview/433230295/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: It had been a Manitoba maple, tall and slender. When it crashed, its trunk destroyed a birdfeeder on the ground with the casual ease of a man crumpling a ball of paper. I stepped gingerly outside, and heard a similar fall on the next block. A snap, a dull thud: all of a sudden, these were noises to dread. It wasn't always so. When Europeans first came to North America, some of them saw the ability to survive the bitter winters as proof of moral superiority over the mild, decadent Old World. Snowy winters in the 19th century - just think of the lush whiteness of a Krieghoff painting - were viewed as emblems of beauty and renewal. In many ways, nature has been losing. The forest fires that ravaged Indonesia last year left the impression that the tropics are burning up. The oceans have fewer and fewer fish in them; many scientists now class cod as an endangered species. Five hundred years ago, when John Cabot's sailors landed on the shores of what they called "New Founde Lande," the cod were so abundant that men could dip a basket in the sea and haul it in, brimming with life.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Nature+snaps+its+fingers%3A+Ice+storm+brings+us+together+-+and+reminds+us+who%27s+boss&amp;author=Abley%2C+Mark&amp;issn=03841294&amp;title=The+Gazette&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-01-08&amp;spage=A.1.FRO&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   When it happened, I was looking out the kitchen window, wondering plaintively how many hours would pass before I could boil a kettle or heat some hot chocolate for my daughters. The house was cooling fast, and the yard was already strewn with branches. A crisp, snapping sound drew my gaze just in time for me to watch a tree breaking like a toothpick.
It had been a Manitoba maple, tall and slender. When it crashed, its trunk destroyed a birdfeeder on the ground with the casual ease of a man crumpling a ball of paper. I stepped gingerly outside, and heard a similar fall on the next block. A snap, a dull thud: all of a sudden, these were noises to dread.
It wasn't just the next block, of course. All over the city, the island, the whole region, ice had assumed power. Whatever our age or language, whatever our religion or income level, we'd been taken captive by a force greater than ourselves.
The experience stirs old memories, old talents. In a crisis like this, we recall how to improvise heat, how to conserve priceless warmth. One of my neighbours fried bacon and eggs yesterday morning by setting up a propane stove on his driveway. People find ways of making do; the healthy ones, at least.
And, like most kinds of crises, this one has the power to bring its victims together.
We tell stories to each other, as though the mere exchange of yarns and schemes would make winter a milder jailer. Usually, I'm not a fan of open-line radio; but in the past couple of days, I've become an avid listener.
If you listen, you pick up knowledge; when you're in the know, you gain a sort of power. Among the most isolated - and therefore, the most powerless - are those people who not only lack heat and light, but also lack a radio with batteries.
Still, no amount of information can turn the Hydro crews into magicians. Like it or not, they have become our escape masters. Their work alone can liberate us from the captivity of cold and darkness.
The crisis has stirred another old, almost atavistic sense: a respect for the sheer dominance of nature. As a rule, we neglect this awareness. Between November and April, daily life in all of Quebec and most of Canada depends on the capacity to hold nature at bay.
We pretend to have conquered nature. Most of the time, nature plays along, jabbing us occasionally in the ribs. You could even say that Montreal, like every other city in a harsh climate, is built on a foundation of denial.
It wasn't always so. When Europeans first came to North America, some of them saw the ability to survive the bitter winters as proof of moral superiority over the mild, decadent Old World. Snowy winters in the 19th century - just think of the lush whiteness of a Krieghoff painting - were viewed as emblems of beauty and renewal.
Not any more. As early as World War II, an American company was advertising its snowplows with the slogan "Snow - Friend of the Enemy." In this decade, the city of Montreal has spent tens of thousands of dollars to promote our city as an underground haven: somewhere you could escape winter without the help of Dorval airport.
If the fallen power lines had a voice, they might be saying: "Dream on." It may be, indeed, that when we finally lurch past the millennium, we'll realize that one of the defining qualities of the 1990s has been the escalating war between nature and humankind.
In many ways, nature has been losing. The forest fires that ravaged Indonesia last year left the impression that the tropics are burning up. The oceans have fewer and fewer fish in them; many scientists now class cod as an endangered species. Five hundred years ago, when John Cabot's sailors landed on the shores of what they called "New Founde Lande," the cod were so abundant that men could dip a basket in the sea and haul it in, brimming with life.
But nature still has its weapons. Just ask the residents of the Saguenay, where the sudden flood of July 1996 killed 10 people and caused roughly $800 million in damages. In a mere two days, the volume of rain that fell on the area was equivalent to the water that pours over Niagara Falls in a month.
Or ask the people who live near the Red River in southern Manitoba. Last spring, 28,000 of them had to flee their homes. The flood created a freshwater sea in which the false-fronted prairie towns became fortified islands.
Around the world, it seems, severe floods are becoming common enough that language fights to keep up. The people of the Netherlands suffered a "flood of the century" in 1993. Two years later, they had another one.
Forget day-to-day politics - and isn't that a relief? Yet beyond all the soundbites and question periods of the year gone and the year to come, many of the key issues facing Canadians are issues about our relationship to nature: questions about energy use, toxic waste, forest conservation, climate change and so on.
Perhaps it's too much of a stretch to relate this week's conquest by ice to that alarming list. Perhaps our present struggles are indeed a mere freak of nature. After all, if the ice had the power to overturn a clutch of steel pylons that carry 735,000 volts of electricity, it's no wonder it also had the power to destroy the maple tree in my back yard.
I'm not so sure. After the last big ice storm in 1983, Montrealers discovered that thousands of the mangled trees had already been weakened by acid rain. It would have been a good lesson to remember; but probably it was human nature to forget the lesson until now.
The effect of the rainfall on the Saguenay, we eventually found out, was worsened by clear-cutting of the forests and dam-building along the waterways. Likewise, the impact of the Red River flood was heightened by the destruction of natural wetlands.
It's not just the David Suzukis of this world who sometimes sound alarmist. It was, bear in mind, the giant Swiss Re insurance company that issued a report in 1994 warning that "Climate will not just change in future; it is doing so today.
"The danger of unmanageable extreme weather situations is therefore not a future threat but already an acute one."
Tell us about it.
Nature, in short, is under constant siege. But when nature snaps back, watch out. Montreal may be finding now - just as Chicoutimi did in 1996 and Winnipeg in 1997 - that our onslaught on the natural world in the end makes things worse for ourselves.
Illustration Color Photo: PETER MARTIN, GAZETTE / A woman makes her way along Oxford Ave. in N.D.G. ;
