What climate change means to you: Businesses and individuals will have to change for Canada to meet its commitments to cut greenhouse gas emissions. But there are gains from these sacrifices.: [Final Edition]

Author: Isaacs, Colin

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/what-climate-change-means-you-businesses/docview/269900236/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Some in industry are concerned that governments will force them to spend money to address the climate change issue, but many industry leaders are already taking climate change into account in their business decisions. The insurance industry is raising rates to cover anticipated weather-related damage. The natural gas companies are telling us that we can reduce greenhouse gas emissions by at least 10 per cent by switching from oil to natural gas. Some oil companies, such as BP, Shell, and Sunoco, are investing heavily in alternative energy projects that can meet society's needs for heat, warmth, and transportation with far less impact on the atmosphere than conventional energy sources. The automobile industry is investing heavily in alternate fuels and more fuel efficient vehicles. For most of the past 10,000 years, the CO2 (carbon dioxide) concentration in the atmosphere remained stable at about 280 parts per million (ppm). Since the industrial revolution, however, the concentration of CO2 has increased 30 per cent and, today, stands at 364 ppm. Conservative estimates for the year 2100 suggest the CO2 concentration will approach 500 ppm, or nearly double that of the pre-industrial era. In addition, it is known that the concentrations of the other major greenhouse gases, methane and nitrous oxide, are also on the rise. The IPCC was given the mandate to assess, on a comprehensive, objective, open and transparent basis, the scientific, technical and socio-economic information relevant to understanding the risk of human-induced climate change. Worldwide, it is the IPCC assessment of climate change science that stands as the "scientific consensus."

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=What+climate+change+means+to+you%3A+Businesses+and+individuals+will+have+to+change+for+Canada+to+meet+its+commitments+to+cut+greenhouse+gas+emissions.+But+there+are+gains+from+these+sacrifices.&amp;author=Isaacs%2C+Colin&amp;issn=11899417&amp;title=The+Spectator&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-01-06&amp;spage=A.9&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Note
The agreement reached at the international conference in Kyoto last month marked a turning point in world attitudes towards climate change. While there is still uncertainty about precise impacts, world leaders in science, government, and industry now agree that human activity is changing the climate. The challenge of the next 15 years will be to incorporate that reality into our everyday decisions.
Some industry groups have tried to argue that climate change is a myth. The world scientific community is now generally agreed that human activities are contributing increased levels of greenhouse gases to the atmosphere and that this will have an impact on the climate.
It is true that some scientists still disagree, but there are very few issues about which scientists are unanimous. Science is a process of discovery and debate. It is not a process that provides instant facts. Even Einstein's Theory of Relativity is still unproven, though we use it everyday as the basis for launching satellites and planning major energy industry initiatives.
Global warming, climate change, and the greenhouse effect are three terms that have been used almost interchangeably. The term global warming is somewhat misleading.
Increased levels of greenhouse gases will trap more of the sun's energy on the surface of the earth, but that does not mean that every place gets warmer. Climate is the result of a complex interaction of the atmosphere with the oceans and the continents, mountains and valleys, and the temperature effects of day and night. Global warming will not occur uniformly. Some places will become warmer, others will become cooler.
IMPACT
Ontario will still experience extended periods of intense cold. Weather patterns will become less predictable and more violent. In Ontario, the average level of the Great Lakes is likely to fall, necessitating expensive dredging for shipping and perhaps reducing hydroelectric generating capacity. (An Environment Canada report suggests warming could cause a rise in sea level because of melting of ice and the general expansion of ocean volume due to higher temperature, while Great Lakes levels will decline due to increased evaporation counteracting increased precipitation.)
Summers will become warmer, with longer heat waves and an increase in episodes of unhealthy air pollution. The forests in cottage country will suffer from heat stress and forest fires will become more frequent. Violent storms may become more frequent in our area.
Some in industry are concerned that governments will force them to spend money to address the climate change issue, but many industry leaders are already taking climate change into account in their business decisions. The insurance industry is raising rates to cover anticipated weather-related damage. The natural gas companies are telling us that we can reduce greenhouse gas emissions by at least 10 per cent by switching from oil to natural gas. Some oil companies, such as BP, Shell, and Sunoco, are investing heavily in alternative energy projects that can meet society's needs for heat, warmth, and transportation with far less impact on the atmosphere than conventional energy sources. The automobile industry is investing heavily in alternate fuels and more fuel efficient vehicles.
Interestingly, the North American petroleum industry, sometimes a critic of the Kyoto negotiations, may be among the biggest losers if climate change is allowed to take hold. About 10 per cent of Canadian oil is used for home heating. If winters become warmer, we will be buying less heating oil. In the north there is already evidence that the tundra is melting and heavy equipment used by oil companies is becoming mired in the mud. More violent storms in the North Atlantic could threaten the offshore oil rigs with dramatically increased costs.
Change does not come just from the Kyoto agreement. Change happens all the time. Fifteen years ago we did not have home computers or compact disks. Who knows what new technologies we will have by 2012? Business makes investment decisions every day, taking into account a wide range of factors to maximize the return to investors. Climate change will become one of the factors considered when planning new initiatives. Those who plan well will succeed. Those who plan badly will see their companies fail, just as happens today.
Steel companies are already moving away from basic steel plate to specialty steels that provide higher performance but use less material. Packaging is being reduced from big clumsy boxes to sleek pouches and lightweight plastic materials. These are the very trends that will help us deal with the climate change problem. The concept of value-added--taking a current product and making it better, or developing a new product that is more exciting and can be sold for a higher price--is already an entrenched business concept.
Doing more with less will become not just a government slogan but a watchword for the entire economy. Both Japan and Europe are already working to make their economies much more energy efficient. By doing so they will reduce the costs of production and make their goods and services much more competitive in world markets.
Climate change is not just about industry. If we ignore the problem, we leave the next generation with an inheritance that will be bad for health and lifestyle. Climate change is an environmental deficit, not unlike the economic deficit that voters have told governments to address. If we are to avoid the environmental deficit, lifestyle changes will be essential, but change does not mean turning the clock back.
Our homes will become more energy efficient, using low energy lighting and low flow appliances such as showers and washing machines that are already common in many parts of the world. Our cars will use less fuel and we'll have transit services that can really get us to work and school. Furniture and appliances will become repairable, upgradeable, and recyclable at the end of their useful lives. We may have a little less stuff but that does not mean that we will have less fun: Recreation, organized sport, education, culture, art, and theatre are among the many activities that can have much less impact on the atmosphere than motorized vehicles and piles of material possessions.
Meeting the Kyoto targets will not be easy. Many scientists believe that before we get too far into the next century we will realize that we have to achieve much more than the Kyoto targets if we are to avoid leaving a real environmental disaster for our children. There is no silver bullet, no quick easy step that will solve the problem overnight. Instead, as the figures in the box at left show, every sector of the economy has something to contribute.
For the climate change problem, the costs of inaction are far greater for Canada than the costs of action. The sooner we start planning to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions, the lower will be the cost and the greater the economic and employment opportunities that we can create.
GREENHOUSE GAS SOURCES
The major sources of greenhouse gases in Canada are power generation, industrial processes, industrial fuel use and cars and trucks. A complete list of the percentage contribution of different sectors to total greenhouse gas emission (in 1995) follows.
Source Per cent of total emissions

fuel use 0.5

Trucks 10

KYOTO AGREEMENT TO REDUCE EMISSIONS
At the 1992 Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro, 36 countries including Canada entered into a voluntary agreement to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to 1990 levels by 2000.
Today, it is clear that the majority of these countries will fall short of this objective. The United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change Secretariat has reported that, among developed nations, the United States, Japan and Canada are responsible for 85 per cent of the increase in CO2 (carbon dioxide) emissions between 1990 and 1995 (United States, 56 per cent; Japan, 21 per cent; Canada, 8 per cent). Based on the relative size of the economies and populations of the United States and Japan, Canada's record is poor.
Projections indicate that despite our efforts since then to reduce emissions, without additional climate change initiatives, Canadian emissions in the year 2000 may still range from 8 per to 13 per cent higher than in 1990.
In Kyoto in early December, agreement was reached on legally binding timetables and targets in which Canada agreed to work toward cutting six greenhouse gas emissions by 6 per cent by 2012. These aren't cuts from today's levels but from baseline measurements in 1990 for three of the gases and either 1990 or 1995 for three others.
Source: Kyoto and Beyond, the report of the Standing Committee on Environment and Sustainable Development in Ottawa, December 1997, and a Dec. 11, 1997 United Nations Press release.
For more information on the Internet, check www.ec.gc.ca/climate
WHAT SCIENTISTS SAY
For most of the past 10,000 years, the CO2 (carbon dioxide) concentration in the atmosphere remained stable at about 280 parts per million (ppm). Since the industrial revolution, however, the concentration of CO2 has increased 30 per cent and, today, stands at 364 ppm. Conservative estimates for the year 2100 suggest the CO2 concentration will approach 500 ppm, or nearly double that of the pre-industrial era. In addition, it is known that the concentrations of the other major greenhouse gases, methane and nitrous oxide, are also on the rise.
These facts, coupled with the observation that global mean surface air temperature had increased 0.3 degrees to 0.6 degreesC over the past 100 years, alerted climatologists and, in turn, policy- makers, to the potential for significant warming of the earth's atmosphere over the next century, a phenomenon which could produce many possible negative consequences.
Around the world, this concern resulted in increased funding and the rapid expansion of climate change research. In particular, it was considered essential to determine whether human activity had been a factor in the increase in greenhouse gases, and thus has contributed to the global warming trend. In 1988, under the auspices of the World Meteorological Organization and the United Nations Environment Program, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) was created.
The IPCC conducts an open-ended process where both the number of participants and the number of participating countries vary. The IPCC process is open to all member countries of the United Nations, and from time to time more than 120 nations have taken part. A mix of approximately 2,500 scientists, economists and other specialists have been engaged in the IPCC process--either in the submission of papers to the IPCC or in the review of these documents.
The IPCC was given the mandate to assess, on a comprehensive, objective, open and transparent basis, the scientific, technical and socio-economic information relevant to understanding the risk of human-induced climate change. Worldwide, it is the IPCC assessment of climate change science that stands as the "scientific consensus."
In 1995, the IPCC stated that "the balance of evidence suggests that there is a discernible human influence on global climate."
Source: Kyoto and Beyond, the report of the Standing Committee on Environment and Sustainable Development in Ottawa, December 1997.
Colin Isaacs of Stoney Creek is a former MPP and longtime environmental campaigner now working as a consultant with his company Contemporary Information Analysis Ltd.

Insurers braced for L100m storm-damage claims bill: [London edition]

Author: Adams, Christopher

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/insurers-braced-l100m-storm-damage-claims-bill/docview/248249427/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Severe storms which have buffeted western and northern parts of the UK since Christmas have caused tens of millions of pounds in structural damage to houses and commercial property. Heavy rain and winds gusting at more than 100mph lashed south-west England on Sunday, toppling trees and flooding roads, as another major storm moved north-east across England from Devon and Cornwall. Part of the sea wall at Westward Ho! in north Devon was demolished, and in northern France motorists and pedestrians were banned from coastal areas.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Insurers+braced+for+L100m+storm-damage+claims+bill&amp;author=Adams%2C+Christopher&amp;issn=03071766&amp;title=Financial+Times&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1998-01-05&amp;spage=08&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Severe storms which have buffeted western and northern parts of the UK since Christmas have caused tens of millions of pounds in structural damage to houses and commercial property.
Heavy rain and winds gusting at more than 100mph lashed south-west England on Sunday, toppling trees and flooding roads, as another major storm moved north-east across England from Devon and Cornwall.
In the Channel, huge waves swamped a drifting Spanish trawler and ripped panels from the bow section of a Stena Line s ferry. Many sailings were cancelled.
Part of the sea wall at Westward Ho! in north Devon was demolished, and in northern France motorists and pedestrians were banned from coastal areas.
The cost of most structural damage will be borne by the insurance industry. Loss assessors acting for policyholders predicted yesterday claims could total nearly £100m.
Royal & Sun Alliance , the country's biggest household insurer, said it had received thousands of telephone calls reporting structural damage, but it was too early to quantify the cost. Guardian Royal Exchange said it was handling five times the normal volume of calls.
"Tiles have blown off roofs, houses have suffered flooding, and trees have fallen on cars," said AA Insurance . "It's been exceptionally busy."
Andrew Dlugolecki, assistant general manager at General Accident , the Perth-based insurer, blamed global warming for an increase in the frequency and severity of windstorms and flooding.
"Over the last 10 to 15 years, we've seen a tremendous amount of damage from storms. They are the most costly events in the UK," he said.
Statistical records compiled for the past 300 years show that strong gales are more common during mild winters. But a report last week by Munich Re , the world's biggest reinsurer, said the number of storms worldwide had risen threefold since the 1960s.
"That extreme atmospheric events accounted for such a large proportion of the losses is evidence of climate change," the report said.
The latest storms will not cost insurers as much as the hurricane which struck southern England in October 1987, when they paid out almost £1bn in claims. That storm was thought to be a one-in-200-year event until another very destructive storm struck in 1990.
The Meteorological Office forecast more winds across the south today, but not as strong. Copyright Financial Times Limited 1998. All Rights Reserved.

Full text: Tough talk, sanctions aren't working in Iraq
It is time for the United States to rethink its strategy toward Iraq and Saddam Hussein. Presently, the United States is talking tough and posturing itself militarily in the Persian Gulf, but how realistic is the challenge posed by our forces? We can threaten air strikes, but at this stage in history, who is really impressed by this sort of saber-rattling?
The Pentgon admits that the chances of actually destroying any of Saddam's chemical or biological weapons in a bombing raid are remote. (Nuclear bombs would do the trick, but their use is politically unthinkable.) A ground invasion and occupation force would be needed to neutralize Iraq, but China, Russia, France and other Arab states oppose military intervention. It would be unwise to act unilaterally so long as Saddam merely hordes his weapons of mass destruction. Unless he actually uses them, we cannot strike without U.N. approval.
And what is the purpose of continuing the sanctions against Iraq? Years of deprivation have failed to turn the people against Saddam. His iron rule seems as strong as ever, and though Iraq may be a pariah state, he remains recalcitrant.
We should try lifting the sanctions allowing much needed supplies of food and medicines to be imported. This could mollify the Iraqis and give them more sanguine feelings for America. Healthy and well-fed, they might be disposed to become more independent of Saddam.
The stick has led only to stalemate, so why not try the carrot? Give Iraq the benefit of the doubt.
In any case we must not be misled by hubris into pursuing a futile and profitless military operation.
Bruce Waller
Chesterfield
Page Avenue solutions
I am not concerned about the Page Avenue extension running through Creve Coeur Park, but I am concerned about the funds this one project will consume for the next several years. This, when there are so many other needed projects in this area.
Without question, this bridge will mainly benefit one concentrated group of people living in one county. Therefore, I would propose that St. Charles County pay for all costs of building the bridge, including the approaches. Also, the state Highway Department should pay for all costs of acquiring land and building a highway to the bridge in both St. Louis and St. Charles counties.
Since St. Charles County would be paying for the bridge it could have a choice:
(1) Start at scratch, hire a new engineering firm to design the bridge, and handle everything in connection with a new bridge.
(2) Or it could let the state continue with its design and construction, but then reimburse the state for all costs of construction of the bridge, including all costs incurred to date for surveys, design, etc. Also during construction the only cost for administration would be the cost of operating a field or job office, and the salaries of the personnel assigned to it. All cost already incurred would be prorated over the life of the job. Also, payments would be due on a monthly basis because that is the way the state pays its contractors.
I believe this would be a fair solution to all concerned citizens living in the area.
Bill Williams
Florissant
Man of principle
Jerry Berger's Dec. 16 column categorized Town & Country's mayor, John Marx, as "combative." I've worked with John in several capacities, in and out of city government, for several years. "Combative" is not a term that I would use to describe his approach to municipal government.
John is a man of principle, conviction and faith. He genuinely wants to do what is right, which sometimes causes political opponents who have sacred cows that they are trying to protect to run for cover and to sling rocks and accusations that are half-truths at best. I call for civility, for all of Town & Country's aldermen to work with the mayor, for progress.
Thomas N. Tener
Town & Country
Teen rights
I read with interest the Nov. 28 article, "Seniors get `Sting 101' lesson as incognito officer joins class." It's about an Edwardsville police officer who posed as a high school student for a few weeks to investigate possible drug problems inside the school.
The school's superintendent, Tom Bradley, apparently has been pushing for this since last year, in addition to already using drug-sniffing dogs and being allowed to search students' cars. Despite the investigation's concluding that there isn't a drug problem inside the school, Bradley seems intent on continuing these tactics.
This police officer was allowed to investigate anyone he wanted to, and he was going into their parents' homes without the parents' knowledge. He justified this by saying, "If you're not doing anything wrong, then you have nothing to worry about."
The article states that some of the students felt violated but neglected to look at the ramifications of these actions. How can we expect students to grow up and be productive members of a democracy when we don't treat them like valued citizens?
There is pending legislation to give teens urine tests prior to allowing them to drive (potential Fourth Amendment violation), their newspapers are censored (First Amendment violation), their lockers, cars, belongings and persons are all searched, possibly without just cause.
These students are not learning how to demonstrate a healthy skepticism of authority. If we neglect the freedoms we have, fascists like Bradley a nd Officer Dave Matevey will continue to sacrifice our freedoms for security.
Marty Woods
St. Louis
Confused verdict
Convicting Terry Nichols of one count of conspiracy and eight counts of involuntary manslaughter seems to present an oxymoronic dilemma.
While conspiracy denotes a deliberate intent, involuntary manslaughter is the result of recklessness or accidental death. It appears that jurors, in their hurried attempts to reach a compromise verdict, were so confused that they outsmarted themselves.
Gene Carton
University City
Universal care
Candidate Steve Miloscia (3rd Congressional District) seems to forget when he submitted his Dec. 23 letter that the old bogeyman "socialized medicine" is no longer the scare phrase used in opposition to universal health-care insurance.
Not that Rep. Richard Gephardt has shown real concern about the more than 700,000 uninsured in Missouri and the more than 80,000 in his own district, but the day is over when "socialized medicine" is used to put fear in people. Better informed voters now know that universal health insurance is a simple non-profit way of cutting out seven-figure salaries for the private HMO CEOs, dividends for stockholders and getting an administrative cost of less than 3 percent compared to the 11 percent to 30 percent of for-profit HMOs.
If Miloscia wishes to support the for-profit, high-cost conglomerates, he might consider a more factual method to convince Gephardt that he, too, should acknowledge that "Medicare for all" regardless of age is a simple universal and cost-saving plan.
Unfortunately, some Democrats of the "new order" forgot their platform of 1992 calling for universal health insurance and changed to "access" in 1996. The later platform spent 70 percent of its verbage telling how great the party was and very little in sound platform issues.
Eugene P. Schwartz
University City
Clinton's big ideas
The Dec. 11 editorial, "Milkman's son in Camelot," said: "Perhaps, the Gephardt speech can also provide an intellectual challenge to Mr. Clinton that could awaken the president from his fixation with small ideas."
The best economy in a generation, lowest unemployment rate in 24 years, the largest expansion of educational opportunity, the best moral leadership on the problem of race since Camelot, the comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty and now the climate change treaty. Such presidential leadership does not indicate a "fixation with small ideas."
Lee Eames
Columbia, Mo.

Matthews, 1986), for the last of which, with Michael Bawtree, Orr won the 1988 Seagrams Prize of the America National Music Theatre Network, during his stay as composer-in-residence at the Banff Centre for Fine Arts in Alberta, Canada.
There are six song-cycles for voice and piano or instrumental ensemble, as well: The Knight and the Lady (1978) for solo voice, and The Echoing Green (1961), after William Blake, for children's voices and piano or orchestra.
His orchestral works likewise show his concern for his audience. In compositions intended for serious listeners, such as the 40-minute Sinfonia Ricercante of 1987, Orr deployed his considerable technique to produce music that would satisfy the most demanding intellect.
Yet in others, like the Triptych (1977), the Fanfare and Processional for strings (1968) or the Carmen Fantasy for cello and orchestra (1987), his sense of humour guaranteed works of immediate appeal. (In fact, A Carmen Fantasy began life as the first of a series of four operatic fantasies for cello and piano; the others are Portrait of the Don (on Don Giovanni, 1987), Catfish Row (on Porgy and Bess, 1997) and Tales from Windsor Forest (on Falstaff, 1997).)
A consistent feature of Orr's surprisingly large output is his music for brass or wind band, some ten in total and composed across his career. There are two concertos, for trombone (1971) and for trumpet (1976), both with brass band, and a number of other pieces, not least A John Gay Suite for symphonic wind band (1972), Tournament for ten solo brass (1985) and the recent Narration for symphonic winds (1993), drawn from music for The Alchemist, an opera on which Orr was still working at the time of his death. (He left part of the first act orchestrated and the rest complete in piano score. After Benjamin Frankel's death in 1973 Orr orchestrated the piano score of Frankel's opera Marching Song; The Alchemist now requires another composer to perform Orr the same service.)
There is also a substantial corpus of chamber music, including two string quartets, three piano trios (the only "serious" Orr to have been recorded on CD), a recent string trio, and most of the series of six Refrains, composed between 1970 and 1992 for a variety of instrumental forces; these are basically extended rondo structures in which, as the composer put it, "a recurrent idea is used to bind together a total structure".
But a dry list of compositions doesn't give a picture of the man, of the delighted twinkle in his eye when he was discussing something he held important (I once sat virtually speechless through a dinner where Orr and Hans Keller discussed, with genuine passion, the significance of a particular gesture in a single bar in the slow movement of a Mozart piano concerto). And he never lost that Scottish ability to draw the humour from misfortune.
He told with glee of attending a performance of Billy Budd at the Royal Opera House when he was suddenly stricken with the most appalling upheaval in his stomach.
Fearing the worst, he swiftly pushed his way past the knees and baleful glares of the stalls audience to try to get out in time. And, Orr would ask with a grin, what do you think the sailors' chorus on stage was singing at this point? "Heave! Oh, heave!"
It is time the classical world caught up with the music of Buxton Orr. The recording of the Piano Trios appeared around a year ago on the Marco Polo label, and A John Gay Suite is due out before too long from Naxos, Marco Polo's sister, budget label; A Celtic Suite for strings (1968) has also been recorded by Black Box.
But that will hardly give an adequate picture of Orr's ability as a composer. Two CD programmes - a coupling of the Sinfonia Ricercante and Triptych and, less ambitiously, a disc of the two String Quartets and the String Trio - push themselves forward as an obvious place to start.

Greenhouse gas deal is a small step for mankind The Kyoto Climate Change Summit could prove to be a major watershed in international relations, writes Frank McDonald, Environment Correspondent: [CITY EDITION]

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/greenhouse-gas-deal-is-small-step-mankind-kyoto/docview/310278025/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: If one believes Michael Grubb of the Royal Institute of International Affairs in London, the Kyoto Protocol on Climate Change will be seen as standing alongside the Treaty of Versailles and the Bretton Woods agreement as one of the major deals of the modern era. It is probably too early to judge whether Mr Grubb has got it right. Nonetheless, the fact that 160 countries with very diverse agendas were able to agree on a protocol to reduce the greenhouse gas emissions blamed by scientists for causing climate change must be ranked as a significant step forward. That's why it was so important to get flexibility from the United States, as the world's largest single polluter, accounting for nearly 25 per cent of all greenhouse gas emissions. The US came to Kyoto offering merely to stabilise its emissions at 1990 levels between 2008 and 2012, but left after agreeing to a 7 per cent reduction.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Greenhouse+gas+deal+is+a+small+step+for+mankind+The+Kyoto+Climate+Change+Summit+could+prove+to+be+a+major+watershed+in+international+relations%2C+writes+Frank+McDonald%2C+Environment+Correspondent&amp;author=&amp;issn=&amp;title=Irish+Times&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-30&amp;spage=57&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: If one believes Michael Grubb of the Royal Institute of International Affairs in London, the Kyoto Protocol on Climate Change will be seen as standing alongside the Treaty of Versailles and the Bretton Woods agreement as one of the major deals of the modern era.
It is probably too early to judge whether Mr Grubb has got it right. Nonetheless, the fact that 160 countries with very diverse agendas were able to agree on a protocol to reduce the greenhouse gas emissions blamed by scientists for causing climate change must be ranked as a significant step forward.
Apart from the preservation of biological diversity, progress on measures to curb climate change was the sine qua non of any credible international effort to protect the global environment. Though every country has its own environmental problems, the threat posed by climate changes eclipses them all.
This threat could be confronted only on the basis of equity. There was simply no way that developing countries such as China and India were going to agree to limit their greenhouse gas emissions without a "firm purpose of amendment" in advance from the industrialised nations which caused the problem in the first place.
That's why it was so important to get flexibility from the United States, as the world's largest single polluter, accounting for nearly 25 per cent of all greenhouse gas emissions. The US came to Kyoto offering merely to stabilise its emissions at 1990 levels between 2008 and 2012, but left after agreeing to a 7 per cent reduction.
All the indications, however, are that the Kyoto deal hailed by President Clinton will not be ratified by the US Senate, at least with its present political complexion. And the fossil fuel lobby, led by the Global Climate Coalition, is already working hard to ensure that this important agreement bites the dust on the Senate floor.
The Kyoto protocol will be open for signature from next March, and it is expected that President Clinton will make quite a show of signing it. Along with his vice-president, Mr Al Gore, who hopes to be the Democratic Party's nominee for the White House in 2000, he seeks to court the large environmental lobby in the US.
Mr Clinton and Mr Gore may also be banking on the prospect that the influence of the fossil fuel lobby will begin to wane in the aftermath of Kyoto. Certainly, with the year-by-year rise in the number of weather-related catastrophes worldwide, it is likely that the insurance industry will become increasingly vocal.
1997 has been a year of spectacular disasters. The once-in-a-century floods in Poland, the Czech Republic and eastern Germany during last July and August caused 120 deaths, led to 187,000 people being evacuated from their homes and are estimated to have cost at least $5 billion in damage to property. Other extreme weather events in 1997 included the worst drought this century in northern China, the worst floods within living memory in East Africa, torrential rains and flash floods in the western US and a hurricane in Mexico which destroyed 97 per cent of the corn crop and damaged numerous tourist hotels in Acapulco.
Few but the "contrarians" continue to doubt the verdict of the Inter-governmental Panel on Climate Change that human activity is altering our climate. There can also be little doubt that the next assessment from the IPCC, which is made up of 2,500 scientists from around the world, will consolidate this thesis.
By next autumn, when the fourth Conference of the Parties to the UN Climate Change Convention gathers in Buenos Aires, the scientific evidence will be even stronger and major players such as the US will find it more difficult to argue in favour of loopholes to evade taking action to deal with the problem.
But even if the cuts in greenhouse gas emissions agreed in Kyoto had been as deep as the European Union initially sought, they would not have been enough to halt climate change. One way or the other, this phenomenon is likely to continue for 100 years or more, even if greenhouse gas emissions are stabilised.
What Kyoto did was to send out a message - however weak and compromised - that we need to change our ways. The profligate society which wastes the world's resources must yield to a more rational dispensation, which puts the emphasis on energy conservation, efficiency and the exploitation of renewable sources.
This is already happening, particularly in Europe. Greater use of urban public transport and national rail networks as well as unprecedented levels of investment in wind and solar energy are all paying dividends in terms of reducing atmospheric pollution and putting the EU at the forefront of technological innovation.
Though the EU managed to portray itself as "the light of the world" in Kyoto, it is still open to question whether it will now soften its commitment to achieve a 15 per cent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2010 in any renegotiation of its current burden-sharing arrangement - the so-called "bubble". Under the present deal, Ireland is meant to cap the increase in its emissions at 15 per cent - a target which IBEC, for example, regards as quite unrealistic. For without firm action, as the Minister for the Environment, Mr Dempsey, warned in Kyoto, Ireland's emissions could be 55 per cent higher in the year 2010.
The acid test of the EU's commitment will be whether its 15 finance ministers can agree on a Union-wide carbon tax. This was originally floated by the European Commission in 1992, at the time of the Earth Summit, but it has since become bogged down in the mire of consensus decision-making on fiscal measures.
Britain's deputy prime minister, Mr John Prescott, has said that Kyoto provided a "window of credibility" for the industrialised world to show the developing countries it was genuinely prepared to take action on climate change. If they are to be brought on board, that credibility will have to be built on between now and Buenos Aires.

Insurance firms face an avalanche of storm claims Some of the implications of last week's storm, now acknowledged as the worst in Ireland for 23 years, are assessed by Frank McDonald, Environment Correspondent: [CITY EDITION]

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/insurance-firms-face-avalanche-storm-claims-some/docview/310339193/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: The chairman of the Heritage Council's architectural committee, Mr David Slattery, expects that its phones will be ringing this morning with distress calls from owners of historic buildings. Insurance companies are also bracing themselves for what could amount to an avalanche of claims for storm damage. "There's no doubt that some historic buildings in substandard condition which were awaiting funds for repairs have probably suffered considerable damage," Mr Slattery told The Irish Times. "These would be buildings with slates gone from the roof which were already at risk of not surviving the winter." The Heritage Council has been allocated an extra (pounds) 500,000 towards its grants scheme for architecturally important buildings. But that sum was intended to help clear its current backlog of cases rather than to deal with new appeals from property owners facing repair bills after the storm.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Insurance+firms+face+an+avalanche+of+storm+claims+Some+of+the+implications+of+last+week%27s+storm%2C+now+acknowledged+as+the+worst+in+Ireland+for+23+years%2C+are+assessed+by+Frank+McDonald%2C+Environment+Correspondent&amp;author=&amp;issn=&amp;title=Irish+Times&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-29&amp;spage=5&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The chairman of the Heritage Council's architectural committee, Mr David Slattery, expects that its phones will be ringing this morning with distress calls from owners of historic buildings. Insurance companies are also bracing themselves for what could amount to an avalanche of claims for storm damage.
"There's no doubt that some historic buildings in substandard condition which were awaiting funds for repairs have probably suffered considerable damage," Mr Slattery told The Irish Times. "These would be buildings with slates gone from the roof which were already at risk of not surviving the winter."
The Heritage Council has been allocated an extra (pounds) 500,000 towards its grants scheme for architecturally important buildings. But that sum was intended to help clear its current backlog of cases rather than to deal with new appeals from property owners facing repair bills after the storm.
Mr Slattery said the increasing frequency of storms - which may be linked with global climate change - had already brought about changes in the design of new buildings, particularly in terms of roof pitches, in an effort to protect them against wind speeds higher than 80 m.p.h.
A spokesman for Hibernian Insurance said storm damage was an "integral part" of the vast majority of insurance policies for domestic or commercial buildings. Most reputable companies also offer a helpline service to put people in touch with contractors to carry out emergency repairs.
Mr Malcolm Hughes, chief executive of Farrell and Associates, a leading Dublin firm of loss adjusters, said the biggest problem facing householders who suffered storm damage would be to find a contractor, given that the building industry is officially on holiday until next Monday.
He also believed that roofing contractors would be reluctant to carry out major repairs "until the weather dies down". And with another storm forecast for tomorrow, running into New Year's Eve, he expected it would take some time before much of the damage to buildings is finally repaired
Mr Hughes expects that last week's storm would be the most significant he has had to deal with, primarily because the damage was so widespread. "The payout will be much higher than for Hurricane Charlie," he predicted.
Many claims are expected to include compensation for food which defrosted in home freezers during electricity cuts. These will be against the insurance companies rather than the ESB. Mr Hughes pointed out that the removal of fallen trees is not covered unless they have caused damage to buildings.
He stressed that no insurance company would seek to evade claims under a household policy by defining the storm as an "act of God". Such a defence could prove useful, however, to a householder against a public liability claim from a passer-by who had been injured by slates falling from a roof.
Trees have been the major casualties of last week's storm. The arboretum on Fota Island, Co Cork, has lost some of its older specimen trees, including some exotic varieties. "Trees are down all over the place", said Mr Barney Whelan, a spokesman for the ESB, who had been touring the worst affected areas, including West Cork. "Ash, beech, sycamore and other native hardwoods have been brought down everywhere, particularly in exposed hilly areas and up side roads."
The storm inevitably hit farmers. Cowsheds in hillside locations had their roofs blown off. There was also damage to sea defences on the shoreline, particularly around Youghal and Dungarvan.
The ESB's work to restore power lines was hampered in many places by fallen trees. Emergency crews had to carry new poles up the side of Mount Eagle, in Co Limerick, because fallen trees and hilly terrain prevented access by vehicles, including JCBs.
More trees are likely to be felled by the storm forecast for tomorrow or Wednesday. Last week's storm was south-easterly, veering south-westerly; the next one is forecast to be a north-westerly. Trees which survived Christmas Eve may be felled by high winds from the opposite direction.
But it's an ill wind that blows no good. Ten years ago, when a similar storm ravaged southern England, environmentalists initially regarded its impact on the landscape as catastrophic. The latest view, however, is that it had a regenerative effect by getting rid of so many old trees.

Global Warming: [Final Edition]

Author: Hume, Stephen

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/global-warming/docview/242894782/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Indeed, the publicist's release promoting [Wayne Grady]'s book The Quiet Limit of the World, the chronicle of a 1994 scientific expedition to the Arctic to study global warming, consists of a series of plainly argued factual refutations of a recent editorial in The Globe and Mail which advocated caution in responding to calls for action to curb the release of greenhouse gases. [Ross Gelbspan] systematically flays the confusionist arguments, revealing in the process the pathology of a troubling attempt to distort the nature of scientific debate, advance self-serving corporate agendas and to plant doubts in the public mind regarding the indisputable facts of climate change that are supported by the scientific method. There is good news in this bad news, Gelbspan says. Eyeing the prospect of a $50-billion payout if Miami takes a direct hit from some warming-intensified hurricane, insurance underwriters are suddenly discovering the merits in green arguments.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Global+Warming%3A&amp;author=Hume%2C+Stephen&amp;issn=08321299&amp;title=The+Vancouver+Sun&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-27&amp;spage=F.5&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The truth is out there: Is the threat of global warming genuine - or is it an over-stated myth? New books illuminate the forces that fight for our hearts and minds on this issue. It's in our best interests to understand the reasons behind the conflict.
THE HEAT IS ON: THE HIGH STAKES BATTLE OVER EARTH'S THREATENED CLIMATE
By Ross Gelbspan
Addison Wesley, 278 pp., $31.50
THE QUIET LIMIT OF THE WORLD: A JOURNEY TO THE NORTH POLE TO INVESTIGATE GLOBAL WARMING
By Wayne Grady
Macfarlane, Walter & Ross,
266 pp., $29.95
THE WAR AGAINST THE GREENS: THE WISE USE MOVEMENT, THE NEW RIGHT AND ANTI-ENVIRONMENTAL VIOLENCE
By David Helvarg
Sierra Club Books, 502 pp., $32.50
A group of learned skeptics gathered recently at a conference sponsored by the Fraser Institute, a conservative think-tank, to debunk the notions of global warming that are generally endorsed by their mainstream colleagues.
They sounded plausible, even persuasive, citing a variety of sources to challenge the view that human industrial activity - primarily through the burning of fossil fuel - is loading unprecedented amounts of carbon-based gases into the atmosphere and triggering a greenhouse effect.
At best, they seem to suggest, the current mainstream consensus that global warming is underway is an hysterical exaggeration of naturally occurring climatic cycles. At worst it's an outright hoax perpetrated to further the political agenda of radical green cultists.
But Andrew Weaver, recent winner of the prestigious Steacie Award and a highly-respected professor at the University of Victoria School of Earth and Ocean Sciences, dismisses the arguments raised against global warming as a product of economic agendas rather than objective science.
"There is a lobby group that wants to put these people in high profile. But none of those people are experts in climate. They have no argument," he says.
"They are so out of touch. A lot other evidence has come on board. It's very compelling. There is no doubt about that evidence. We can say it [global warming] is caused by human beings. That is well established. We are sure of it."
And Weaver is equally dismissive in his critique of the media's decision to take these attacks on global warming seriously.
"You have editors who are essentially business editors, who know squat about the science and whose opinions should be discounted to zero," he says.
So, is the threat of global warming genuine - after all, a federal scientific panel looking into the matter once said that only a thermo-nuclear exchange between superpowers gives humans the potential to so radically change the world in which they live - or is it largely an over-stated myth cooked up by eco-nuts, goddess worshippers and left-wing chicken littles?
To understand the context in which scientists like Weaver frame their skepticism of the skeptics, David Helvarg's The War Against the Greens offers a meticulously documented insight into the evolution of a backlash that serves not knowledge but the financial interests of resource industries.
He charts the careful corporate construction of a pseudo- grassroots citizens' movement - in which British Columbia's own Share movement finds its conceptual origins - which has as its long- term objective the deregulated and unrestricted use of timber, oil, gas, mineral and range land, not to mention the abolition of environmental laws and enforcement agencies.
Behind this "Wise Use" agenda is the financial backing of South African mining companies, Canadian and American timber companies, huge Japanese conglomerates, the National Rifle Association and even the ultra-conservative Unification Church of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon.
"Only in the cynical argot of Washington, where `perception is reality,' could a corporate-sponsored environmental backlash successfully sell itself as a populist movement," Helvarg says.
"If the anti-enviros' links to the Farm Bureau, Heritage Foundation, NRA, logging companies, resource trade associations, multi-national gold mining companies, Japanese ORV manufacturers and a Korean billionaire who thinks he's God prove anything, it's that large industrial lobbies and transnational corporations have learned how to play the grassroots game."
"Confusionism" is what mainstream scientists call the sniping from the fringes, frequently from individuals whose own research is heavily funded by vested interests like the coal industry.
And it can be seductive to the simple-minded.
The mainstream media, enmeshed as it is with large-scale corporate culture, often appears to remain doubtful about the consensus of mainstream science. It's a peculiar reversal of the media's usual tendency to embrace the mainstream and to doubt the efficacy of fringe groups in politics, economics and culture.
Indeed, the publicist's release promoting Wayne Grady's book The Quiet Limit of the World, the chronicle of a 1994 scientific expedition to the Arctic to study global warming, consists of a series of plainly argued factual refutations of a recent editorial in The Globe and Mail which advocated caution in responding to calls for action to curb the release of greenhouse gases.
If there is a public perception of increasingly severe weather events around the globe, this does not prove that global warming is the culprit, the newspaper argued.
Grady, with elegant prose and graceful logic, weaves natural science, oceanography and Arctic history into a forceful narrative that compels the discerning reader to conclude otherwise.
He explains from firsthand knowledge how scientists discovered that the polar ice cap is 30 per cent thinner than it was in 1987 and how new data and more sophisticated computer modelling now link severe weather events around the world to the accelerated warming of the earth.
In fact, he points out, the years 1992, 1993, 1994, 1995 and 1996 have one disturbing thing in common - they are the five hottest years in recorded human history. And after Europe's sweltering summer, 1997 will probably join the list.
The consequences are already observable in the Canadian arctic. Mean annual temperatures a metre beneath the tundra have risen by more than a degree in the past decade and the permafrost has begun to melt, triggering 2,000 landslides and leaving a moonscape of sink holes and foreshores eroded by storm surges from the Arctic ocean.
If the polar ice caps melt quickly and completely, warns Grady, "we'll be living on a different planet."
Another bracing antidote to the self-interested nonsense from economists and corporate spin doctors that now masquerades as science is the work of Ross Gelbspan, one of those shoe leather investigative reporters who comes with a Pulitzer Prize and a distinguished professional pedigree from The Boston Globe, The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Washington Post.
Gelbspan systematically flays the confusionist arguments, revealing in the process the pathology of a troubling attempt to distort the nature of scientific debate, advance self-serving corporate agendas and to plant doubts in the public mind regarding the indisputable facts of climate change that are supported by the scientific method.
He begins not with theory, but with concrete, easily-observable events.
"In January 1995 a vast section of ice the size of Rhode Island broke off the Larsen ice shelf in Antarctica," Gelbspan points out. "Although it received scant coverage in the press, it was one of the most spectacular and nightmarish manifestations yet of the ominous changes occurring on the planet."
Then he quotes Dr. Rodolfo del Valle, the Argentine scientist who witnessed the disintegration of the 20,000-year-old ice shelves:
"If conditions remain unchanged (rising global temperatures) could cause catastrophic flooding all over the world. We thought the flooding would occur over the course of several centuries, but the whole process has been much quicker than we anticipated."
Since then, a 65-kilometre-long crack has opened in the adjoining ice shelf and work by Columbia University scientists discovered that the entire west Antarctic ice sheet is losing mass to the oceans.
Mainstream science remains divided on whether this instability indicates the imminent collapse of the ice sheet, but one thing is not in dispute - Antarctica serves as an immense global thermostat regulating the ocean temperatures and currents which determine both weather and climate on the continents we inhabit.
Meddle with it and things will change.
Small wonder, then, that while one group of corporate interests seeks to manipulate the public perception of reality to the benefit of its bottom line, another - the insurance industry - is beginning to sweat bullets at the prospect of global warming.
That's because one of the consequences of atmospheric change predicted by the mathematical modelling of climatologists is an increase in frequency and intensity of extreme weather events.
Last year at a conference in Toronto, the Insurance Bureau of Canada presented a vision of global warming that was far from that presented at the Fraser Institute in Vancouver.
"Climate change has brought a growing flood of catastrophic damage that is expected to get even worse. Hurricanes, typhoons, tornadoes, hailstorms, floods, drought - all have become more frequent and much more intense," delegates were told.
"In high-risk areas, insurance companies have been bankrupted, premiums increased, protection reduced and some property owners left with no insurance protection."
There is good news in this bad news, Gelbspan says. Eyeing the prospect of a $50-billion payout if Miami takes a direct hit from some warming-intensified hurricane, insurance underwriters are suddenly discovering the merits in green arguments.
And so The Heat is On is more than a depressing lament, it's also an expression of hope and a call to action. One of the most hopeful developments, he argues, is this emerging coalition between one of the global corporate giants of the information age - the insurance industry - and the environmental movement.
Another, he says, is the fact that we have the possibility of a fix in clean alternative energy sources - solar power, wind power, tidal power - and new technologies like the hydrogen fuel cell which permits internal combustion engines without burning the polluting hydrocarbons that contribute to global warming.
This fix won't be cheap or easy, but it will be cheaper and easier than waiting for the coming changes to overwhelm us.
In the meantime, what's shaping up says Gelbspan, is a conflict in which the insurance industry will use its formidable resources to battle the fossil fuel industry for the control of public perceptions of reality.
Think of what's ahead as a battle between the information age of the future and the dirty industrial age of the past.
An informed, educated public will play a critical role in determining its outcome, Gelbspan says. Books like these contribute powerfully to that education.

On the slow train from Kyoto: [ALL Edition]

Author: Buell, John

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/on-slow-train-kyoto/docview/413869736/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: If there were a contest for the most overblown news event of 1997, the global warming summit in Kyoto ought to win hands down. The editors of the Bangor Daily News were charitable in labeling it merely "hot air." An inordinate amount of political energy has gone into the discussion of largely unenforceable numerical targets for reductions in greenhouse gases. In the process, the conference has distracted us from the real issue, the economic gains that sensible greenhouse reduction strategies would bring. The hallow nature of the Kyoto summit is highlighted when we consider the quieter but more significant politics of transit policy in the United States. While U.S. delegates to the global summit trumpeted this nation's new found commitment to the environment, Congress struggled to approve a paltry two year, $2.3 billion subsidy for Amtrak. Both Congress and the environmentalist president are now on record that all subsidies for Amtrak will cease by 2002.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=On+the+slow+train+from+Kyoto&amp;author=Buell%2C+John&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-23&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: If there were a contest for the most overblown news event of 1997, the global warming summit in Kyoto ought to win hands down. The editors of the Bangor Daily News were charitable in labeling it merely "hot air." An inordinate amount of political energy has gone into the discussion of largely unenforceable numerical targets for reductions in greenhouse gases. In the process, the conference has distracted us from the real issue, the economic gains that sensible greenhouse reduction strategies would bring.
The hallow nature of the Kyoto summit is highlighted when we consider the quieter but more significant politics of transit policy in the United States. While U.S. delegates to the global summit trumpeted this nation's new found commitment to the environment, Congress struggled to approve a paltry two year, $2.3 billion subsidy for Amtrak. Both Congress and the environmentalist president are now on record that all subsidies for Amtrak will cease by 2002.
The decision slowly to starve Amtrak is misguided economics and destructive ecology. Maine, which is on the receiving end of dirty Northeastern air and growing summertime gridlock, has a disproportionate stake in this debate. The logic behind the unending war on Amtrak is that old canard: the free market should decide our transit options.
Even as an economics 101 theorem, this nostrum runs into immense problems. Healthy transportation systems expand markets and convey benefits to far more than the initial users and purchasers. Transit is an activity that catalyzes and encourages many other economic activities. Because of these spillover effects, market price is a poor guide to transit policy. From the earliest days of our republic, governments at all levels have sought to guide transit policy. Generous subsidies favored canals and rail in the nineteenth century. Without this intervention our economic growth would have been substantially slower.
More startling is how one sided we are in demanding that rails pay their own way. Federal grants to Amtrak are "operating subsidies," but the billions spent every year to police mid eastern oil is "national defense." When rail workers maintain or upgrade a road bed, they are engaged in "rail work." When police or fire fighters come to the scene of a traffic accident, they are performing "police work." Jane Holtz Kay, the author of Asphalt Nation, has recently calculated that twenty percent of all state and local budgetary expenditure is auto related, yet motorists pay far less than this amount directly. Kay estimates that if the cost of gas relfected the real social costs of auto related transit, gas would be at least $5.00 a gallon. Yet how many of us refer disapprovingly to the "subsidized gas" on which our auto travel depends?
What have we bought with our subsidized auto transit? The United States has the least efficient transit system in the advanced industrial world. Two decades ago, Ivan Illich pointed out that when we consider the hours needed to earn the post tax dollars to purchase a car, charges for its insurance and repair, the time spent in traffic and in search of parking, our cars really move us at about five miles an hour. We would do much better on bikes, but modern cities seldom make that safe or practical.
A calculation using Illich's methodology today would doubtless yield even more discouraging numbers. Europeans with their more balanced transit policies have achieved greater levels of mobility for substantially less cost. Much of the enhanced competitiveness of Europe and Japan in recent years is a reflection of the greater ease in moving people and product components.
Not surprisingly, the ecological consequences are just as disheartening. The auto alone is responsible for a third of all U.S. greenhouse emissions. And even while parked, the car is an ecological disaster. The Environment and Forecasting Institute in Heidelberg estimates that about a third of U.S. energy goes to production of the auto and the infrastructure needed to sustain it. And every year autos kill about 40,000 of our fellow citizens and maim hundreds of thousands.
Unfortunately, alternatives to the auto are caught in their own vicious circles. Amtrak's critics correctly point out that service is often slow and equipment old and uncomfortable. But slow service and dilapidated equipment are consequences of a generation of underfunded capital needs. These conditions in turn make it hard to attract new customers and build the political and financial foundation for further growth.
Nothing speaks as clearly to the power of the auto in our politics and culture as events in Washington and Kyoto. Amtrak is slowly starved and the Kyoto meetings talk more about abstract targets than about the future of the auto. Some will say that Americans love cars, and surely even radical critics can't challenge that assertion. But their love of cars might be tempered by more honest discussion of the the causes and consequences of an auto-dependent society. And if Americans love cars so much, shouldn't cars be able to pay their own way in the free market?
John Buell is a political economist who lives in Southwest Harbor. Readers wishing to contact him may e-mail comments to: jbuell@acadia.net.

Global climate change treaty could be boon for Wisconsin: [All Edition]

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/global-climate-change-treaty-could-be-boon/docview/260695987/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: As details of the global climate change treaty in Kyoto emerge, the economic doom-and-gloom forces already have begun unleashing their public relations blitzkrieg on the treaty. The Wisconsin Farm Bureau and American Forest Association have blasted the treaty as an economic disaster when quite the opposite could be true. I believe there's a better way. Wisconsin's 22 coal-fired power plants produce 7,000 megawatts of electricity. With minor adjustments, each coal-fired plant could include biomass wood waste and crops with coal for fuel. Presently, only two coal plants include biomass. For instance, a 5% replacement of coal with biomass would create the equivalent of a 350 megawatt power plant and require 1 million tons annually of state-grown biomass, creating up to 3,000 rural jobs. As the coal and fossil fuel "soot advocates" attempt to frighten Americans with an economic doomsday scenario, remember that a strong climate treaty can create an economic boom for Wisconsin. Americans can choose to roll up their sleeves and begin a cleanup or they can sit back, complain and deny the mess even exists. You decide.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Global+climate+change+treaty+could+be+boon+for+Wisconsin&amp;author=&amp;issn=10828850&amp;title=Milwaukee+Journal+Sentinel&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-21&amp;spage=5&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: As details of the global climate change treaty in Kyoto emerge, the economic doom-and-gloom forces already have begun unleashing their public relations blitzkrieg on the treaty. The Wisconsin Farm Bureau and American Forest Association have blasted the treaty as an economic disaster when quite the opposite could be true.
Whether or not global warming is true, a strong global climate treaty could result in an economic boom for Wisconsin.
Currently, Wisconsin imports 90% of its energy, sending $6 billion annually to coal states such as Wyoming and petroleum exporters such as Iraq.
I believe there's a better way. Wisconsin's 22 coal-fired power plants produce 7,000 megawatts of electricity. With minor adjustments, each coal-fired plant could include biomass wood waste and crops with coal for fuel. Presently, only two coal plants include biomass. For instance, a 5% replacement of coal with biomass would create the equivalent of a 350 megawatt power plant and require 1 million tons annually of state-grown biomass, creating up to 3,000 rural jobs.
Estimates show that 4.5 million tons of wood residue is available in Wisconsin yearly or enough biomass to offset 20% of our coal use.
Wisconsin agriculture has the potential of completely displacing our state's transportation fuel imports with biofuels such as soy diesel and non-corn-based ethanol. A 10% blend of biofuels statewide (as Minnesota requires) could retain $400 million to $800 million annually in Wisconsin's economy.
These fiscal estimates don't begin to include the environmental and health savings expected from a significant reduction in fossil fuel use.
As the coal and fossil fuel "soot advocates" attempt to frighten Americans with an economic doomsday scenario, remember that a strong climate treaty can create an economic boom for Wisconsin. Americans can choose to roll up their sleeves and begin a cleanup or they can sit back, complain and deny the mess even exists. You decide.
Michael Mangan Emerald Energy Delafield Treaty would
hurt Wisconsin farmers The global climate change treaty will have
a negative impact on farmers' costs of production.
One of the most disturbing elements of the treaty is that negotiations were done without input from agriculture on incentives and programs that can help reduce energy use. Had that been done, this treaty could boost opportunities for agriculture to continue its contribution to environmental protection, instead of having the threat of higher fuel and electricity costs.
At the Wisconsin Farm Bureau Federation annual meeting Dec. 9, farmers approved resolutions to support state and national energy policies that encourage energy conservation and alternative sources of energy from agricultural products.
Farmers want an energy policy that promotes an increase in production and marketing of agricultural-based fuels such as switch grass, supports the use and production of ethanol from corn and provides incentives and research for converting farm waste and farm products such as whey to energy.
Farmers are probably the biggest contributors to environmental protection and hold the potential for more advancements in finding alternative sources of energy.
Increasing markets and the use of agricultural products will perhaps raise farm income to offset higher costs of production. A national policy of incentives and research will open the doors for those opportunities.
Tom Thieding Executive director Communications Wisconsin
Farm Bureau Federation Thomas should heed his own warning In
his column of Dec. 17, Cal Thomas makes a valid point when he writes that we should be cautious as we listen to the debate on global warming.
We should indeed: While Thomas appears persuasive, he omits information crucial to the reader's full understanding. I'll cite just one example.
S. Fred Singer, whom Thomas quotes at length, is one of a handful of scientists regularly cited by those who oppose pollution restrictions. But Thomas does not tell us what writer Ross Gelbspan does in his 1997 book, "The Heat is On."
Singer openly acknowledges that he is funded at least in part by Exxon, Shell, ARCO, Unocal and Sun oil companies, whose economic survival depends on our continuing to favor fossil fuels over energy sources that do not compromise air quality.
Moreover, on a 1994 edition of "Nightline," Singer did not deny having received funding from the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, to whose newspaper he regularly contributes.
Thomas accuses "the usually fair (Ted) Koppel" of calling Singer and his fellow skeptics "ignorant members of the Flat Earth Society.`
Had Thomas given readers more information about Singer, his funding and his political associations, readers would be in a better position to judge for themselves.
Victoria Thorpe Miller Hales Corners U.N. already doing bad
job The subject of global warming will be a hotbed of discussion
for many years to come.
My concern is with the United Nations dictating to individual countries what an acceptable amount of pollution would be. United Nations control over the fees it wants to impose will create another unnecessary bureaucracy.
For that matter, the U.N. is not doing a very good job addressing the issues within its control, such as the hunger and starvation that continue to plague Third World nations, the U.N.'s budget, which it cannot balance, and weapons-control monitoring in Iraq. I am more fearful of biological warfare than whether the Earth will get another degree warmer over the next hundred years.
If the United States fails to meet its requirements for reducing greenhouse gases, will we be sending billions of dollars to the U.N.? Will any of this money be sent to countries that are being run by dictators or warlords?
Individual governments should set their own standards and benchmarks. The people of this country have a voice if they want to make changes to address the environment.
By the way, did anyone notice if these delegates flew separately or jet-pooled?
Diane Ettmayer Hales Corners Sensenbrenner on job Kudos to you for reporting the story of Rep. F. James Sensenbrenner's reactions to the Kyoto global warming proposal. We are fortunate in Wisconsin to have a congressman who effectively monitors this global-warming farce.
The findings on this issue are not all conclusive and no such treaty without Senate consent should be even proposed. This has become purely a political issue using an emotional appeal without substantive evidence.
Janet G. Jacobs Elm Grove Warming is serious issue In the Dec. 13 Journal Sentinel, Stuart Carlson's cartoon made light fun of the idea of global warming.
After reading Ross Gelbspan's new book, "The Heat Is On," I realize we have to get very serious about this.
Gelbspan offers two ideas that are very persuasive: First, the overwhelming consensus of scientific thought is that we are in the early stages of the heating of the atmosphere. Second, the world's insurance companies are leading the opposition against the coal and oil industries because insurance payouts for weather-related damages reached $57 billion for the 1990s.
Bob Rink Menomonee Falls

NATURE WILL JUDGE KYOTO SUCCESS: [FINAL EDITION]

Author: ROSS GELBSPAN

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/nature-will-judge-kyoto-success/docview/388337330/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Judged by the enormous political obstacles confronting delegates, the international agreement on addressing climate change reached in Kyoto, Japan this week is an extraordinary political success. President Clinton and the U.S. delegation deserve great credit for resisting a $13 million advertising campaign by fossil-fuel interests to block the treaty. Their duplicitous message to Americans was "don't do anything unless developing countries who emit far less pollution do the same" while their lobbyists concurrently button-holed delegates from developing nations in the Kyoto's convention halls urging them not to sign a treaty. By adhering to the requirement of the 1992 Rio Treaty that exempts the large developing nations from the first round of energy cuts, the administration preserved America's diplomatic credibility while agreeing to U.S. cuts that are achievable. America's initial treaty obligation of 7 percent cuts below 1990 levels will, in contrast to industry doomsayers, create more jobs and more wealth for the American economy. That 7 percent number translates into a cut of about 20 percent below current emission levels because we're emitting roughly 13 percent more today than in 1990. But more than 2,000 economists and many energy specialists, including Amory Lovins at the Rocky Mountain Institute and analysts at the Tellus Institute in Boston, say that we can cut up to 30 percent simply by implementing conservation and energy efficiency measures. These moves will spark new industries, create jobs and save existing firms millions on their energy bills.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=NATURE+WILL+JUDGE+KYOTO+SUCCESS&amp;author=ROSS+GELBSPAN&amp;issn=&amp;title=Sun+Sentinel&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-18&amp;spage=31.A&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Judged by the enormous political obstacles confronting delegates, the international agreement on addressing climate change reached in Kyoto, Japan this week is an extraordinary political success.
Judged by the accelerating effects of greenhouse gas emissions on our increasingly unstable climate, Kyoto is a mere dress rehearsal for the much larger effort that lays ahead.
First, the good news. While intransigent senators backed by fossil-fuel-dependent businesses say it goes too far and many environmentalists say it contains loopholes that doom it to uselessness, the "Kyoto Protocol" is an unprecedented diplomatic milestone.
For the first time, more than 150 nations have agreed that we must work together to keep the planet hospitable for our children.
President Clinton and the U.S. delegation deserve great credit for resisting a $13 million advertising campaign by fossil-fuel interests to block the treaty. Their duplicitous message to Americans was "don't do anything unless developing countries who emit far less pollution do the same" while their lobbyists concurrently button-holed delegates from developing nations in the Kyoto's convention halls urging them not to sign a treaty. By adhering to the requirement of the 1992 Rio Treaty that exempts the large developing nations from the first round of energy cuts, the administration preserved America's diplomatic credibility while agreeing to U.S. cuts that are achievable.
America's initial treaty obligation of 7 percent cuts below 1990 levels will, in contrast to industry doomsayers, create more jobs and more wealth for the American economy. That 7 percent number translates into a cut of about 20 percent below current emission levels because we're emitting roughly 13 percent more today than in 1990. But more than 2,000 economists and many energy specialists, including Amory Lovins at the Rocky Mountain Institute and analysts at the Tellus Institute in Boston, say that we can cut up to 30 percent simply by implementing conservation and energy efficiency measures. These moves will spark new industries, create jobs and save existing firms millions on their energy bills.
The administration might actually find allies in the fossil fuel community. British Petroleum has acknowledged the destructive potentials of climate change and announced a large investment in solar energy. In October, the president of General Motors called for carbon taxes to reduce emissions. Recently, Shell announced its intention to invest $500 million in renewable energies. These energy industry leaders understand the overriding scientific evidence - and the need to position their companies prominently for the world's inevitable energy transition.
Unfortunately, there is another perspective from which to judge the outcome of Kyoto, and that is the perspective of nature.
The deep oceans are warming, causing the breakup of Antarctic ice shelves and fueling, in the views of many scientists, longer and more destructive El Nino weather patterns. The Alaskan tundra, which for thousands of years absorbed carbon dioxide and methane (two key greenhouse gases), is now thawing and releasing those gases into the atmosphere. The permafrost in Siberia and Alaska is turning to pea soup. Tropical diseases are migrating north. Insurance losses to floods, droughts and severe storms are escalating by orders of magnitude. And people all over the world are increasingly vulnerable to weather-driven food shortages, property losses and personal trauma from the succession of extreme weather events, which are occurring with frightening regularity all over the world. While diplomats have argued over politically realistic cuts, the science clearly tells us that to restore our atmosphere to a hospitable state we must cut our emissions by a staggering 60 percent to 70 percent.
That is a large task - but it is one that can and must ultimately be achieved. In the U.S., we should begin the process by changing our subsidy policies. Today the federal government spends $25 billion subsidizing big coal and big oil. If all those tax credits, subsidies and incentives were diverted to the commercialization of renewable energies, it would propel them into the big league of global commerce. We should also work to deregulate the electric utility industry in a way that encourages renewable energy sources.
Ultimately a comprehensive global energy transition away from coal and oil and to climate-friendly, renewable technologies requires a partnership between the world's governments and its energy giants. The profit stream of $2 trillion in oil and coal commerce must shift to windmill plants in India, solar assemblies in El Salvador, hydrogen-producing photovoltaic farms in the deserts of the Middle East and fuel cell factories in Cleveland.
That kind of energy transition would create an economic boom and generate millions of jobs all over the globe. It would begin to reverse the widening economic gap between the North and the South. And in short order the renewable energy industry would eclipse high technology as the central driving engine of growth of the global economy.
Measured against the rather paltry reductions envisioned at Kyoto, the task seems indeed daunting. Measured against the destabilization of the global climate, it is imperative. The treaty at Kyoto is a small beginning. But it contains the seeds for a monumental sea change which could help all nations - developed and developing - prosper even as it helps pacify our inflamed climate.
X X X Ross Gelbspan is the author of "The Heat Is On: The High Stakes Battle Over Earth's Threatened Climate," Addison Wesley Longman, 1997. Readers may write to him at: 247 Kent Street, Brookline, Mass. 02146.
