Rivalry for right-wing voters' loyalty flourishing

Author: Speirs, Rosemary

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/rivalry-right-wing-voters-loyalty-flourishing/docview/348512937/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Before he flew off for sunny climes Monday, Manning gave an interview on CBC Newsworld, in which he wished aloud that [Jean Charest] would take himself off to replace Daniel Johnson as leader of the Quebec Liberals. Second, reporters know that if Johnson resigns or is defeated in the next Quebec election, Charest will be under great pressure to save Canada by replacing Johnson as leader of Quebec's only federalist party. Until the election, Charest can protest all he wants, but we all suspect his future lies elsewhere. Third, on the big issues, Charest's comments are too often a pale echo of Manning's. There are nuances in how the two parties would go about it but Charest, like Manning, is calling for tax cuts before all else. Like Manning, he calls for more power-sharing with the provinces. And, like Manning, he says the commitment made by the Liberal government in Kyoto last week to reduce greenhouse gases six per cent below 1990 levels is unachievable.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Rivalry+for+right-wing+voters%27+loyalty+flourishing&amp;author=Speirs%2C+Rosemary&amp;issn=08324174&amp;title=Star+-+Phoenix&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-18&amp;spage=A.5&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: OTTAWA Those two rivals for the right, Preston Manning and Jean Charest, offer up the same Christmas wish: that the other guy would disappear.
Before he flew off for sunny climes Monday, Manning gave an interview on CBC Newsworld, in which he wished aloud that Charest would take himself off to replace Daniel Johnson as leader of the Quebec Liberals.
With their young leader thus disposed, the Progressive Conservative Party of Canada could divide and be absorbed by other parties. "Red Tories could join the Liberals and Blue Tories could join us, and everybody would be happy," Manning said.
Charest, meanwhile, held a news conference at which he again singled out Reform MP Darrel Stinson, who recently offered to punch him out, as proof that Manning's party is too extremist for most Canadians' palates.
Reform's a short-term party, too regional and too divisive to last for long on the political scene, Charest argued. By contrast, the Conservatives, around since Confederation, are the respectable national alternative to the Liberals and will reap their reward in the next election.
Seven months after the election that gave Reform 60 seats and the Conservatives 20, but an equal split 19 per cent each of the right- wing vote, the two parties show no signs of uniting. Reform has no seats east of Manitoba and the Tories only two west of Quebec. But neither is yet ready to concede: each party still hopes to wipe the other out, and each still prefers to continue a fratricidal battle in hopes of eventually claiming all the spoils.
Manning, delighting in the trappings of being Leader of the Opposition, seems pained by the historic Conservative party's persistence.
Manning is second only to Prime Minister Jean Chretien, and perhaps to Finance Minister Paul Martin, in the amount of media attention he gets. As opposition leader, he can dominate question period because he is allotted the opening questions, helping set Parliament's agenda.
Monday, when he left Calgary on holidays, his office said that only Sandra Manning knew the couple's itinerary, an obvious signal they were heading to the sun for 10 days but prefer we don't know. Manning's staff diverted attention by throwing a party for press gallery reporters at a downtown Ottawa tavern.
Charest, at his news conference, noted matter-of-factly that nightly news coverage concentrates only on the government and the official opposition, with very little attention paid the three other parties. He's right, of course.
But a few points about the media's part in his relative obscurity. First, Charest sometimes wants attention for very little, a case in point being Monday. The press release announcing his news conference promised he'd unveil his party's four-year plan for rebuilding, but all he had to say was that he'd be holding a series of round tables of experts on the pressing issues of the day.
Second, reporters know that if Johnson resigns or is defeated in the next Quebec election, Charest will be under great pressure to save Canada by replacing Johnson as leader of Quebec's only federalist party. Until the election, Charest can protest all he wants, but we all suspect his future lies elsewhere.
Third, on the big issues, Charest's comments are too often a pale echo of Manning's. There are nuances in how the two parties would go about it but Charest, like Manning, is calling for tax cuts before all else. Like Manning, he calls for more power-sharing with the provinces. And, like Manning, he says the commitment made by the Liberal government in Kyoto last week to reduce greenhouse gases six per cent below 1990 levels is unachievable.
The difference here is that Charest, a former federal environment minister, believes the climate change threat is real and must be combatted. So, it's difficult to understand why he's put himself in the same doubters' camp as Manning, unless he hopes by doing so to gain points with big business, which so far is backing the Liberal government.
In a quieter mode, and therefore often unnoticed, Charest has attempted to build his party's reputation as a more constructive opposition than Reform, supporting the Liberals when they think the government is right. That's led to some victories, such as persuading Martin to extend the deadline for tax deductions for charitable donations because of the postal strike, giving Canadians to the end of January for their 1997 claims.
Now Charest is going for a bigger win. He's asked the Tory Senators to hold up the Liberal increases in Canada Pension Plan premiums, hoping to wangle last-minute improvements, such as more accountability by the new CPP board of directors, or lower Employment Insurance premiums as a tradeoff.
Charest's efforts at constructive opposition haven't made him headlines.
But they are what chiefly distinguishes today's Conservatives from Reformers, and, he says, makes them more fit to be the alternative government.

Leader of `Canada's Spare Tire' Ready for the Road: [Final Edition]

Author: Wells, Paul

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/leader-canadas-spare-tire-ready-road/docview/242904751/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Critiquing the Liberals' handling of the run-up to the Kyoto conference on climate change, which he accurately labelled "disastrous," Mr. [Jean Charest] tossed around enough green-wonk jargon to re-establish his credentials as the party leader most comfortable with environmental issues. You can make a good argument either for heading right or for hugging the centre. On one hand, Canadians aren't used to having two big parties to the right of the Liberals, and might regard that as an unnatural state of affairs. A Tory haunted by this will go after Reform voters. On the other hand, most Liberal voters' second choice is the Conservatives. A Tory haunted by this will go after Liberals. The trouble is getting through those three or four years without sounding like the Liberals he's criticizing. On CPP reform, he says the Liberals should "at least make a commitment to reduce (employment insurance) premiums by the same amount that they're increasing CPP premiums." The Liberals have made that precise commitment for 1998. Saying, in effect, "they'd better keep it up" is not a cry that stirs the blood.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Leader+of+%60Canada%27s+Spare+Tire%27+Ready+for+the+Road&amp;author=Wells%2C+Paul&amp;issn=08321299&amp;title=The+Vancouver+Sun&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-18&amp;spage=A.18&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Paul Wells is the Montreal Gazette's national affairs columnist.
OTTAWA -- Jean Charest still draws far more reporters to a press conference, as leader of a party with 20 members of Parliament, than do the leaders of the 44-MP Bloc Quebecois or the 21-MP New Democratic Party. The Ottawa press gallery still cuts the Progressive Conservative leader a little slack. Not much, but some.
Commenting on the parliamentary session just ended and the rest of the mandate ahead, Mr. Charest earlier this week showed the charm that remains his greatest asset, and the command of detail that separates him from Prime Minister Jean Chretien and even Reform Leader Preston Manning.
Critiquing the Liberals' handling of the run-up to the Kyoto conference on climate change, which he accurately labelled "disastrous," Mr. Charest tossed around enough green-wonk jargon to re-establish his credentials as the party leader most comfortable with environmental issues.
The environment is a manager's portfolio, and Mr. Charest is a manager, ironically better at incremental change than at laying out the grand visions he always talks about. He thinks the new Canada Pension Plan investment fund should be open to scrutiny by the auditor-general. Excellent idea. Excellent little idea.
As he tries to bring his party back from its 1993 near-death experience, Mr. Charest must decide every day whose votes to chase: the Liberals' or the Reformers'. Given his druthers, of course, he'd rather have them both, but that's not always possible.
You can make a good argument either for heading right or for hugging the centre. On one hand, Canadians aren't used to having two big parties to the right of the Liberals, and might regard that as an unnatural state of affairs. A Tory haunted by this will go after Reform voters. On the other hand, most Liberal voters' second choice is the Conservatives. A Tory haunted by this will go after Liberals.
Mr. Charest is haunted by those Liberal votes. Somebody once called the Tories, the party voters have turned to when they can't stomach the Liberals, "Canada's spare tire."
Charest pronounces himself inflated and road-ready. "What I sense, and what I'm predicting, is that people will regain their taste -- in three, four years from now -- for gathering around a single table, rather than finding themselves in parliaments divided by region."
The trouble is getting through those three or four years without sounding like the Liberals he's criticizing. On CPP reform, he says the Liberals should "at least make a commitment to reduce (employment insurance) premiums by the same amount that they're increasing CPP premiums." The Liberals have made that precise commitment for 1998. Saying, in effect, "they'd better keep it up" is not a cry that stirs the blood.
He wants to offer "a credible alternative." Alternative to what? Often, to whatever he just said. "The latest poll shows us how much Quebecers are tired of referendums," he said. Then, on polls showing him as the best leader for the Quebec Liberals. "Well, polls, you have to take them with a grain of salt." Then, on his tax-cut policy: "Recent polling seems to indicate (Canadians) are coming around to that view."
On unity, he said, "The problem isn't in Quebec City, the problem is in Ottawa." Does that mean Canada is today threatened more gravely by its federalist prime minister than by Quebec's secessionist premier? "I don't measure it in those terms," he said.
But Ottawa must be willing "to undertake changes that everyone in this country, every provincial government, is looking forward to ... . And Mr. Chretien has had a great deal of difficulty doing that. Even when faced, as he was at the premiers' conference, with a clear will ... he has to be dragged along, screaming and kicking."
So a Prime Minister Jean Charest would drop his own position to embrace a consensus among the provinces? "I'm not saying that at all. Not at all. What I'm saying, though, is this. That it's incumbent upon me to come to the table with a plan and some objectives. Not just sit there and improvise, and make it up as you go along, from press conference to press conference."
Jean Charest is against improvising at press conferences. Got it.

Charest still emits charm and fuzzy messages: [Final Edition]

Author: Wells, Paul

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/charest-still-emits-charm-fuzzy-messages/docview/349105204/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Critiquing the Liberals' handling of the run-up to the Kyoto conference on climate change, which he accurately labelled "disastrous," [Jean Charest] tossed around enough green-wonk jargon to re- establish his credentials as the party leader most comfortable with environmental issues. Charest is haunted by those Liberal votes. Somebody once called the Tories, the party voters have turned to when they can't stomach the Liberals, "Canada's spare tire." Charest pronounces himself inflated and road-ready. "What I sense, and what I'm predicting, is that people will regain their taste -- in three, four years from now -- for gathering around a single table, rather than finding themselves in parliaments divided by region." Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Charest+still+emits+charm+and+fuzzy+messages&amp;author=Wells%2C+Paul&amp;issn=08373434&amp;title=The+Standard&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-17&amp;spage=B.7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Jean Charest still draws far more reporters to a press conference, as leader of a party with 20 MPs, than do the leaders of the 44-MP Bloc Quebecois or the 21-MP New Democratic Party. The Ottawa press gallery still cuts the Progressive Conservative leader a little slack. Not much, but some.
Commenting on the parliamentary session just ended and the rest of the mandate ahead, Charest this week showed the charm that remains his greatest asset, and the command of detail that separates him from Prime Minister Jean Chretien and even Reform Leader Preston Manning.
Critiquing the Liberals' handling of the run-up to the Kyoto conference on climate change, which he accurately labelled "disastrous," Charest tossed around enough green-wonk jargon to re- establish his credentials as the party leader most comfortable with environmental issues.
The environment is a manager's portfolio, and Charest is a manager, ironically better at incremental change than at laying out the grand visions he always talks about. He thinks the new Canada Pension Plan investment fund should be open to scrutiny by the auditor general. Excellent idea. Excellent little idea.
As he tries to bring his party back from its 1993 near-death experience, Charest must decide every day whose votes to chase: the Liberals' or the Reformers'. Given his druthers, of course, he'd rather have them both, but that's not always possible.
You can make a good argument either for heading right or for hugging the centre. On one hand, Canadians aren't used to having two big parties to the right of the Liberals, and may regard that as an unnatural state of affairs. A Tory haunted by this will go after Reform voters. On the other hand, most Liberal voters' second choice is the Conservatives. A Tory haunted by this will go after Liberals.
Charest is haunted by those Liberal votes. Somebody once called the Tories, the party voters have turned to when they can't stomach the Liberals, "Canada's spare tire." Charest pronounces himself inflated and road-ready. "What I sense, and what I'm predicting, is that people will regain their taste -- in three, four years from now -- for gathering around a single table, rather than finding themselves in parliaments divided by region."
The trouble is getting through those three or four years without sounding like the Liberals he's criticizing. On CPP reform, he says the Liberals should "at least make a commitment to reduce (employment insurance) premiums by the same amount that they're increasing CPP premiums." The Liberals have made that precise commitment for 1998. Saying, in effect, "they'd better keep it up" is not a cry that stirs the blood.
He wants to offer "a credible alternative." Alternative to what? Often, to whatever he just said. "The latest poll shows us how much Quebecers are tired of referendums," he said. Then, on polls showing him as the best leader for the Quebec Liberals. "Well, polls, you have to take them with a grain of salt." Then, on his tax-cut policy: "Recent polling seems to indicate (Canadians) are coming around to that view."
On unity, he said, "the problem isn't in Quebec City, the problem is in Ottawa." Does that mean Canada is today threatened more gravely by its federalist prime minister than by Quebec's secessionist premier?
"I don't measure it in those terms," he said. But Ottawa must be willing "to undertake changes that everyone in this country, every provincial government, is looking forward to... And Mr. Chretien has had a great deal of difficulty doing that. Even when faced, as he was at the premiers conference, with a clear will... he has to be dragged along, screaming and kicking."
So a Prime Minister Jean Charest would drop his own position to embrace a consensus among the provinces?
"I'm not saying that at all. Not at all. What I'm saying, though, is this. That it's incumbent upon me to come to the table with a plan and some objectives. Not just sit there and improvise, and make it up as you go along, from press conference to press conference."
Jean Charest is against improvising at press conferences. Got it.

Man's greed fuels global bonfire The breakdown of the rule of law has helped make 1997 the worst ever year for sending forests up in smoke. Paul Brown reports

Author: Brown, Paul

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/mans-greed-fuels-global-bonfire-breakdown-rule/docview/245199981/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: FOREST fires deliberately lit by man in many parts of the world have made 1997 the worst year in recorded history for destruction of the natural environment, a report released yesterday says. The biggest and most numerous fires were in Brazil, where they raged along a 10,000-mile front, and still burn. Second came Indonesia, where months of smog put 40,000 people in hospital. But Papua New Guinea, Colombia, Africa, Australia and southern Europe have had large areas devastated, too. Greece, Spain, Italy and France have all suffered, according to the World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) report, entitled The Year the Earth Caught Fire.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Man%27s+greed+fuels+global+bonfire+The+breakdown+of+the+rule+of+law+has+helped+make+1997+the+worst+ever+year+for+sending+forests+up+in+smoke.+Paul+Brown+reports&amp;author=Brown%2C+Paul&amp;issn=02613077&amp;title=The+Guardian&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-17&amp;spage=013&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: FOREST fires deliberately lit by man in many parts of the world have made 1997 the worst year in recorded history for destruction of the natural environment, a report released yesterday says.
The biggest and most numerous fires were in Brazil, where they raged along a 10,000-mile front, and still burn. Second came Indonesia, where months of smog put 40,000 people in hospital.
But Papua New Guinea, Colombia, Africa, Australia and southern Europe have had large areas devastated, too. Greece, Spain, Italy and France have all suffered, according to the World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) report, entitled The Year the Earth Caught Fire.
Although the droughts in the Amazon and South-east Asia caused by the change in monsoon patterns brought about by the strong El Nino in the Pacific are partially to blame, human greed is the main cause.
The breakdown of law and order in many countries has escalated the destruction. Although some countries, including Indonesia, claim that lighting fires is banned, much of the damage there is on government-funded projects.
Forest fires have always been a hazard of lightning during hot periods or drought, and in some cases they help the environment by creating clearings and healthy regeneration, the report says. But the risks are increased by human activities such as selective logging, drainage and pollution-related climate change.
Most accidental fires result from losing control of fires started for land clearance, charcoal burning and cooking. Some begin from transport and dropped cigarettes. But this year the main causes have been land clearance for farms or plantations, timber speculation, insurance crime and even vandalism.
"The widespread breakdown of the rule of law is a critical factor in fire abuse," the report says.
The data are backed by satellite information analysed by the Woods Hole Institute in the United States and Edinburgh University.
Researchers agree the destruction is continuing. Some peat fires in Indonesia are expected to burn for years. Although damped by rains, they are likely to break out again in the dry season. Some fires have been burning since 1983.
Claude Martin, director-general of WWF, said: "These fires were not an act of God. They were deliberately set, as they have been for many years, to clear forest for other purposes, and sometimes to cover up for timber poaching and land theft.
"It is also increasingly clear that the guilty parties are not just small farmers, as has been assumed, but that most of the damage is being done by plantation and timber companies. This is not just an emergency, it is a planetary disaster."
Barita Manullane, from Indonesia, where 5 million acres of forest have been lost this year, said government-sponsored rice-growing projects were chiefly to blame.
He is in charge of a project to save the orang-utan, and said the swamp forests where they survive were being drained and deliberately burned, even though it was, in his view, impossible to grow rice there.
"The peat has now caught fire and, despite the rains coming, burns on. I cannot see how they can ever put them out. Many of the animals are dead or driven from the trees by the haze."
Fires in Brazil have increased by 50 per cent on last year. Loggers, cattle farmers and peasants have taken advantage of the dry season to clear land. An average 599 new fires a day were reported, making 24,549 fires in a period of 41 days. Many fires are still burning.
In Brazil's Atlantic rain forest one of the rarest mammals in the world, the golden lion tamarind, is threatened by deliberate burning.
In Colombia there have been 7,000 forest fires, including 37 in protected areas, and 40,000 acres of national parks have been burned. Nearly all the fires were believed to have been started by man.
Papua New Guinea is suffering its worst drought for 50 years, and speculators have burned thousands of square miles of forest and grassland, leaving millions on the edge of starvation. An international relief effort is under way but loss of vegetation is expected to affect the climate adversely.
Most recently, Australia has suffered forest and scrub fires, which have penetrated the suburbs of Sydney.
Kenya's famous Imenti Forest around Mount Kenya has been burned by illegal settlers as bribed forest officials turn a blind eye. Tanzania, Senegal and the Congo have had large forest fires.
Rwanda's relic cloud forest was threatened in the Nyungwe Montane Forest Reserve, where several square miles were left burning for weeks with no attempt to put them out.
Michael Tene, an attache at the Indonesian embassy in London, said: "We regret the fires which we are trying to stop, but we do not have the means. We are not a stupid people. We want the forest but at the same time we have to feed 200 million people and so we need rice, too."

Subject: Forest & brush fires; Environmental impact; Social conditions & trends

Waiting on Warming

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/waiting-on-warming/docview/288812585/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: The global warming agreement that came out of Kyoto last week is still a work in progress. Therefore, it cannot be categorized either as the environmental triumph that the Clinton-Gore team would like or the grave threat to the American economy that its opponents fear. Rather, without the signature of the United States, it is essentially a framework that will shape a national discussion the next 16 months (the treaty would have to be signed by March 1999). And that is perhaps the most positive outcome of the Kyoto conference: It has put global warming in the mainstream consciousness, beyond the hyperbole of the two extremes.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Waiting+on+Warming&amp;author=&amp;issn=07463502&amp;title=The+Salt+Lake+Tribune&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-14&amp;spage=AA.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The global warming agreement that came out of Kyoto last week is still a work in progress. Therefore, it cannot be categorized either as the environmental triumph that the Clinton-Gore team would like or the grave threat to the American economy that its opponents fear.
Rather, without the signature of the United States, it is essentially a framework that will shape a national discussion the next 16 months (the treaty would have to be signed by March 1999). And that is perhaps the most positive outcome of the Kyoto conference: It has put global warming in the mainstream consciousness, beyond the hyperbole of the two extremes.
Going into the conference, President Clinton had set two central planks in America's position: a reduction of greenhouse gases to 1990 levels by around 2010 and a commitment to emissions reductions by developing countries. He came away with neither.
At the nudging of Vice President Gore, the United States agreed to a 7 percent emissions cut from 1990 levels, which actually equates to more than a 35 percent cut from what Americans' emissions are projected to be in 2010. And, while giving in to greater emissions cuts, the United States still didn't get the commitment from developing countries that the Senate, by a 95-0 vote, had insisted upon in July.
So Clinton and Gore know that the Kyoto protocol would be dead on arrival at the Senate, which is why they are wise not to send it there yet. Instead, they will try to get developing countries to agree to emissions limits between now and next November, when a follow-up conference is scheduled for Buenos Aires. That is as it should be; in 1996 numbers, China is already the world's second largest carbon emitter (albeit not, of course, on a per capita basis), and it ought not be exempt from global climate-change efforts.
Clearly, until that issue is resolved, this is not an agreement to which the United States will become a signatory. But it is an issue in which Americans will now be clearly engaged -- with all of the accompanying questions regarding their unfettered burning of fossil fuels for energy and transportation.
Assuming Clinton will not send the protocol to the Senate until after the Buenos Aires conference, Americans have a year to decide, as The Economist frames the issue, how much insurance they want to take out against the risk of global warming. The phenomenon exists, but the consequences are uncertain. Yet those are circumstances in which many Americans will still lean toward caution; in fact, a recent New York Times poll indicates that Americans are more willing to protect against global warming than skeptics think.
They will have to think about it more now, as Clinton is sure to engage them on it in 1998. Indeed, by compromising to keep the Kyoto conference from collapsing, the administration has permitted the domestic debate to get serious. And the future of the planet is, after all, a serious matter.

Title: Waiting on Warming

Publication title: The Salt Lake Tribune; Salt Lake City, Utah

Pages: AA1

Number of pages: 0

Section: Opinion

Publisher: The Salt Lake Tribune

9 provinces to talk social policy Bouchard sees negotiations as Ottawa stepping on other governments' turf

Author: Fraser, Graham; Seguin, Rheal

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/9-provinces-talk-social-policy-bouchard-sees/docview/384735643/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: "It's so obvious. It's so symbolic," Mr. [Lucien Bouchard] said after the meeting. ". . . For the first time in the history of this country, all of the provinces, Quebec excepted, and the federal government are on the eve of concluding an agreement according to which the federal government would be allowed to step into all the jurisdictions of the provinces, despite the Constitution."

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=9+provinces+to+talk+social+policy+Bouchard+sees+negotiations+as+Ottawa+stepping+on+other+governments%27+turf&amp;author=Fraser%2C+Graham%3BSeguin%2C+Rheal&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-13&amp;spage=A.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Bouchard sees negotiations as Ottawa stepping on other governments' turf
9 provinces to talk social policy
Bouchard sees negotiations as Ottawa stepping on other governments' turf
Saturday, December 13, 1997
The Globe and Mail
OTTAWA -- Ottawa and nine provinces have agreed on a new consultative process for social policy -- but immediately ran into significant disagreements on how it should be interpreted.
Quebec Premier Lucien Bouchard made it clear that he was not part of the consensus, however it should be interpreted.
"It's so obvious. It's so symbolic," Mr. Bouchard said after the meeting. ". . . For the first time in the history of this country, all of the provinces, Quebec excepted, and the federal government are on the eve of concluding an agreement according to which the federal government would be allowed to step into all the jurisdictions of the provinces, despite the Constitution."
Prime Minister Jean Chrétien and the nine other premiers agreed to start negotiating a framework agreement for Canada's social union, which they said would apply to federal, provincial and territorial governments "while respecting each other's constitutional jurisdiction and powers."
The issues to be negotiated include:
A set of principles for social policy;
What the leaders called "collaborative approaches" to the federal government's use of spending power;
Clarification of the ground rules for intergovernmental co-operation;
Identification of ways to clarify the roles and responsibilities of the different levels of government within different social-policy areas.
However, the most controversial area, which provoked immediately contradictory interpretations, was the agreement to discuss "appropriate dispute-settlement mechanisms between governments."
Several premiers made it clear that, if a dispute-settlement mechanism was agreed upon, it would apply to one of the thorniest issues of conflict: the federal government's enforcement of the Canada Health Act.
That act lays out the key principles of government-run health insurance, including accessibility and universality, which prohibit provinces from allowing doctors to charge extra fees or creating a private medical system. When provinces have challenged this, the federal government has deducted money from their health transfers.
Provincial leaders were delighted that the federal government agreed to study a dispute-mechanism process. "I think it was a very good conference," Alberta Premier Ralph Klein said.
Mr. Klein said he was particularly pleased at the agreement to enter into a framework to achieve social-policy renewal, "including something that we've been after for a long time and that is to set up a mechanism for dispute resolution."
However, while some provincial officials crowed that the federal government had agreed to discuss the Canada Health Act, federal ministers immediately sent out a contradictory message.
Mr. Chrétien stressed that the federal government wants to discuss the issue with the provinces, but that the Canada Health Act remains a federal law. "If somebody breaks the law, the federal government will be the government that enforces the law," he said.
In the same vein, Health Minister Allan Rock said that the Canada Health Act remains a key priority. "I think Canadians want a federal government that has the authority that ensures that the [Canada Health] Act is being respected from coast to coast to coast," said Mr. Rock. "We intend to fulfill that role."
But the premiers took a different view. "Absolutely, it is [up] for discussion," said British Columbia Premier Glen Clark. "It is on the table for discussion."
Manitoba Premier Gary Filmon and Saskatchewan Premier Roy Romanow both agreed that the principles of the Canada Health Act had not been challenged, but argued that its enforcement would be discussed as part of the negotiations over functions of the dispute-settlement mechanism.
Newfoundland Premier Brian Tobin argued that there was a misunderstanding that suggested there had been disagreement.
"Something incredible happened today," he said. He said there was unanimity among the premiers, including Mr. Bouchard, in recognizing that Canadians feel there is stress in the medical system, a danger of a two-tier system, and in giving a unanimous message to the Prime Minister that the health system is hurting and reinvestment is necessary.
Despite -- or perhaps because of -- the differing interpretations, both Mr. Chrétien and Mr. Klein were positive about the tone of the meeting.
"This was a typical Canadian meeting," Mr. Chrétien said. "No great flash, no fireworks, just solid progress."
He praised what he called the mood of partnership, adding: "There is no bad news to report."
Mr. Klein struck the same note. "You know, the Prime Minister was in a real listening mood," he said. "Now he's going to have the challenge of taking some of these resolutions back to his caucus and getting concurrence there, but I think the messages were very strong -- certainly the message of co-operative federalism."
At the meeting, Mr. Bouchard presented a proposal that the provinces be given the right to opt out of any social program "susceptible to having an impact in a field of provincial jurisdiction," with full financial compensation. He also wanted a federal moratorium on any such programs, and the agreement that a whole range of federal initiatives, from the improvement of the national child benefit to the Canada student-loans program, be postponed.
After the meeting, Mr. Bouchard complained that Mr. Chrétien had dismissed his proposal out of hand. "This is a move towards a very centralized government with provinces having no powers, no responsibilities, but to accept what the federal government will decide in terms of programs and funding," the Quebec Premier said.
Mr. Clark made it clear he disagreed with Mr. Bouchard's interpretation. "In fact, the purpose of the framework agreement is to stop the federal government from unilateral action in provincial jurisdiction, but to work together to set national standards as opposed to federal standards," he said.
In addition to the agreement to discuss a framework for Canada's social union, Ottawa and nine premiers reaffirmed their commitment to launch a national child-benefit system by July 1, a national children's agenda, a framework for co-operation on policies dealing with the disabled and a youth-employment action plan, and to make the issue of youth employment a national priority.
All of the leaders, including Mr. Bouchard, agreed on the importance of attacking the problem of student debt, and agreed that Finance Minister Paul Martin and Human Resources Development Minister Pierre Pettigrew should consult with provincial education ministers so that Mr. Martin can address the problem in his next budget.
There was also unanimous agreement on a consultative process on climate change that will look at the consequences of the Kyoto protocol before it is ratified.

  

The issues to be negotiated include:
A set of principles for social policy;
What the leaders called "collaborative approaches" to the federal government's use of spending power;
Clarification of the ground rules for intergovernmental co-operation;
Identification of ways to clarify the roles and responsibilities of the different levels of government within different social-policy areas.
However, the most controversial area, which provoked immediately contradictory interpretations, was the agreement to discuss "appropriate dispute-settlement mechanisms between governments."

He also wanted a federal moratorium on any such programs, and the agreement that a whole range of federal initiatives, from the improvement of the national child benefit to the Canada student-loans program, be postponed.
After the meeting, Mr. Bouchard complained that Mr. Chrétien had dismissed his proposal out of hand. "This is a move towards a very centralized government with provinces having no powers, no responsibilities, but to accept what the federal government will decide in terms of programs and funding," the Quebec Premier said.
In addition to the agreement to discuss a framework for Canada's social union, Ottawa and nine premiers reaffirmed their commitment to launch a national child-benefit system by July 1, a national children's agenda, a framework for co-operation on policies dealing with the disabled and a youth-employment action plan, and to make the issue of youth employment a national priority.
All of the leaders, including Mr. Bouchard, agreed on the importance of attacking the problem of student debt, and agreed that Finance Minister Paul Martin and Human Resources Development Minister Pierre Pettigrew should consult with provincial education ministers so that Mr. Martin can address the problem in his next budget.
There was also unanimous agreement on a consultative process on climate change that will look at the consequences of the Kyoto protocol before it is ratified.

And now that all the talking is over ...;: [Late Edition]

Author: Hogarth, Murray

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/now-that-all-talking-is-over/docview/363465425/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: EARLY yesterday morning the world's top environmental campaigners on climate change were out on the town in Kyoto, drinking and dancing to the tune of a new world order.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=And+now+that+all+the+talking+is+over+...%3B&amp;author=Hogarth%2C+Murray&amp;issn=03126315&amp;title=Sydney+Morning+Herald&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-13&amp;spage=35&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: EARLY yesterday morning the world's top environmental campaigners on climate change were out on the town in Kyoto, drinking and dancing to the tune of a new world order.
As they progressed from the Pig and Whistle British-style pub, to the seedy Bar Isn't It?, to the tiny Bar Six-and-a-Half, they outlined their view of what comes after the climate change treaty.
In Australia, America and around the world there will be massive attention paid to the implications of implementing a global reduction of the greenhouse gas pollutants that cause global warming. These will include harm to fossil fuel industries, especially coal, of which Australia has 100 billion tonnes still to be dug up.
But domestic laws to make vehicles more fuel-efficient can reduce dependency on oil imports, and promote natural gas use - of which Australia also has a lot.
And less greenhouse gas emission from vehicles has the double benefit of less air pollution in cities.
Building codes will demand greater energy efficiency to save on emissions from power generation, but this also means financial savings.
Huge impetus will be added to the development of solar and other renewable energy technologies such as wind. And institutional investors such as the giant insurance companies will increasingly judge the environmental soundness and technologies of companies in their portfolios.
Stopping the bulldozers and tree-poisoners in the Australian bush can bring great reductions of carbon dioxide, the chief villain among the six greenhouse gases.
All this is happening already and will speed up. But the treaty itself is unlikely to be fully enforced for about four years. It requires progress on cutting emissions by 2005 and cuts from most nations by 2012.
Some form of carbon tax to drive trading of emissions within countries and internationally is likely, because this would allow the free market to drive sometimes costly and unpopular changes to the way people live, rather than politicians.
Australia, controversially to many, is allowed to increase by 8 per cent of the 1990 baseline.
The fairness of this may face challenges later, and may bring pressure for Australia to do more as leaders in countries such as the United States and Canada struggle to explain to voters why they have to accept much harder targets than Australians.
One concern is that in a world where clean energy is king, Australia will not be under enough pressure to improve its technology.

Slow but steady progress made on environmental issues The outcome of the Climate Change Summit was a small but significant step for mankind, writes Frank McDonald in Kyoto: [CITY EDITION]

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/slow-steady-progress-made-on-environmental-issues/docview/310367184/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: On the face of it, the target for greenhouse gas reductions agreed in Kyoto this week seem paltry, even pathetic. But the really important thing about the world's first treaty on climate change is that it moves the whole process decisively in the right direction. They had come to Kyoto offering little (Japan) or nothing (the US). But by the time they left after the final round of all-night negotiations both countries had agreed to the Protocol and pledged to cut the greenhouse gas emissions. The EU had won considerable kudos by offering to reduce its overall emissions by 15 per cent on 1990 levels by the year 2010. But it was clear from the outset that its major industrial competitors were never going to come close to matching this ambitious target. A diplomatic compromise was inevitable. In the end, the figures agreed in their tripartite talks worked out at 8 per cent for the EU, 7 per cent for the US and 6 per cent for Japan, all to be achieved over a four-year period from 2008 to 2012. The industrialised world as a whole also signed up to an overall cut of 5.2 per cent.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Slow+but+steady+progress+made+on+environmental+issues+The+outcome+of+the+Climate+Change+Summit+was+a+small+but+significant+step+for+mankind%2C+writes+Frank+McDonald+in+Kyoto&amp;author=&amp;issn=&amp;title=Irish+Times&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-13&amp;spage=11&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: On the face of it, the target for greenhouse gas reductions agreed in Kyoto this week seem paltry, even pathetic. But the really important thing about the world's first treaty on climate change is that it moves the whole process decisively in the right direction.
Extracting the required concessions from some of the participating countries, notably the United States and Japan, was not unlike a long-drawn-out dental appointment, with a lot of pain and even some blood on the floor, though the European Union proved to be quite a good dentist.
They had come to Kyoto offering little (Japan) or nothing (the US). But by the time they left after the final round of all-night negotiations both countries had agreed to the Protocol and pledged to cut the greenhouse gas emissions.
The EU had won considerable kudos by offering to reduce its overall emissions by 15 per cent on 1990 levels by the year 2010. But it was clear from the outset that its major industrial competitors were never going to come close to matching this ambitious target. A diplomatic compromise was inevitable. In the end, the figures agreed in their tripartite talks worked out at 8 per cent for the EU, 7 per cent for the US and 6 per cent for Japan, all to be achieved over a four-year period from 2008 to 2012. The industrialised world as a whole also signed up to an overall cut of 5.2 per cent.
The US is livid that one of its key conditions, "meaningful participation" by key developing countries, had to be dropped in the face of implacable opposition from China and India. Indeed, only the fear of being blamed for a failure in Kyoto kept the Clinton administration on board.
The G77 Group, which represents 136 developing countries, insisted that the industrialised nations must be the first to take action on the issue, since it was their emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases which had caused the problem of climate change in the first place. At stake was the issue of "global equity" as G77 sees it. Though emissions from China, India and other major developing countries are rising fast and will ultimately outstrip those from the industrialised world, they remain very low on a per-capita basis, by factors of up to 20 to one.
The US, with only 5 per cent of the world's population, is the biggest emitter of carbon dioxide, accounting for nearly 25 per cent of the global total. If it did not agree to make real cuts, there would be no chance whatsoever of persuading the developing world to sign up, even on a voluntary basis. President Clinton was kept under relentless pressure by the mis-named Global Climate Coalition (GCC), which primarily represents US oil, coal and motor manufacturing interests. It set out to ensure that the Kyoto summit would end in failure or, at least, in the realm of meaningless declarations.
The Exxon Oil Company, one of the GCC's leading members, was to the fore in pressing the US administration to insist that the developing countries were stitched into any deal in Kyoto. At the same time, it was calling on them to increase their own consumption of oil to promote economic growth. By far the most hysterical statement issued during the 10-day summit came from the GCC itself. It claimed that the agreement amounted to "unilateral economic disarmament" by the US that would throw three million Americans on to the dole queue and cost the economy $150 billion a year.
Such assertions are regarded as quite outlandish by environmental groups and by the European Union.
Of course, because the Kyoto summit decided on lower greenhouse gas reduction targets, the EU's famous "bubble" will have to be renegotiated. But the danger here is that its 15 member-states, including Ireland, would be allocated lower targets, thus undermining Europe's high moral ground. This would be a great mistake, not least because of the message it would send the key developing countries such as China. Mr John Prescott, Britain's Deputy Prime Minister, has already reaffirmed its intention of sticking by its original targets and there is no reason why Ireland can't do the same. There are all sorts of "win-win" measures which can be taken to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, such as serious energy conservation, investment in alternative energy sources, more fuel efficient vehicles and most of all the imposition of a "carbon tax' to shift the burden from PRSI.
Internationally, the primary task between now and the fourth Climate Change Summit in Beunos Aires next November will be to iron out the details of such US-inspired initiatives as "emissions trading" to ensure that these are not used to avoid action to curb greenhouse gases on the home front. As for those who discount the whole thesis of climate change, the meteorological data for Kyoto tell their own story. A century ago, the city had 100 days of frost every winter; now it has 15 and there are still roses in full bloom and bright red leaves on the Japanese maples in mid-December.
In November one of the world's leading insurance companies, Munich Re, warned that the potential losses from an extreme natural catastrophe affecting one of the planet's major cities or industrial centres might "bring about the collapse of the world's financial markets".
The most memorable speech at the Kyoto summit was delivered by Mr Kinza Clodumar, president of the Polynesian Republic of Nauru. Like other low-lying small island states, Nauru is threatened with extinction, and its President talked movingly about how his people were now "trapped" between an interior devastated by colonial phosphate mining and the prospect of "a terrifying flood of biblical proportions" due to rising sea levels. "The wilful destruction of entire countries and cultures with foreknowledge would represent an unspeakable crime against humanity," he declared. "No nation has the right to place its own misconstrued national interest before the physical and cultural survival of whole countries."
In this context, the Kyoto Protocol may be seen as a squalid formulation of the lowest common denominator. But at least it indicates that world leaders are at last prepared to face up to the powerful fossil-fuel lobby and start dealing with this truly overwhelming environmental issue.

The City Column: Warming to the prospect of global greening

Author: Buckingham, Lisa

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/city-column-warming-prospect-global-greening/docview/245204897/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Never mind that it took a sideswipe from the Deputy Prime Minister, John Prescott, to spur the IPE into action. And never mind that the IPE could be pushed aside by US markets, which already have experience of trading emissions permits. At least the exchange is interested and is preparing to tell the Government how it would operate such a market. The prospects range from financing environmental industries to reporting on green performance. They affect just about every City institution and activity from corporate finance to equity analysis, risk management and investment. So far, institutions have tended to react only to green threats, rather than opportunities. Thus the insurance industry is more advanced than most on environmental issues because it stands to lose out from unusual weather and climatic catastrophes. In other sectors it has proved difficult to raise enthusiasm. Accountants have tried to develop environmental reporting but,in the absence of any statutory requirement, this has had limited success. Analysts have been reluctant to factor in liabilities from problems such as contaminated land to their assessments of share prices, mainly because of the time scales involved in such liabilities. And they have been sceptical about the potential for green products and processes because of doubts about the sustainability, as it were, of consumer interest and the seriousness of governments' positions.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=The+City+Column%3A+Warming+to+the+prospect+of+global+greening&amp;author=Buckingham%2C+Lisa&amp;issn=02613077&amp;title=The+Guardian&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-13&amp;spage=025&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: AT LEAST one part of the City seems to have finally awakened to the environmental challenge, with the International Petroleum Exchange saying that it is interested in running a market for tradeable pollution permits.
Never mind that it took a sideswipe from the Deputy Prime Minister, John Prescott, to spur the IPE into action. And never mind that the IPE could be pushed aside by US markets, which already have experience of trading emissions permits. At least the exchange is interested and is preparing to tell the Government how it would operate such a market.
The question is how long it will take the rest of the City to catch on to the many green opportunities arising from Kyoto and elsewhere.
The prospects range from financing environmental industries to reporting on green performance. They affect just about every City institution and activity from corporate finance to equity analysis, risk management and investment. So far, institutions have tended to react only to green threats, rather than opportunities. Thus the insurance industry is more advanced than most on environmental issues because it stands to lose out from unusual weather and climatic catastrophes.
In other sectors it has proved difficult to raise enthusiasm. Accountants have tried to develop environmental reporting but,in the absence of any statutory requirement, this has had limited success. Analysts have been reluctant to factor in liabilities from problems such as contaminated land to their assessments of share prices, mainly because of the time scales involved in such liabilities. And they have been sceptical about the potential for green products and processes because of doubts about the sustainability, as it were, of consumer interest and the seriousness of governments' positions.
Beyond the City, the business world has been less sceptical, although action has tended to be concentrated in a handful of leading companies, such as B&Q.
Prompted by the last green summit in Rio de Janeiro in 1992, many companies have now begun to understand their environmental impact and the opportunities, as well as dangers, which might emerge from action to combat climate change and resource wastefulness. It is to be hoped Kyoto will have the same effect on financial institutions as Rio had on industrial and commercial businesses.
Cheap frills ironed out in share options
THE attempt by the Institute of Directors to flaunt the modesty of its members' pay rises served again to draw attention to the importance of lucrative frills in addition to their basic packages.
So it is heartening to learn from pay expert David Tankel of New Bridge Street Consultants that the option plan for employees, which supermarkets group Safeway is installing, seemslikely to be adopted much more widely.
Mr Tankel, who advises many FTSE-listed companies, says all-employee options will continue to spread, acting as mechanisms to reward individual performance, enhance employee share-ownership in Britain and overseas or to mark a corporate milestone.
Now Safeway, again tipped as being in the line of predatory fire, may have its own reasons for trying to shore up employee loyalty. It may also believe that introducing options that depend on improving "customer care" will offer longer-term protection if speculation evaporates.
The supermarkets group is not the first to introduce executive-style options on the shop floor. Asda, which will next week report profits of pounds 180 million and is seen as having a rekindled interest in Safeway, rewarded staff with options as part of Archie Norman's transformation of the company.
Other proponents include Glaxo Wellcome, the drugs group, Abbey National and advertising agency WPP.
But Mr Tankel comments: "Safeway's plan is innovative because it emphasises and supports the company's focus on customer-care performance. Given the imminent demise of tax relief for profit-related pay, this approach may well have wider applications."
Although all full-time staff were given options to launch the plan, future awards will rely on the annual customer-care performance of the store in which they work.
"Employees will be rewarded directly for their efforts as well as focusing on the group's share-price performance after the options are granted. Because options normally lapse if employees leave, the plan should help to reduce staff turnover levels," says Mr Tankel.
Options have the same advantages for staff as for the board. People do not have to save to amass them as with share-save schemes, which also have little appeal for overseas workers. Options are easier to administer, and if there are problems in giving shares to workers abroad, phantom options can be used, the profits from which can be given as a bonus.
As Mr Tankel points out, one drawback is that options can be exercised only once every three years. This, he says, made sense when options worth four times salary could be awarded, but is less convincing now the maximim grant is pounds 30,000.
The Employee Share Ownership Centre and Proshare have already started to lobby the Government for greater flexibility. Options could start to compensate for the chasm between the top and the bottom of businesses' reward structures.
How to stop the chips going down
AS IF the substantially underestimated impact on stock markets from the Asian economic meltdown were not bad enough for investors, the potentially horrendous consequences stemming from the computer "millennium bug" are adding to an air of potentially fatal unreality.
Some of the largest fund managers are beginning to wonder out loud whether the companies in which they invest are taking these enormous risks seriously enough.
And an atmosphere of panic is beginning to develop as headhunters engulf anyone with the technology skills necessary to protect computer systems from the crash that threatens when the midnight hour passes in two years' time.
But now, the Institute of Chartered Accountants has published proposals that could alleviate some of the mystery. The ICA wants companies to include statements of "business risk", which would identify important problem areas, such as the possibility of the closure of an entire operation because of a computer failure, and describe action being taken to manage those risks. Importantly, the accountants want companies to include the potential for gain, rather than just the exposure to loss.
The Securities and Exchange Commission in the US has already released its requirements for the disclosure of risks relating to the millennium problem and the Accounting Standards Board is expected to publish recommendations early in the New Year about how British firms should treat the costs associated with upgrading their computer systems.
Rightly, though, the accountants say the thirst for knowledge about companies' exposure to risks, which might also include environmental issues (see above) and ethical sourcing, should not be limited only to the cash implications.
The Guardian is planning to launch a column which will hold utility firms and monopoly businesses to account on the behalf of consumers. If you would like issues addressed or complaints answered, please write to Celia Weston, City Complaints Desk, The Guardian, 119, Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.
Additional reporting by Roger Cowe

____________________________________________________________

Big U.S. Industries Launch Attack on Warming Treaty --- Big Three Auto Companies, Steelmakers, Utilities Are Leading the Charge

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/big-u-s-industries-launch-attack-on-warming/docview/398602555/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Auto companies, utilities and steel manufacturers all forecast dire consequences if the agreement, reached in marathon negotiations in Kyoto, Japan, is put into effect. Even the reaction from the insurance industry, which has looked more favorably on the idea of a global-warming treaty in the past, was lukewarm. The response isn't a surprise; many of the sentiments expressed have been voiced repeatedly. And both government officials and environmental groups discount some of the industry complaints, maintaining that U.S. businesses could make the kinds of reductions in greenhouse gases the treaty envisions through better use of new environmentally friendly technologies. Under the agreement reached in Kyoto, the U.S. would commit to reduce the amount of greenhouse gases it emits to a level 7% below its 1990 emissions. The goal would have to be reached between the years 2008 and 2012. The European Union would pledge to cut its emissions by 8%, Japan by 6%.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Big+U.S.+Industries+Launch+Attack+on+Warming+Treaty+---+Big+Three+Auto+Companies%2C+Steelmakers%2C+Utilities+Are+Leading+the+Charge&amp;author=&amp;issn=00999660&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-12&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Promptly and predictably, some of the biggest players in American industry have come out swinging against the proposed new treaty to limit global warming.
Auto companies, utilities and steel manufacturers all forecast dire consequences if the agreement, reached in marathon negotiations in Kyoto, Japan, is put into effect. Even the reaction from the insurance industry, which has looked more favorably on the idea of a global-warming treaty in the past, was lukewarm.
The response isn't a surprise; many of the sentiments expressed have been voiced repeatedly. And both government officials and environmental groups discount some of the industry complaints, maintaining that U.S. businesses could make the kinds of reductions in greenhouse gases the treaty envisions through better use of new environmentally friendly technologies.
But the immediate reaction from the business community gives some sense of the obstacles the Clinton administration faces in trying to win Senate ratification of the agreement -- and of the kind of support Republican congressional leaders can expect if they try to block the deal.
Under the agreement reached in Kyoto, the U.S. would commit to reduce the amount of greenhouse gases it emits to a level 7% below its 1990 emissions. The goal would have to be reached between the years 2008 and 2012. The European Union would pledge to cut its emissions by 8%, Japan by 6%.
Greenhouse gases are produced in large measure by the burning of fossil fuels such as coal and oil, which means that utilities, cars and coal-burning manufacturing plants all would be sources of the reductions. U.S. auto makers, who feel they have as much at stake as anybody in the global-warming debate, were sharply critical of the agreement.
"For months, we have urged the administration not to bind this country to reductions of greenhouse-gas emissions with arbitrary deadlines," Chrysler Corp. Chairman Robert J. Eaton said. "Innovation and invention don't often come with dates certain. The administration chose to do that anyway."
Ford Motor Co. Chairman Alex Trotman denounced the treaty and, like other business leaders, was particularly critical of the fact that it doesn't demand specific reductions of greenhouse gases by developing countries. "Since the protocol has targets for developed nations but no commitment from developing nations, it won't work," he said.
What the industry fears is that the pact's emissions standards will force the creation of more-stringent U.S. fuel-economy requirements to reduce gasoline use. That is a problem, because such requirements would essentially call for the production of more small cars, which aren't as popular with American car buyers or as profitable for auto makers as bigger, heavier-polluting pickups, sport-utility vehicles and vans.
"If they put a deadline on new technology development, it could force us to use what [technology] we have and balance the rest of our vehicle fleets with small cars," a Chrysler spokeswoman said. And John Middlebrook, the head of General Motors Corp.'s Chevrolet division, said he sees little consumer demand for smaller cars that emit less pollution. "With gasoline prices where they are in this country today, people are just not driven to buy fuel-efficient products," he said.
Similarly, representatives of the U.S. steel industry said the agreement would be what one called "a huge economic blunder" that would result in "monumental" costs to their industry.
Andrew Sharkey, president of the American Iron and Steel Institute, the industry's main trade association, said the pact would benefit "rival steel industries in developing nations that have refused to participate [in reducing emissions], such as China, India and South Korea." Mr. Sharkey said the pact would "devastate" the U.S. steel industry without reducing world-wide energy-related emissions, because steel production would be shifted to other nations.
The nation's largest steelmaker, the U.S. Steel Group of USX Corp., echoed that position, with a spokesman saying, "We would oppose any agreement that doesn't include developing nations, as that would put us in a competitive disadvantage."
Aluminum companies also were critical. A spokesman for Kaiser Aluminum Corp., which is 63%-controlled by Maxxam Inc., said passage of such a treaty would hurt its ability to compete against foreign producers. "Another concern is whether the assumptions underlying the treaty are well founded in science," he said.
The treaty left oil companies, often looked to as a main culprit in greenhouse-gas emissions, hoping the president would "keep his word" and not pass the treaty on to the Senate. "He's on the record as saying he won't approve it if important criteria involving developing countries and potential adverse effects on the economy aren't met," said Red Cavaney, president of the American Petroleum Institute. The administration said yesterday it wouldn't send the treaty to the Senate until after a follow-up summit in Buenos Aires in November 1998.
Mr. Cavaney noted that any treaty approved without those criteria could force oil companies, as well as other industries with high energy costs, to move plants and jobs to countries not laboring under emissions-reduction requirements.
He also said the industry is concerned about unrealistic expectations on the technology front. "From an oil perspective, the technology is neither known nor available to provide and satisfy the current energy demand and get the kind of reductions that are being discussed." He said the treaty in its current form will force the government either to step in and ration energy, "which means less energy for everyone," or "dramatically and artificially" raise prices through taxes.
In the utility industry and elsewhere, some leaders urged the Clinton administration to rely more heavily on voluntary programs to reduce greenhouse gases rather than move toward the mandatory reductions envisioned by the Kyoto pact.
"We're very concerned about this," said W. Robert Woodall, vice president of environmental policy for Atlanta-based Southern Co. "We're the largest coal-fired producer of electricity in the country. We have already made plans to reduce emissions with voluntary programs. We had high hopes for the voluntary programs." With 75% of its power generated by coalfired plants, Southern could be severely hurt by the proposed treaty, he said.
Similarly, Thomas Kuhn, president of the Washington-based Edison Electric Institute, called the agreement "economic suicide." He said it would cost electricity utilities that have coal-fired generating facilities as much as $30 billion by some estimates to reduce emissions to the levels of 1990.
Within the insurance industry, global warming has been an increasingly hot topic of debate. Some insurers, especially those who are large sellers of homeowner policies in hurricane-prone regions of the country, think they might benefit from a global effort to reduce climate changes, which could lead to more extreme weather swings.
But support for a treaty is lackluster, industry experts say, because some fear that it would put a damper on economic growth in the U.S.
"The theory of climate change seems to make some sense, but there seems to be a serious lack of data supporting that theory," said John Arlington, assistant vice president for federal affairs for the American Insurance Association, a trade association of some of the nation's largest property-casualty insurance carriers.
Forest-products companies also might stand to benefit from a push to cut greenhouse gases, because one possible approach is to plant more trees, which soak up carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere. But the industry has adopted a wait-and-see stance.
"There's still a great deal of vagueness, and many of the details may not be worked out before" the conference next fall in Argentina, said W. Henson Moore, chairman and chief executive officer of the American Forest and Paper Association.
Rick Holley, chief executive officer at Plum Creek Timber LP, said the company supports the notion of decreasing emissions, but is concerned about the treaty's apparent absence of emission caps for developing countries such as China. Mr. Holley also expressed hope that timber companies would get "pollution credits" for the fact that trees absorb carbon. "Our industry plants millions of trees a year, and we should get credit in any pollution trading arrangement for that," he said.
Meantime, makers of grain-derived ethanol fuel think the global-warming pact will lift their business. Raymond Friend, president of High Plains Corp., said the pact helps to make ethanol a more attractive alternative for automobile fuel than petroleum. High Plains isn't drawing up expansion plans yet, however. "We're optimistic. But we'll wait to see how demand shapes up," Mr. Friend said.
Credit: A Wall Street Journal News Roundup

Goldstream among hardest hit fisheries

Author: Lavoie, Judy

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/goldstream-among-hardest-hit-fisheries/docview/345677645/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: By Judith Lavoie Times Colonist staff Dismal returns of coho salmon on the East Coast of Vancouver Island are bringing calls for a ban on sports fishing for Georgia Basin coho. Department of Fisheries and Oceans spokesmen say they do not have enough data yet to consider banning retention of coho by sports fishermen. However, a plan that would allow only hatchery fish to be retained in 1999 is under review. The Goldstream Hatchery is one of the hardest hit areas andhatchery manager Peter McCully said the few fish which have returned are undersized. Climate change and ocean survival are believed to be at the root of the coho collapse, but exact reasons have not been pinpointed. Georgia Basin coho returns were expected to be poor this year. There was no commercial coho fishery, although some were caught as bycatch.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Goldstream+among+hardest+hit+fisheries&amp;author=Lavoie%2C+Judy&amp;issn=&amp;title=Times+-+Colonist&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-11&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: By Judith Lavoie Times Colonist staff Dismal returns of coho salmon on the East Coast of Vancouver Island are bringing calls for a ban on sports fishing for Georgia Basin coho. Department of Fisheries and Oceans spokesmen say they do not have enough data yet to consider banning retention of coho by sports fishermen. However, a plan that would allow only hatchery fish to be retained in 1999 is under review. The Goldstream Hatchery is one of the hardest hit areas andhatchery manager Peter McCully said the few fish which have returned are undersized.
"We are looking at about one-tenth of what we expected. Probably less than 300 coho showed up," he said. "It's devastating for the volunteers and we don't have any answers, which is even more distressing."
Climate change and ocean survival are believed to be at the root of the coho collapse, but exact reasons have not been pinpointed. Georgia Basin coho returns were expected to be poor this year. There was no commercial coho fishery, although some were caught as bycatch.
But there was a significant sports fishery coho harvest, and closing it down next year could make a difference, McCully said.
Although coho have been the backbone of sports fishing on Vancouver Island, they could be replaced by chinook, he suggested.
Ron Kadowaki, DFO head of south coast salmon stock assessment, said coho returns were very poor in Cowichan and Black Creek, and the 20,000 returns at Big Qualicum Hatchery were the only survivors of one million fish released.
"It's not a good situation for the East Coast of Vancouver Island and it doesn't look good for the next few years. We're going to have to be very careful with coho," he said.
There will be intense scrutiny of the situation this winter, Kadowaki said.
"Drastic measures were taken in 1997. Whether they were enough is something for this winter's consultations."
Paul Sprout, DFO operations branch director, said hatcheries have already started clipping coho fins, so a program to allow retention of hatchery fish only could start in 1999.
"Whether we do it or not remains to be seen, but it's an insurance policy if there are significant conservation problems with coho," he said.
Some technical problems need ironing out and there would be public consultations before the program could start, he said.
Until all figures have been analysed there can be no speculation about sports fishing bans, he said.
Bob Rogerson of the Amalgamated Conservation Society said sports fishermen would give up catching coho grudgingly.
Although it could be reluctantly accepted on southern Vancouver Island it would cause huge problems for the tourist industry up- Island, he said.
Over the decades the major problem has been the net fishery in Juan de Fuca Strait, but DFO did not take any action until there was a crisis - despite complaints from sports fishermen, Rogerson said.
"The coho have been mismanaged for 40 years and it can be laid directly on the doorstep of the net fishery," he said.
Even without a direct coho commercial fishery there is a problem with the fish ending up as bycatch, he said.

People: McCully, Peter

Corporations abuse environment most

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/corporations-abuse-environment-most/docview/257743727/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: FROM a Mitsubishi plant that processes rain forest logs in the Amazon and Tokyo, to polluting Chevron oil refineries in California and elsewhere, the world environment is taking a beating from corporate globalization. In a new book, "The Corporate Planet," author Joshua Karliner says corporations are using free trade agreements and World Bank loans to build a world order where they are accountable only to themselves. "Transnational corporations continue to speed the planet full throttle down a socially and ecologically unsustainable course while whistling a tune of change," says Karliner, executive director of the Transnational Resource and Action Centre in San Francisco.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Corporations+abuse+environment+most&amp;author=&amp;issn=07486154&amp;title=China+Daily&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-11&amp;spage=4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   FROM a Mitsubishi plant that processes rain forest logs in the Amazon and Tokyo, to polluting Chevron oil refineries in California and elsewhere, the world environment is taking a beating from corporate globalization.
In a new book, "The Corporate Planet," author Joshua Karliner says corporations are using free trade agreements and World Bank loans to build a world order where they are accountable only to themselves.
Moreover, he says, corporations are working to undermine international environmental agreements, such as the global warming treaty, being debated this week in Kyoto, Japan.
"Transnational corporations continue to speed the planet full throttle down a socially and ecologically unsustainable course while whistling a tune of change," says Karliner, executive director of the Transnational Resource and Action Centre in San Francisco.
In his book, Karliner traces the history of the Chevron Corp as a classic example of a US multinational corporation -- from its oil origins in California to its operations in Asia, Africa and Latin America.
Although Chevron carries out environmental audits of its international operations, it is not clear what these audits have revealed, Karliner says. He maintains Chevron does not present any information about air emissions, hazardous waste or oil spills in its environmental report.
Karliner uses the Mitsubishi Group as an example of the "rise, worldwide growth and environmental impact of Japanese corporate power."
The more than 160 transnational corporations that make up the Mitsubishi Group range from chemical industries to oil, paper, wood, food, life insurance and industrial equipment. Karliner shows how Mitsubishi's logging practices are responsible for deforestation in the Amazon Basin and Southeast Asia.
The book also describes how, under free trade agreements, environmental regulations are often seen as getting in the way of the bottom line. "In their quest to maximize profits, transnationals have played a central role in shaping and promoting free trade agreements," says Karliner.
The free trade agreements are designed to protect multinationals, and tend to portray environmental regulations and labour laws as "barriers to free trade."
In India, for example, a number of environmental laws are being rolled back as growing foreign investment rolls in under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and the World Trade Organization.
Prohibitions against putting industrial plants in ecologically sensitive zones have been eliminated. Similarly, forestry regulations appear to have been loosened for the pulp and paper industry and mining laws watered down by mining corporations.
The book also says corporations "greenwash" the public. "Corporations have fabricated an elaborate series of green veils through which they cloud their responsibility for some of the most destructive activity ever unleashed upon the world," he adds. In advertising campaigns and other public relations strategies, many transnationals distort the truth, says the book.
The greatest doubt that global warming exists and is caused by fossil fuel emissions, for example, comes from those corporations that profit from such fuel -- oil companies, vehicle manufacturers and other industries. Most scientists agree that these emissions will cause more storms, rising sea levels and increases in floods and droughts.
In September 1997 a coalition of industry groups in the US launched a multi-million-dollar ad campaign against the United Nations climate change treaty, which aims to reduce emissions that cause global warming. Industry groups say reducing emissions will harm the US economy.
"Such greenwashing, or corporate environmental propaganda, distorts how we understand the nature of the environmental crisis," says the book.
(Third World Network Features)
