Climate: Work Under Way: [ALL 12/10/97 Edition]

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/climate-work-under-way/docview/405623619/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Earth needs a greenhouse effect, as we have reminded readers for years, if it isn't to go the way of frigid Mars. The challenge is to help the upper atmosphere trap just the Goldilocks-right amount of sun warmth. Not too hot, not too cold. 'Greenhouse' negotiators in Kyoto faced the hugely difficult task of deciding who pays what premiums for a workable insurance policy against a potentially too warm world 50 to 100 years hence. They tried to put teeth into the broad pledges made five years ago in Rio.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Climate%3A+Work+Under+Way&amp;author=&amp;issn=08827729&amp;title=The+Christian+Science+Monitor&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-10&amp;spage=20&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Earth needs a greenhouse effect, as we have reminded readers for years, if it isn't to go the way of frigid Mars. The challenge is to help the upper atmosphere trap just the Goldilocks-right amount of sun warmth. Not too hot, not too cold.
'Greenhouse' negotiators in Kyoto faced the hugely difficult task of deciding who pays what premiums for a workable insurance policy against a potentially too warm world 50 to 100 years hence. They tried to put teeth into the broad pledges made five years ago in Rio.
It should be noted that Kyoto was only one more step toward such teeth. Ratifications and detailed national programs are the next, by no means certain, step.
Before environmentalists, industrialists, labor, thermostat pushers, and the motoring public themselves become overheated in coming debates, remember that, even without teeth, efforts to cut greenhouse-gas emissions are already well under way.
Climate scientists are speeding research on the still-uncertain cause-effect systems influencing climate change. Major global firms (British Petroleum, Norsk Hydro, Ford, Honda, Toyota, Asea Brown Boveri, Daimler Benz, Dupont, and many North American utilities) are spending hundreds of millions on research. They are developing car engines with exhaust cleaner than their intake air, fuel-cell motors and heating systems, more cost-effective photovoltaic roofing, and pollution-swallowing manufacturing processes.
We continue to believe that governments can best move this effort along by four means: (1) Creating tax incentives for emission-related business research. (2) Funding university research and its flow to businesses. (3) Quickly cutting trade barriers on environmental equipment. (4) Negotiating a global system for tradable emissions credits to help even out different national fuel dependencies and transport needs.

Premiers wonder which Chrétien they'll face this time As first ministers gather in Ottawa, they know only that the federal government is anxious to be a player again

Author: Greenspon, Edward

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/premiers-wonder-which-chrétien-theyll-face-this/docview/384729537/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Any attempts to gang up on the federal government must overcome the fact that the provinces suffer from a lack of cohesion over their vision for Ottawa's future role. While they share a sense of anger at the cuts imposed on them, the smaller provinces view the federal government as more of a protector than intruder in their affairs.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Premiers+wonder+which+Chr%C3%A9tien+they%27ll+face+this+time+As+first+ministers+gather+in+Ottawa%2C+they+know+only+that+the+federal+government+is+anxious+to+be+a+player+again&amp;author=Greenspon%2C+Edward&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-09&amp;spage=A.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   As first ministers gather in Ottawa, they know only that the federal government is anxious to be a player again
Premiers wonder which Chrétien they'll face this time
As first ministers gather in Ottawa, they know only that the federal government is anxious to be a player again
Tuesday, December 9, 1997
Parliamentary Bureau Chief
OTTAWA -- Canada's premiers are making the pilgrimage to the nation's capital this week hoping to break bread with the province-friendly Liberals of a year ago and braced for a return of the bossy feds of old.
The suspense in this week's meeting of first ministers boils down to this: Did the brief era of federal-provincial good will ushered in with the February, 1996, Speech from the Throne screech to a halt with the Chrétien government's we-are-back Throne Speech this fall?
The September speech was a millennial blueprint in which the Liberals set forth their hopes to expand government-run health insurance into drugs and home care and the Prime Minister personally declared his intention to create a multibillion-dollar scholarship fund for postsecondary students.
For the premiers, it was a bit much to swallow. In the name of deficit reduction, they have weathered severe cutbacks in federal transfer payments for health care and education. Suddenly, here were the Liberals striking a heroic stance as they outlined their plans for the postdeficit age -- with the action to take place on terrain the Constitution deems provincial.
Like so much in federal-provincial relations, it all comes down to money. More specifically, to who gets to call the shots on the so-called fiscal dividend -- the billions of dollars in surpluses Ottawa is projected to begin racking up next year. The Chrétien Liberals seem bound and determined to go over the heads of the provinces and design programs in which the federal government communes with individual Canadians. That means, for instance, plowing money into federal scholarships rather than handing it to the provinces directly.
The premiers view the case of health as even more egregious. At their annual meeting in August, they told Ottawa that they expect the first returns from the fiscal dividend to be restoration of the social transfers the federal government slashed in fighting its deficit over the past four years, and that goes well beyond the promise reiterated yesterday to establish a $12.5-billion cash floor for social transfers.
The premiers say that nobody contributed more to deficit reduction than the provinces, which sustained reductions of more than $6-billion in federal transfers. Ottawa, using a different method of calculation, claims that it cut its own programs far more deeply.
There is no doubt that the federal government wants to be a player again after a period in which its fiscal weakness and postreferendum morosity caused it to pull in its horns in areas ranging from environmental regulation to job training to social housing.
Last week, a Liberal-dominated Commons committee dumped on the environmental harmonization accord with the provinces. The transfer of federal housing stock still is incomplete. And while many provinces have signed labour-market agreements with Ottawa, the Ontario-dominated Liberal caucus has made it clear to Human Resources Minister Pierre Pettigrew that an agreement with the Harris government would be tantamount to a deal with the devil.
Mr. Pettigrew himself prefers to stress other matters. He points to his impressive but still incomplete deal with the provinces to create a new national child benefit as proof that a new mood still prevails.
"I think first ministers will be taking stock of more remarkable progress than they probably expected in June, 1996, when they tasked their social services ministers to make progress on children. There will certainly be cause for celebration there of pretty substantial progress."
But the premiers, in the words of one senior adviser, "will be waiting with bated breath" to see whether these are the February, 1996, Liberals or the September, 1997, Liberals. Alberta's Ralph Klein has been grumbling in the leadup to the meeting about federal officials trying to stage-manage the event to suit their own agenda.
The provinces come to this meeting feeling that they've come through for the Prime Minister on Quebec. The Calgary declaration of September, which is now being subjected to low-key public consultations in nine provinces and two territories, is meant to put something in the shop window for federalists as Quebec heads toward a provincial election and perhaps another referendum.
In return for taking a chance on reopening the messy issue of distinct society for Quebec (now rechristened unique character), the premiers demanded this meeting to deal with what Saskatchewan's Roy Romanow likes to call the other 80 per cent of the national-unity equation -- the nuts and bolts of federal and provincial programs.
"The provinces extended their hands to Ottawa as much as to Quebec with the Calgary accord," remarked an official from a Western province. Now it is time to see if that politeness is returned.
The assertive tone of the September Throne Speech has doubled the determination of provinces like Ontario and Alberta to push for what they call a framework agreement, in essence a set of rules to restrict Ottawa wandering at will into provincial territory. In its 1996 Throne Speech, Ottawa volunteered to restrict the use of the so-called spending power by which it has in the past powered its way into social programming.
But this well-publicized renunciation of the spending power is non-binding and purposely littered with loopholes. Ontario and Alberta would like to start closing these off (although Ontario's Mike Harris, in particular, must be mindful that his population supports a large role for Ottawa in social policy).
Mr. Klein is burned at Ottawa for supposedly reneging on its agreement with the provinces over climate change.
Any attempts to gang up on the federal government must overcome the fact that the provinces suffer from a lack of cohesion over their vision for Ottawa's future role. While they share a sense of anger at the cuts imposed on them, the smaller provinces view the federal government as more of a protector than intruder in their affairs. Moreover, two of the dominant voices at the table -- by dint of personality more than size -- belong to leaders of small provinces, Saskatchewan's Roy Romanow and Newfoundland's Brian Tobin.
Nor does Jean Chrétien, who would rather be golfing in a rainstorm than supping with the premiers in any case, want the meeting to turn into an effort by the Lilliputian provinces to tie down the federal Gulliver. He hopes to script instead an outpouring of mutual self-congratulations over the co-operative spirit the two levels of government have so far displayed in designing the national child benefit, which is to go into effect in July.
He will seek to repeat the trick -- this time in the area of youth unemployment. After their annual meeting in August, the premiers said Ottawa should get out of youth programs and hand the money it spends over to them. Mr. Chrétien told them no. Now it looks as if the first ministers will jointly instruct Mr. Pettigrew and his provincial counterparts to sit down and design a common approach to the issue.
Even though he is one of the most provincially oriented ministers in Ottawa, Mr. Pettigrew draws the line at youth.
"I agree that we should eliminate duplication. We should work more in partnership. But you cannot demand simply that the government of Canada sends a cheque to the provinces and disappears from the map altogether."
The toughest debate will revolve around health care despite the premeeting move to end the era of cuts. The provinces want Ottawa to put money back into health transfers and to allow for some form of joint interpretation of the Canada Health Act. Whatever their ideoogical stripe, the premiers resent that Ottawa acts as judge and jury on infractions of the principles of medicare even though it now contributes just a fraction of the money in the system.
The Chrétien government doesn't want to give much ground on either point. It has been talking internally about more transparent rules around medicare, but it has no intention of surrendering the hammer. As for the transfers, it prefers to find more visible ways than sending a cheque to the provinces to remind Canadians of its nurturing role in health care.
Thus the discussion in Ottawa about expanding medicare into new areas such as drug coverage and home care.
The provinces counter that medicare needs to be fixed before it is expanded. "The biggest threat to medicare in the last 10 years is this government and its cuts to transfers," said one provincial official. There is nothing wrong with studying joint action on drugs and home care, he added, so long as the funding of the current system is addressed first.

Title: Premiers wonder which Chrétien they'll face this time As first ministers gather in Ottawa, they know only that the federal government is anxious to be a player again

World-Wide

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/world-wide/docview/308277934/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Vice President Al Gore announced in Kyoto he was giving American negotiators unspecified "increased flexibility" in a standoff with Europe over how deeply to cut emissions. Negotiators had plunged into final talks aimed at strengthening the 1992 Climate Change Treaty by setting legally binding targets for reducing industrial nations' emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases linked to global warming. Gore also said the Clinton administration would fight to override any Senate opposition to a treaty back home. De Silguy said he is willing to run for the office of president of the regional council in Brittany as a candidate for the conservative Rassemblement pour la Republique party of President Chirac. The European Commission's top monetary official oversees the process of nominating countries for membership in the euro. Serbian presidential candidates appeared headed for a runoff after a third election proved inconclusive. Yugoslav Foreign Minister Milan Milutinovic, a Milosevic ally, led nationalist Vojislav Seselj in nearly complete poll results. But neither man secured the 50% of votes needed for victory.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=World-Wide&amp;author=&amp;issn=09219986&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-09&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: THE U.S. SIGNALED greater flexibility on fuel-emissions cuts.
Vice President Al Gore announced in Kyoto he was giving American negotiators unspecified "increased flexibility" in a standoff with Europe over how deeply to cut emissions. Negotiators had plunged into final talks aimed at strengthening the 1992 Climate Change Treaty by setting legally binding targets for reducing industrial nations' emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases linked to global warming. Gore also said the Clinton administration would fight to override any Senate opposition to a treaty back home.
But even if the U.S.-European differences are bridged, the U.S. is still trying to win commitments by developing countries to limit emissions.
---
De Silguy said he is willing to run for the office of president of the regional council in Brittany as a candidate for the conservative Rassemblement pour la Republique party of President Chirac. The European Commission's top monetary official oversees the process of nominating countries for membership in the euro.
---
Serbian presidential candidates appeared headed for a runoff after a third election proved inconclusive. Yugoslav Foreign Minister Milan Milutinovic, a Milosevic ally, led nationalist Vojislav Seselj in nearly complete poll results. But neither man secured the 50% of votes needed for victory.
---
Yeltsin again postponed summoning his cabinet to account for the government's poor economic performance. The meeting, first set for Dec. 1 and then put off for a week, will now be held in January.
Russia's intelligence agency dismissed speculation that charges against an American accused of spying would be reduced. The Federal Security Service said the investigation against Richard L. Bliss was moving ahead.
---
A German insurance group said it would pay undisclosed amounts to settle seven insurance cases stemming from the Holocaust. The cases were discovered after Allianz AG agreed to demands that it research policies that might have been illegally sold or cashed in during Nazi rule of Germany.
---
Germany's defense minister announced the suspension of an army general who headed the military's leadership academy when it invited a neo-Nazi to give a lecture. Ruehe also said the colonel who invited Manfred Roeder for the Jan. 24, 1995, lecture was being disciplined.
---
The U.N. weapons chief will hold talks with officials in Paris and London en route to his first visit to Iraq since the temporary expulsion of U.S. arms inspectors from that country. Butler is scheduled to begin talks with Iraqi officials Sunday on the issue of unimpeded access to any site by the U.N. inspectors.
---
Israel and Turkey pledged to improve military ties. The move by defense ministers of the two countries, meeting in Turkey, came in reaction to passage of a draft resolution by the 55-member Organization of the Islamic Conference that denounced such ties with Israel. Meanwhile, Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Abdullah arrived in Tehran for the summit, signaling Iran's diminishing isolation in the region.
---
Netanyahu's government survived a no-confidence vote, 52-45, brought by the opposition in protest of stalled peace talks. Separately, government figures revealed that housing construction started in Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza Strip had risen by 23% in the first half of 1997, with a 63% jump in government-financed construction.
---
Philippines President Ramos said he will back his political lieutenant, House Speaker Jose de Venecia Jr., to become his successor in next May's presidential election. Ramos is forbidden by the constitution to run for a second term.
---
A former Algerian diplomat accused his government of killing civilians and blaming it on the Islamic opposition. Mohammed Larmi Zitout said he quit his job as the No. 2 diplomat in the Algerian embassy in Libya because of he could no longer support the government.
---
Spain will move 15 more prisoners of the Basque separatist group ETA closer to their homes. ETA, which has killed nearly 800 people, has protested the government's policy of dispersing the prisoners throughout the country.
---
Police in Germany evacuated 10,000 people from homes, schools and public buildings in Oranienburg while munitions experts defused a World War II bomb.

Address Global Warming Now, While the Costs Are Still Low

Author: KENNETH L. LAY FOR KNIGHT-RIDDER NEWS SERVICE

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/address-global-warming-now-while-costs-are-still/docview/288746636/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: The international climate-change treaty negotiations in Kyoto offer the chance to prevent, at surprisingly low cost, a global warming scenario that might otherwise prove extremely expensive. Unfortunately, the career naysayers will attempt to confuse the debate, while companies that neither challenge nor support the scientific foundations for near-term action could waste a tremendous opportunity to stimulate realistic climate solutions. Since, for most companies, control of greenhouse gas emissions is not an important issue, incremental and flexible regulatory programs would have negligible near-term impacts on the U.S. economy. Exports, for example, would suffer little, because of their relatively small energy component and the likelihood that energy prices will not increase significantly. Additionally, the cost of carbon reductions will decline as mass production meets the growing domestic and overseas market for ``green'' technologies. According to the Alliance to Save Energy, smart regulatory programs could even create as many as 800,000 new jobs.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Address+Global+Warming+Now%2C+While+the+Costs+Are+Still+Low&amp;author=KENNETH+L.+LAY+FOR+KNIGHT-RIDDER+NEWS+SERVICE&amp;issn=07463502&amp;title=The+Salt+Lake+Tribune&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-09&amp;spage=A.11&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The international climate-change treaty negotiations in Kyoto offer the chance to prevent, at surprisingly low cost, a global warming scenario that might otherwise prove extremely expensive. Unfortunately, the career naysayers will attempt to confuse the debate, while companies that neither challenge nor support the scientific foundations for near-term action could waste a tremendous opportunity to stimulate realistic climate solutions.
Since, for most companies, control of greenhouse gas emissions is not an important issue, incremental and flexible regulatory programs would have negligible near-term impacts on the U.S. economy. Exports, for example, would suffer little, because of their relatively small energy component and the likelihood that energy prices will not increase significantly.
Additionally, the cost of carbon reductions will decline as mass production meets the growing domestic and overseas market for ``green'' technologies. According to the Alliance to Save Energy, smart regulatory programs could even create as many as 800,000 new jobs.
There are three reasons why regulatory action is warranted.
First, the science -- although not conclusive -- is substantial, and the absence of iron-clad certainty does not justify apathy. Although industry has frequently opposed environmental or health regulations that were later justified by proof measured in deaths, illness and injury, industry has not always cried wolf -- productivity and competitiveness can be hindered by poorly designed regulation. This is why we should rely on systems such as emission credit trading to mitigate the impact of climate change.
Second, the cost of obtaining ``dead certain proof'' could be high. Even if one argues that the science is not perfect, one must also acknowledge that the cost associated with certainty could be measured in more heat waves, pest infestation, storm damage, and rising sea levels. A realistic regulatory program would set in motion public- and private-sector initiatives to capture the cheap reductions as soon as possible, while we continue to validate the science.
Third, the cost is low for insurance that takes the form of new national regulatory programs. With the right policies, such as a carbon credit trading program and incentives to start reducing carbon emissions sooner rather than later, the cost of control for the next five years would be negligible.
Stephen DeCanio, an economist with President Reagan's Council of Economic Advisors, has pointed out that to cut emissions from 1990 levels by 20 percent, eight climate economic models show GDP losses of .9 percent to 1.7 percent, but that a 1.0 percent loss of GDP would amount to ``less than six months of normal economic growth.'' This means a half-year's delay in reaching the standard of living that would have been achieved without emissions curtailment -- hardly the end of Western economies.
Why is there so much confusion about costs? When economic modelers use different assumptions, the models yield a wide array of results. But when Robert Repetto of the World Resources Institute recently analyzed many of the economic models forecasting impacts of a carbon control program, he found that when they used the same assumptions, the models gave generally similar results, namely a small and potentially favorable macroeconomic impact. This makes sense, since for 95 percent of U.S. industrial employment, energy costs are less than 5 percent of the value of total output.
The regulatory flexibility currently advocated by the more pro-active members of industry builds on 20 years of experience with air pollution credit trading in the United States. The General Accounting Office, OECD and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) have documented that between 1976 and 1995 these programs saved U.S. industry billions of dollars, as compared with alternative command and control regulatory schemes.
The keys to success are simplicity, incrementalism, and an early start date. Steady reductions of 1 percent to 2 percent per year from our currently high emissions base will prompt a clear demand for solar power, wind power, fuel cells and other 21st-century technologies, thereby creating a demand for efficiency in energy and manufacturing.
To solve the climate-change problem, we need to implement those systems that reward people for saving energy, reducing emissions and building a culture that identifies and corrects inefficient use of resources. Meanwhile, low-cost carbon reductions will be achieved, as well as nitrogen dioxide, particulate and sulfur emissions reductions. If the problem turns out to be a mirage, we can stop. If the problem is more severe than expected, we can phase in larger reductions.
It's time to stop debating the issues surrounding climate-change initiatives and focus instead on simple, realistic, cost-effective solutions. This is one area where an ounce of near-term prevention will be worth considerably more than a pound of cure later on.Kenneth L. Lay is chairman and CEO of Enron Corp., one of the world's largest integrated natural gas and electricity companies.

Marketing gas: [London edition]

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/marketing-gas/docview/248503264/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: EU energy ministers meeting in Brussels will try to agree plans to open Europe's $100bn-a-year natural gas market to competition. After eight years of discussion, and a renewed push for agreement since last year's deal on liberalisation of the electricity market, a compromise plan has largely been agreed. The key question remains the extent to which the market would be opened to competition, and which customers would be eligible to shop around for gas supplies. Luxembourg, holder of the EU presidency, proposes opening about 23 per cent of the market - accounted for by the largest energy users in each EU state - initially, rising to 28 per cent after five years, and 33 per cent after 10 years, similar to the pattern of the electricity directive. Al Gore, US vice-president, makes a one-day trip to Kyoto to meet international delegates at the UN climate change conference on Monday, when ministerial-level meetings start to round up last week's talks. Mr Gore will give a speech which delegates hope may break the deadlock in the negotiations. The 10-day conference is scheduled to end on Wednesday with agreement among developed countries on targets to cut greenhouse gas emissions, but progress has been slow. The US has demanded participation by developing countries as a precondition for signing the agreement, and Mr Gore said last week that the US was prepared to walk away from an unsatisfactory agreement. Controversy has already marred the first world chess championship played on the knock-out system, at Groningen, Netherlands. Nearly 100 grandmasters compete for the right to challenge the Russian holder Anatoly Karpov in next month's final. World number one Garry Kasparov has refused to take part, while world number two Vladimir Kramnik has also withdrawn on the grounds that Karpov has an unfair advantage. The record $5m prize fund is guaranteed by Kirsan Ilyumzhinov, president of the International Chess Federation and ruler of the Caucasian republic of Kalmykia, where critics allege that oil and caviar revenues are being squandered on off-beat projects such as the newly constructed Chess City.

Full text: EU energy ministers meeting in Brussels will try to agree plans to open Europe's $100bn-a-year natural gas market to competition. After eight years of discussion, and a renewed push for agreement since last year's deal on liberalisation of the electricity market, a compromise plan has largely been agreed. The key question remains the extent to which the market would be opened to competition, and which customers would be eligible to shop around for gas supplies. Luxembourg, holder of the EU presidency, proposes opening about 23 per cent of the market - accounted for by the largest energy users in each EU state - initially, rising to 28 per cent after five years, and 33 per cent after 10 years, similar to the pattern of the electricity directive.
Gore takes the heat
Al Gore, US vice-president, makes a one-day trip to Kyoto to meet international delegates at the UN climate change conference on Monday, when ministerial-level meetings start to round up last week's talks. Mr Gore will give a speech which delegates hope may break the deadlock in the negotiations. The 10-day conference is scheduled to end on Wednesday with agreement among developed countries on targets to cut greenhouse gas emissions, but progress has been slow. The US has demanded participation by developing countries as a precondition for signing the agreement, and Mr Gore said last week that the US was prepared to walk away from an unsatisfactory agreement.
Mating game
Controversy has already marred the first world chess championship played on the knock-out system, at Groningen, Netherlands. Nearly 100 grandmasters compete for the right to challenge the Russian holder Anatoly Karpov in next month's final. World number one Garry Kasparov has refused to take part, while world number two Vladimir Kramnik has also withdrawn on the grounds that Karpov has an unfair advantage. The record $5m prize fund is guaranteed by Kirsan Ilyumzhinov, president of the International Chess Federation and ruler of the Caucasian republic of Kalmykia, where critics allege that oil and caviar revenues are being squandered on off-beat projects such as the newly constructed Chess City.
Refugee count
The United Nations refugee agency publishes its annual report on the state of the world's refugees. The Geneva-based UN High Commissioner for Refugees has been forced to cut budgets next year because funding has fallen along with declining refugee emergencies. However, the report points out that the numbers of internally displaced and stateless people are rising and, unlike refugees fleeing across national borders, they often have little or no access to international assistance. The UNHCR has a current caseload of about 23m refugees and displaced people, down from 26m in early 1996.
Foreign affairs
EU foreign ministers meet in Brussels to prepare for this week's EU summit in Luxembourg, where plans for eastern enlargement are at the top of the agenda. Ministers will also discuss the follow-up to last week's summit with the US and Canada.
Holidays
Argentina, Austria, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Guam, Italy, Liechtenstein, Macau, Malta, Monaco, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Portugal, San Marino, Seychelles, Spain, Switzerland, Vatican City, Venezuela.
Surveys
China; World Pulp and Paper.
TUESDAY 9
Deadline Bosnia
Bosnia's ethnic communities will come under strong pressure to settle quickly the many remaining disputes hampering reintegration of their war-shattered country. The western powers which, together with Russia and Japan, make up the Bosnian Peace Implementation Council are expected to call at their two-day meeting in Bonn for Serbs, Moslems and Croats to agree common citizenship, passport and car registration laws by December 15, and currency and customs arrangements and a new national flag by December 20. Earlier deadlines have been ignored by the Bosnian Serb republic and the Moslem-Croat federation.
European diagnosis
The United Nations Economic Commission for Europe publishes its latest economic assessment of Europe's economies. The UN/ECE, which has traditionally focused on central and eastern Europe, says that aggregate output has grown this year in the transition economies for the first time since the collapse of communism in 1989. In particular, the economic decline in Russia appears to have ended - though there is no sign of the promised recovery. Most other countries in the region have seen positive growth in the past two years.
Korean settlement bid
Historic negotiations on a permanent settlement to the Korean conflict begin in Geneva between North and South Korea, the US and China. The four-party talks, hosted by the Swiss government, kick off with a two-day opening session, but diplomats say they could last for months or years.
Islamic summit
Some 2,000 official delegates are expected to attend the three-day summit of the Organisation of Islamic Conference in Tehran, including 35 heads of state from Moslem countries. Another 15 delegations of "special guests" have been invited. The 55-member organisation's summit will discuss regional issues such as the Arab-Israeli conflict and Afghanistan and ways of improving trade and economic relations between Islamic countries.
Russia's WTO application
The World Trade Organisation working party considering Russia's membership application meets in Geneva. The talks are moving more slowly than hoped because of delays by Moscow in producing offers to open up its domestic market for goods and services. Russia and the US agreed earlier this year that they would aim for Russian entry in 1998, but this now looks an unlikely prospect.
Holiday
South Africa, Tanzania.
Survey
Hungary.
WEDNESDAY 10
Labour facing revolt
Britain's Labour government faces its first serious backbench revolt since the election in a vote to cut benefits to lone parents. Ministers' decision to go ahead with the cuts, proposed by the previous Conservative government, prompted more than 100 Labour MPs to write a private letter to Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the exchequer, calling for the plans to be postponed. Some were placated by Mr Brown's Green Budget plans to pump £300m into childcare and helping lone parents find jobs. A number of Labour members are expected to vote against the measure or abstain.
Nobel awards
The Norwegian Nobel Committee holds a ceremony for the winners of the 1997 Peace Prize, the International Campaign to Ban Land Mines and its co-ordinator, Jody Williams. In Stockholm, the 1997 Nobel Prizes are presented followed by a banquet at city hall.
Holidays
Equatorial Guinea, Kiribati, Namibia, Thailand.
Surveys
French Finance and Investment: Italian Industry and Finance.
THURSDAY 11
Sinn Fein at No 10
Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness, the Sinn Fein leaders, are due to meet Tony Blair, the UK prime minister, in Downing Street. Conservatives and Ulster Unionists have expressed outrage at the meeting, the first time a senior Irish Republican has been invited to Downing Street since 1921. But Mr Blair has indicated he is determined to treat Sinn Fein, the political wing of the IRA, the same as other parties involved in the Northern Ireland talks.
Chileans vote
Some 8m Chileans go to the polls to elect a new house of representatives and half the senate. The centre-left government coalition, the Concertation of Parties for Democracy, expects to keep its majority in the lower house and hopes to win one or two more seats in the senate. The real balance of power in congress will not be clear, however, until just before Christmas, when the armed forces and the supreme court have named five of the nine "institutional" senators. The one secure new member is Chile's former dictator, Gen Augusto Pinochet, who takes an automatic ex-officio seat when he retires from the army command in March.
No jobs for the girls
The International Labour Organisation in Geneva publishes a report on women in management which shows that women are still failing to break through the so-called "glass ceiling" barring them from top jobs.
Holiday
Burkina Faso.
Survey
FT Exporter.
FRIDAY 12
Enlargement summit
EU leaders meet in Luxembourg for a two-day summit which is expected to select a short-list of countries from central and eastern Europe that are ready to open negotiations in March 1998 on entry to the Union around the turn of the century. The favoured countries are expected to be the Czech Republic, Poland, Hungary, Estonia and Slovenia, to be joined by Cyprus. EU leaders will agree special assistance to Latvia, Lithuania, Bulgaria, Romania, and Slovakia and offer the disappointed countries the possibility of a review of their applications in a year's time. The 15 heads of government will try to placate Turkey with the promise of inclusion in a pan-European conference next year.
Financial services pact
Today is the deadline for concluding a World Trade Organisation pact on liberalising global financial services markets. Negotiators will have been working round the clock to squeeze out the maximum improvements in foreign access to trading partners' banking, insurance and securities sectors. But the final say will lie with Washington, which walked away from an earlier deal in 1995.
Holidays
Kenya, Mexico, Russian Federation.
Surveys
Employee Benefits; Turkish Finance and Industry.
SUNDAY 14
Czech conference
The Czech Civic Democratic party, which has led the country since 1992, holds an extraordinary conference to elect a new leader after the resignation of prime minister Vaclav Klaus last month over a corporate donation scandal. Mr Klaus has said he will stand again and so far no serious rival candidate has come forward. The conference is likely to be bitter, with a division between Mr Klaus and other senior members of the party, and between regional party members, who are thought to back Mr Klaus, and deputies, most of whom want him to step down. If Mr Klaus is re-elected, the party could split and early elections will be likely. Compiled by Roger Beale. Fax: (+44) (0)171 873 3196. Copyright Financial Times Limited 1997. DEBATE: KYOTO, THE ECONOMY, AND THE AIR WE BREATHE

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/debate-kyoto-economy-air-we-breathe/docview/1842117606/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: None available.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=DEBATE%3A+KYOTO%2C+THE+ECONOMY%2C+AND+THE+AIR+WE+BREATHE&amp;author=&amp;issn=08856613&amp;title=Philadelphia+Inquirer&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-07&amp;spage=E.7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Few issues have generated more submissions to this page lately than the Kyoto conference. Below are some selections.
Just who are the 2,600 scientists proclaiming the certitude of human-caused global warming? Nine out of 10 are unqualified to render expert opinions, according to a Citizens for a Sound Economy study. Among the so-called experts: a plastic surgeon, landscape architects, lawyers, dermatologists, English and linguistics experts, a hotel administrator, a gynecologist, sociologists - even an expert in traditional Chinese medicine!
Beginning with the discovery of fire, energy has enabled us to move from cave dwellings to today's unprecedented quality of life. Now we're being pressured to take immediate, draconian action to answer a question we don't yet understand. Given the immense sweep of human history, a few more years invested in learning more about the science of global climate change cannot but improve our response.
Juli McGreevy, state coordinator
Coalition for Vehicle Choice
If President Clinton is to restore U.S. environmental credibility in Kyoto, he needs to offer a major national initiative to reduce carbon dioxide emissions.
How about some EPA automobile legislation that includes sport utility vehicles (SUVs) and minivans? Require that by 2003 these vehicles meet today's average fuel efficiency requirements (27.5 mpg) for cars. (Right now, they don't have to.) Require government offices to purchase fuel-cell vehicles as available. Impose a 1-cent-per-gallon gas surcharge through the year 2010 - proceeds paid proportionally by market share to U.S.-originating passenger vehicle manufacturers. Link insurance liability rates to vehicle weight. A Ford Escort, at under 2700 pounds, would get a rebate of $50, while a Ford Expedition, at 5000 pounds, would carry an insurance liability surcharge of $400.
The 1-cent gas tax and sales surcharges would generate hundreds of millions of dollars for carmakers. It would also mean massive savings in U.S. petrodollars.
Here's how: If we held minivans and SUVs to automobile standards, they would have to get 2.6 more miles to the gallon. That would save an average of 46 gallons per new vehicle per year. And it would cut vehicle carbon dioxide emissions by 10.4 percent.
Now, 15.5 million new vehicles are to be made in the 1998 model year. Saving that 2.6 miles per gallon means we could buy 42.4 million less gallons of oil (which we would have used to make gas). With crude oil at roughly $17 a barrel, that's a savings of $721 million in imported oil per year - almost 8 percent of 1995 petroleum imports from Persian Gulf states.
Such savings would help trim our burgeoning trade deficit, slow our growing dependence on foreign oil, and increase the international marketability and sales of U.S. cars.
These proposals would significantly and quickly decrease U.S. pollution and reestablish U.S. environmental credibility. Can Congress offer something better?
Theodore L. Gaillard Jr.
Philadelphia-based writer on
military and economic affairs
Many American industries seem blind to the economic opportunities a strong Kyoto climate agreement could bring.
Cutting emissions will create new markets - for silicon solar cells, fiberglass wind turbines, and hybrid electric cars, to mention three - which could create one of the largest new growth sectors of the 21st century. The global wind power industry is a $2-billion-a-year business growing at 25 percent per year. The world market for solar cells has gone from $350 million in 1998 to roughly $1 billion in 1997. A new generation of hybrid electric cars, with twice the fuel economy and half the carbon dioxide emissions of today's cars, is also on the way.
If energy becomes a business based on information, manufacturing and services - rather than finding, extracting, and processing buried fuels - leadership in energy would shift from countries that sit atop large reservoirs of hydrocarbons to those with the innovation, infrastructure and skills to predominate in a new high-tech industry. The United States is in a good position to compete in such an industry.
Christopher Flavin, president
Seth Dunn, staff researcher
Worldwatch Institute
Behind the big debate over global warming lie questions of overpopulation and sustainable development. Asia and Latin America say they need to speed up industrial production to give their growing millions a decent standard of living. As populations grow, more and more forests are burned to create farmland, and more energy-consuming, smoke-throwing factories emerge, along with more gas-guzzling vehicles.
Instead of punishing developing countries who've come late to the dance, the United States and the other industrialized nations should work to guide them to a sustainable mode of growth. The industrialized countries can set an example by curbing their consumerist lifestyles and cutting down emissions. And they - the United States especially - must help developing countries with runaway population growth, to balance their numbers with available resources.
Werner Fornos, president
Population Institute
Do you look forward to paying more for electricity and gasoline? Do you want government to tell you that you can't buy certain cars because they don't get enough miles to the gallon? If your answer is no, then you're not ready for what's coming out of Kyoto. The Clinton administration and allies have done everything they can to hide the high price tag that comes with controlling greenhouse gases.
It means higher gasoline and electricity costs and lower economic growth. One economic study by the respected WEFA Group forecasts additional costs of $30,000 over the next twenty years for a family of four. And the goal of those pushing a Kyoto treaty is indeed to make us poorer by cutting our energy use. President Clinton, of course, denies there is a price to be paid.
China, India and Mexico know better. They are refusing to commit to any limits on their own economic growth. If we sign a treaty to reduce our own greenhouse emissions while exempting all developing countries, there will be a massive transfer of American industrial jobs to these countries - and no global reductions in greenhouse gases.
Malcolm Wallop, chairman
Frontiers of Freedom Institute

Traditional approaches will have to give way to innovative ones if countries are to agree on firm targets and timetables in Kyoto.
A system of tradeable emission permits, the keystone of the Clinton plan, is one such approach. We can't draw property lines in the atmosphere, but we can grant rights to emit air pollution, rights that can be traded like shares of stock. Some people think this is like putting Dracula in charge of the blood bank. But if we limit emission permits to a level below what would happen otherwise, they will reduce pollution.
The U.S. Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990 already mandate tradable emission allowances for electric utilities - and the system is working. It will also work with nations. If we assign permits in a flexible, equitable manner, their impact should be reasonable and proportionate from country to country. That alone should remind Kyoto representatives that debating fine points is unnecessary, and they may then turn to the business of designing a fair and workable system.
Adam Rose
Professor of mineral economics
Pennsylvania State University
This is an economic meeting disguised as an environmental meeting which is part of a Chinese plot.
Sen. Michael Enzi (R., Wyo.)
Even if one assumes that heavy costs are associated with immediately reducing greenhouse gas emissions, there are still good reasons for early action. One is legal, as enshrined in a principle of the [1992 United Nations Climate Change Convention], which states that parties to the convention are to take ``precautionary measures to anticipate, prevent or minimize the causes of climate change and mitigate its adverse effects.'' Another is scientific. The authors of IMAGE 2, a Dutch study, showed that early action is critical when taking environmental and economic goals into consideration. As the authors pointed out, ``If global emissions are too high in the year 2010, there is little chance afterwards to make a course correction which avoids climate-related impacts.''
What, though, are the chances of our being able to make such a course correction? According to M. Da-Huong, M. Grubb, and J.-C. Hourcade, authors of another study, they are low. Their bottom line is that if we acknowledge that there is a significant risk that we need to stay below a particular level, then, given the socioeconomic inertia in energy systems, delay will prove costly. The authors' conclusion is that there is a pressing case for limiting carbon dioxide emissions now.
In all, this is far more than a scholarly debate between proponents of ``act now'' and proponents of ``delay until later.'' What countries agree
at Kyoto and then proceed to do will have a profound impact on future outcomes . . .
Kilaparti Ramakrishna
Deputy director
Woods Hole Research Center
Almost no attention has been given to how a global warming treaty will be implemented and enforced and what consequences it will have for our national sovereignty and personal freedoms.
If relying on national governments to police their own industries has proved unworkable, then an international authority with the power to compel compliance is the logical consequence. It will be necessary to monitor the internal economic activities of all the countries involved. It will require countless inspectors and a large international bureaucracy, probably under the United Nations, to collect, process and analyze the data.
In all, we are likely to be left with a vast new international bureaucracy looking for something to do. We will have taken the first step toward imposing centralized energy planning, with all the loss of sovereignty and individual liberty that such a global regime entails.
Myron Ebell, policy director
Frontiers of Freedom Institute

Insurers are worried by fossil fuels: [CITY EDITION]

Author: McDonald, Frank

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/insurers-are-worried-fossil-fuels/docview/310269655/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Executives representing more than 70 insurance companies around the world yesterday indicated that they would be reviewing their investment strategies to support more environment-friendly alternatives to burning oil and coal. One of them, Ms Tessa Tennant of NPI Global Care Investments, even suggested that advertisements for oil and petrol should carry government health warnings to raise public awareness about climate change. Mr Andrew Dlugolecki, assistant general manager at General Accident, said insurance companies with large shareholdings are now analysing their strategies, in particular for the energy, transport and tourism industries.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Insurers+are+worried+by+fossil+fuels&amp;author=McDonald%2C+Frank&amp;issn=&amp;title=Irish+Times&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-06&amp;spage=13&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Executives representing more than 70 insurance companies around the world yesterday indicated that they would be reviewing their investment strategies to support more environment-friendly alternatives to burning oil and coal. One of them, Ms Tessa Tennant of NPI Global Care Investments, even suggested that advertisements for oil and petrol should carry government health warnings to raise public awareness about climate change.
Mr Andrew Dlugolecki, assistant general manager at General Accident, said insurance companies with large shareholdings are now analysing their strategies, in particular for the energy, transport and tourism industries.
"If they have not got a strategy to deal with climate change, they will not be a good investment. We are not saying to member-companies that they should not invest in coal or oil, but to give serious thought to whether these industries can cope with the future".
Mr Dlugolecki was speaking at a news conference on the fifth day of the Kyoto Climate Change Summit as delegates representing 147 countries continued their negotiations on a legally-binding protocol to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
The 70-plus companies involved in the UN Environment Programmes Insurance Industry Initiative have annual revenues exceeding $2 trillion and thus cannot be ignored. They have emerged as an important counterweight to the fossil fuel lobby.
It has been estimated that as much as one-third of investments in global stock markets, amounting to more than $15 trillion, are managed by insurance companies and pension funds. "We have a serious duty to safeguard our funds", Mr Dlugolecki said.
In their position paper, published yesterday, the companies allied with UNEP said it was "in the interests of the industry to understand better the investment opportunities and challenges which will arise from measures to reduce greenhouse gas emissions."
They warned that even small shifts in regional climate zones or storm patterns, brought about by global warming, carried the risk of a "large increase" in property damage, which would leave the industry exposed to massive claims. Natural disasters already represent 85 per cent of insured catastrophes world-wide, amounting to $12.4 billion in 1995.
But climate change poses other risks, too. For example, changes in human health due to the spreading of diseases may affect the life assurance and pension industries, while shifts in agricultural production could have an impact on crop insurance.

Kyoto draws together diverse cast: Environmentalists and lobbyists struggle to influence conference delegates: [USA edition]

Author: Boulton, Leyla

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/kyoto-draws-together-diverse-cast/docview/248506751/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Even the bushes in Kyoto have feelings this week. "Silent but angry", said one placard posted on a shrub outside the climate change conference yesterday. Another, also installed in a dawn raid by Japanese environmentalists, wondered: "Are u going to save us, Al?" ahead of Monday's arrival of Al Gore, the "green" US vice-president. The conference centre itself resembles a cross between a traditional Japanese temple and a space ship. The mission of the 10,000 green creatures inside is to save Mother Earth - as the official Japanese poster describes the planet - from increased drought, flooding, and freak weather associated wth climate change.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Kyoto+draws+together+diverse+cast%3A+Environmentalists+and+lobbyists+struggle+to+influence+conference+delegates&amp;author=Boulton%2C+Leyla&amp;issn=03071766&amp;title=Financial+Times&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-06&amp;spage=03&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Even the bushes in Kyoto have feelings this week. "Silent but angry", said one placard posted on a shrub outside the climate change conference yesterday. Another, also installed in a dawn raid by Japanese environmentalists, wondered: "Are u going to save us, Al?" ahead of Monday's arrival of Al Gore, the "green" US vice-president.
The conference centre itself resembles a cross between a traditional Japanese temple and a space ship. The mission of the 10,000 green creatures inside is to save Mother Earth - as the official Japanese poster describes the planet - from increased drought, flooding, and freak weather associated wth climate change.
Perhaps as an insurance policy against failure, all the world's 166 nations are represented in an ark-shaped conference hall. There they sit in alphabetical order from Albania to Zimbabwe, wrangling over 21st century targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions from fossil fuels.
But for those who do not much like the idea of a future free of coal, oil or gas, alternatives include installing "sinks".
This is alien conference jargon for forests that can absorb some of the carbon dioxide spewed out by cars and power plants.
The back entrance to Kyoto's International Conference Centre offers no escape. There, Greenpeace , the environmental group which wants to replace fossil fuels with solar power, yesterday erected a dinosaur made of oil cans and spare car parts.
A banner summed up its view of progress in the negotiations so far: Dinosaur Diplomacy 1, Climate 0.
The 18-strong Greenpeace delegation had started the week with gentler tactics of persuasion by offering "free solar coffee" from a mobile kitchen generating electricity from sunlight.
Inside the conference hall, official negotiators rub shoulders with lobbyists pushing everything from nuclear energy ("Give them a Future Green with Energy") to, in the lone case of the Japan Bicycle Promotion Institute, getting on your bike.
Thrown into the mix are 4,000 journalists. On call to help them around computers on loan for the conference are official "cyber-guides".
Occasionally, delegates retreat across the road for consultations or snatches of sleep at the equally futuristic Takaragaike Prince Hotel.
This informs visitors its aim is to try to help save the planet with measures that include turning down the lights in corridors used by staff.
Guests are offered Y2,000 ($15) discounts for every day they agree not to have their towels and sheets changed.
Tomorrow, the not quite lost ark turns from publicity stunts to God.
Raul Estrada-Oyuela, the embattled Argentine chairman of the negotiations, is to lead an Inter-Religious Gathering on Climate Change at Kyoto's Kamawarachi cathedral.
Leyla Boulton Copyright Financial Times Limited 1997. All Rights Reserved.

Climate conference: Polluters warned of equity pullout

Author: PAUL BROWN IN KYOTO

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/climate-conference-polluters-warned-equity/docview/245189666/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: European and Asian insurance companies, which are among the world's biggest stock owners, warned environment-damaging companies yesterday that they will unload their shares if they do not mend their ways. The insurance industry, which controls pounds 10,000 billion in equities, a third of the value of global stockmarkets, held a press briefing as a "counterweight" to the fossil-fuel lobby, which publicly admits that it wants to wreck the climate talks in Kyoto. Andrew Dlugolecki, of General Accident, said this was going a bit far, but added: "What we are saying to individual companies in which we have large shareholdings is that we are analysing their strategies on the environment. We will be looking particularly at companies in the energy, transport and tourist industries. If they have not got a strategy for dealing with climate change they will not be a good investment.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Climate+conference%3A+Polluters+warned+of+equity+pullout&amp;author=PAUL+BROWN+IN+KYOTO&amp;issn=02613077&amp;title=The+Guardian&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-06&amp;spage=019&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: EUROPEAN and Asian insurance companies, which are among the world's biggest stock owners, warned environment-damaging companies yesterday that they will unload their shares if they do not mend their ways.
The insurance industry, which controls pounds 10,000 billion in equities, a third of the value of global stockmarkets, held a press briefing as a "counterweight" to the fossil-fuel lobby, which publicly admits that it wants to wreck the climate talks in Kyoto.
NPI, one of the more radical British pension and insurance companies, said oil and petrol advertising should carry global health warnings, as tobacco advertising carries personal health messages.
Tessa Tennant, speaking for the company, said: "This is a precautionary measure which all governments can readily take. It is widely recognised that transport emissions are a significant and increasing source of various pollutants. Let us focus on this and get the message across to people in their daily lives."
Andrew Dlugolecki, of General Accident, said this was going a bit far, but added: "What we are saying to individual companies in which we have large shareholdings is that we are analysing their strategies on the environment. We will be looking particularly at companies in the energy, transport and tourist industries. If they have not got a strategy for dealing with climate change they will not be a good investment.
"We are not saying to member companies they should not invest in coal or oil, but {asking them} to give serious thought to whether these companies can cope with the future, and use their influence to change the ways of these companies. We have a serious duty to safeguard our funds."
Elizabeth Dowdeswell, secretary-general of the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP), said 85 per cent of insurance company losses were due to natural disasters. It was a giant industry with a $2,000 billion turnover, several times more than the entire oil industry.
UNEP had been working for two years with 71 insurance companies on the issue of climate change. The commendable decision to base some of their investment decisions on the companies' attitudes towards global warming was the result of this liaison.
Ivo Knoepful of Swiss Reinsurance, a pounds 30 billion company, said: "We can only afford to invest in progressive companies. Rail companies are really in the business of transportation, oil companies need to reclassify themselves as energy industries and get into the future."
Mr Dlugolecki said: "It is a serious issue which our members can no longer ignore."
One bad storm in the southern United States could cost pounds 100 billion in property losses. A 10 per cent increase in wind speed in storms - one of the possible consequences of climate change - could increase insurance losses by 150 per cent.
In the US, insurance companies paying compensation for houses destroyed by flooding are already stipulating that the replacement should be built in a safer place.
In Britain drought caused by climate change cost the insurance industry pounds 500 million in claims in 1990 and 1991. Payments are expected to rise by 50 per cent, to pounds 750 million a year, by 2020.
The Hadley Centre for Climate Change in Berkshire confirmed in Kyoto yesterday that 1997 was the hottest year recorded.
Despite US insistence that nothing has changed, delegates say that Washington will agree to a reduction target of at least 5 per cent by the time negotiations end on Wednesday. This has been made possible by including only three gases - carbon dioxide, methane and nitrous oxide - in the reduction targets.
The US originally wanted to include three CFC substitutes made and sold there. Without these three, the US can reduce emissions by 5 per cent by 2012 without taking additional measures.

`Poorest of poor' face greenhouse disaster; THE KYOTO SUMMIT: [Late Edition]

Author: MURRAY HOGARTH in Kyoto

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/poorest-poor-face-greenhouse-disaster-kyoto/docview/363415767/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Failure to act now on greenhouse gases guarantees climate change that will take "centuries to millennia" to reverse, international scientists warned yesterday in a powerful foray into the debate at the Kyoto summit.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=%60Poorest+of+poor%27+face+greenhouse+disaster%3B+THE+KYOTO+SUMMIT&amp;author=MURRAY+HOGARTH+in+Kyoto&amp;issn=03126315&amp;title=Sydney+Morning+Herald&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-05&amp;spage=12&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: 2100 THE WORLD WITH TWICE THE CARDON DIOXIDE joined to story.
Failure to act now on greenhouse gases guarantees climate change that will take "centuries to millennia" to reverse, international scientists warned yesterday in a powerful foray into the debate at the Kyoto summit.
The new chairman of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), Dr Robert Watson, also increased the moral pressure on Australia and the United States over their demands for greater Third World commitments to cut the gases.
He warned that the worst impacts of global warming - revealed yesterday in a new report - would fall on the "poorest of the poor".
The report, by the leading international climate scientists who advise the United Nations, also warns of high vulnerability for Australia's ecosystems, coastal zones, water resources, human settlements and health.
The IPCC released only a summary of its extensive reports for 10 global regions.
But the Herald has obtained a copy of the full chapter on Australasia, which suggests New Zealand could fare considerably better than Australia. It also suggests greater economic loss for Australia than the average for the world if nothing is done about global warming.
The range of loss for Australia and New Zealand combined is put at minus 1.2 to minus 3.8 per cent of gross domestic product, or up to about $18 billion a year for Australia. Dr Watson put the "crude estimate" of worldwide losses from inaction at between 1 and 2.5 per cent of global output.
The Australasian chapter also warns of "environmental refugees", as both Australian island territories and small Pacific nations face inundation, and a threat of greater property insurance premiums for Australians.
Today, the huge international insurance industry is expected to boost pressure for strong action by developed nations at Kyoto, publishing a position paper on climate change and indicating a shift away from investments in companies that fail to reduce or diversify energy use.
However, famine, floods and disease in the developing countries dominated the impacts predicted for a "double CO world" - where levels of the main greenhouse gas, carbon dioxide, reach twice the level of the pre-industrial era around 2100.
"The bottom line is fundamentally that developing countries are more vulnerable than developed countries in a changed climate world, with the poorest of the poor being most vulnerable," said Dr Watson.
Both he and his immediate predecessor, IPCC chairman emeritus Professor Bert Bolin, urged delegates from 160 nations to resolve their many differences and to act now.
"If we wait for perfect knowledge and we do not like that changed environment, it would not take us decades to reverse the damage, it would potentially take centuries to millennia," Dr Watson said. "Hence actions now have implications for future generations and that is the real challenge for the policymakers."
Both Professor Bolin and Dr Watson defended the IPCC's work against attacks by climate change sceptics. Professor Bolin said he deplored the lack of scientific openness and honesty by some critics, while Dr Watson expressed concern about their influence over many US politicians.
2100 THE WORLD WITH TWICE THE CARDON DIOXIDE
Polar regions
* Sea and river ice loss and permafrost thaw
* New sea routes mean new opportunities for shipping, oil
Africa
* Muck of the Nile delta to be lost
* Wildlife and nature reserves devastated
Small Island States
* Extremely vulnerable to global climate change and global sea-rise.
Australia
* Great Barrier Reef benefits from rising sea-levels, but will be devastated by greater heat, stronger cyclones and silt run-off.
Latin America
* Additional stress on the Amazon rainforests affects the global carbon cycle.

Insurers call for emission curbs: [London edition]

Author: Adams, Christopher; Boulton, Leyla

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/insurers-call-emission-curbs/docview/248480157/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Climate change could be a deceptively pleasant experience at first, with many experiencing long, hot summers of the sort occurring only once a century. But the cost of natural disasters is expected to rise sharply. In a joint statement with the United Nations Environment Programme (Unep) , a group of 35 insurers from Europe and Japan will express support for a market-based approach to imposing limits, where countries could trade their carbon emissions allowances. The report will recommend businesses take urgent action. "Climate change will have a big effect on some industries and you have to plan for it," says Andrew Dlugolecki, assistant general manager of General Accident , the UK insurer.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Insurers+call+for+emission+curbs&amp;author=Adams%2C+Christopher%3BBoulton%2C+Leyla&amp;issn=03071766&amp;title=Financial+Times&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-05&amp;spage=04&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Climate change could be a deceptively pleasant experience at first, with many experiencing long, hot summers of the sort occurring only once a century. But the cost of natural disasters is expected to rise sharply.
The world's biggest insurance companies, concerned they will bear the brunt, will urge world leaders in Kyoto today to agree international curbs on greenhouse gases.
In a joint statement with the United Nations Environment Programme (Unep) , a group of 35 insurers from Europe and Japan will express support for a market-based approach to imposing limits, where countries could trade their carbon emissions allowances.
The report will recommend businesses take urgent action. "Climate change will have a big effect on some industries and you have to plan for it," says Andrew Dlugolecki, assistant general manager of General Accident , the UK insurer.
Insurance companies believe global warming is already altering weather patterns. Natural disasters, mainly windstorms and flooding, have increased more than fourfold during the past 20 years, says Munich Re, the world's biggest reinsurer.
From 1987 to 1993, 16 catastrophes occurred, costing more than $1bn (£600m) each, resulting in insured losses worldwide of more than $50bn. Of those, 85 per cent were due to windstorms and 15 per cent to earthquakes, oil spills and fire.
Even small shifts in storm patterns can cause a big rise in property damage. Computer simulations show that if the strength of a hurricane rises by 10 per cent, a 150 per cent increase in damage can occur, says Mr Dlugolecki.
The cost of natural disasters has risen with the concentration of wealth in the world's most developed cities. A hurricane hitting Miami tomorrow could cause damage totalling $100bn.
Beyond recommending that limits be imposed on carbon emissions, the insurers say investment managers should help develop environmental reporting standards to be used "alongside benchmarks for profitability and security.It also says that the capital resources of both the public and private sector should aim to promote "alternative energy generation and use".
Insurance companies manage nearly a third of investments in global stock markets.
US insurers have yet to express strong support for curbing emissions. The Re-insurance Association of America says some of its members fear they could be held legally responsible for signing the UNEP document. Copyright Financial Times Limited 1997. All Rights Reserved.

When will the world wake up to the threat of global warming?: [FINAL Edition]

Author: Dyer, Gwynne

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/when-will-world-wake-up-threat-global-warming/docview/407009176/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: THE UNITED Nations' climate summit that opened this week in Kyoto, Japan, will probably not end in a flaming row. Countries must not lose face, and so they are more likely to cobble together some shoddy compromise that is worth nothing. But a spectacular failure would be much better, for at least it might get the donkey's attention. Or more precisely, the frog's attention. Environmentalists often compare human behavior to that of frogs -- who, if you drop them into a pot of boiling water, will jump right out again and survive. But sit a frog in a pot of cool water, raise the heat gradually, and he'll sit there happily until he boils to death. The haze is gone from Malaysia now, but a cabaret group, Instant Cafe, is still getting a lot of mileage out of it. They were playing a corporate function in Kuala Lumpur last weekend -- people who'd coughed and wept their way through the haze for all of September and October -- and the audience rocked with laughter when they did their "Haze" song:

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=When+will+the+world+wake+up+to+the+threat+of+global+warming%3F&amp;author=Dyer%2C+Gwynne&amp;issn=19308965&amp;title=The+Sun&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-04&amp;spage=25.A&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: THE UNITED Nations' climate summit that opened this week in Kyoto, Japan, will probably not end in a flaming row. Countries must not lose face, and so they are more likely to cobble together some shoddy compromise that is worth nothing. But a spectacular failure would be much better, for at least it might get the donkey's attention.
Or more precisely, the frog's attention. Environmentalists often compare human behavior to that of frogs -- who, if you drop them into a pot of boiling water, will jump right out again and survive. But sit a frog in a pot of cool water, raise the heat gradually, and he'll sit there happily until he boils to death.
Are humans really like frogs? Of course they are. Take Malaysians, for example.
A hazy situation
The haze is gone from Malaysia now, but a cabaret group, Instant Cafe, is still getting a lot of mileage out of it. They were playing a corporate function in Kuala Lumpur last weekend -- people who'd coughed and wept their way through the haze for all of September and October -- and the audience rocked with laughter when they did their "Haze" song:
Come and visit Malaysia.
Come and stay for lots of days
You don't need your suntan lotion.
You'll be safe from UV rays.
No need to sunbathe by the ocean.
Get dark by strolling in our haze.
The "haze" is mostly smoke from the thousands of forest fires that are set in Indonesia every dry season: First you log out any commercially valuable trees, then you burn the rest because that's the cheapest way to clear the land for cultivation. The smoke from huge areas of burning forest drifts over neighboring Malaysia, blocking out the sun and causing respiratory disorders.
The haze was particularly bad in 1991, when the eruption of Mount Pinatubo added extra ash to the atmosphere. It was even worse this year because of the prolonged drought caused by El Nino. But it happens every year, and it will go on happening until the region's rain forests are all gone. (At the current loss rate of around 3 percent per year, that will be around 30 years from now.)
Yet few Malaysians think they can do anything about it because they know that the companies that are setting most of the fires in Indonesia have close links with Indonesian President Suharto's government in Jakarta, and generally get their way.
They are also vaguely aware that destroying the forests raises the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere and contributes to global warming. But that problem isn't affecting their daily lives yet, and they have lots of present worries to keep them busy.
A breed apart
People in large industrialized democracies like the United States like to think they are different: better information, more open societies, a more educated public. But, in fact,they are equally captive to special interest groups.
The United States, for example, promised at the 1992 Earth Summit in Rio to cut its carbon dioxide emissions back to 1990 levels by the year 2000. Instead, U.S. carbon emissions are 13 percent higher than in 1990, and Washington is now saying that it can't get back down to the target figure until 2013. What happened?
The Clinton administration knows what it should do. At a preparatory meeting of the climate change conference in Geneva earlier this year, the United States mobilized the world's big insurance companies, who proved that global warming was already hitting their balance sheets in terms of claims for storm damage.
That debunked the "junk science" (paid for by fossil fuel producers) that pretends a global warming is just an unproven hypothesis. With the European Union offering emission cuts to 14 percent below 1990 levels by 2010 and the U.S. government also apparently on board, success in Kyoto seemed within reach.
True, the Australians, who export a lot of coal, were arguing that there should be no common global target, just individual targets tailored to individual countries' situations. (Agree to that, and you will spend the next century in negotiations.)
Some oil-rich states were even insisting that if the world cut back on fossil fuel use, they must be compensated financially. But it was clear that once the United States openly espoused a tough target for cutting emissions, a lot of the resistance would crumble.
What went wrong? Basically, Mr. Clinton belatedly realized that U.S. fossil fuel producers, in alliance with other major industries that worry about higher energy costs, control enough U.S. senators to block any treaty that hurts their interests. So rather than fight a hopeless battle, he has chosen pre-emptive surrender.
Getting hotter
Just as in Jakarta, the tail is wagging the dog. Many more Americans have an interest in curbing global warming than in the industries that cause it, but the majority is less conscious of its interests: The water in the pot is getting hotter, but only gradually, So the prospective victims exert less political pressure, and the other side gets its way.
Without a serious American offer on cutting emissions, none of the other hold-outs at Kyoto will be under any pressure to yield, for the United States is the most flagrant polluter of all (4 percent of the world's population, 24 percent of its greenhouse gas emissions). So the best that can be hoped for at Kyoto is dramatic failure.
The Europeans should stick to their proposal and make no compromises. They won't get their way, but that will at least ensure that the problem isn't shelved for five years after a cynical deal that leaves everyone free to do whatever they want.
Gwynne Dyer is a London-based journalist.
