Firing up climate change;: [Late Edition]

Author: DAVID LANGSAM - David Langsam is a freelance journalist specialising in environmental issues.

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/firing-up-climate-change/docview/363397061/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: WITH the driest conditions on record for parts of southern Australia and fire brigades already battling another devastating bushfire season, it might be time for rural and outer-suburban voters to rethink their attitude to climate change.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Firing+up+climate+change%3B&amp;author=DAVID+LANGSAM+-+David+Langsam+is+a+freelance+journalist+specialising+in+environmental+issues.&amp;issn=03126315&amp;title=Sydney+Morning+Herald&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-04&amp;spage=19&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: WITH the driest conditions on record for parts of southern Australia and fire brigades already battling another devastating bushfire season, it might be time for rural and outer-suburban voters to rethink their attitude to climate change.
Despite the Federal Government's denial of the internationally agreed science, it continues to fund important research on measures to counteract the impact of the climate change it denies.
The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) continues to search for crops that will survive increased insect infestation and other climate change impacts. But what might help the Coalition Government pay attention to its farming constituency and marginal seat voters - ahead of the coal and oil industries - is the threat of bushfires, with an expected doubling of bushfire days in much of south-eastern Australia over the next few decades.
Ash Wednesday in February 1983 claimed 76 lives in Victoria and South Australia. In 1967, 62 people died in fires in and around Hobart. The Insurance Council of Australia says the material cost of major bushfires in the past 30 years is about $700 million in current values. The insurance loss in the 1994 NSW bushfires was $56 million and Ash Wednesday cost $320 million.
While the figures account for the damage to buildings, they do not include the cost of the lives of the firefighters and civilians killed in the fires. Nor does Mr Howard's claimed cost of responding to climate change include the loss of work time for volunteer firefighters, the cost to industry of lost production, nor the financial benefits to Australia from being ahead of the world on emissions reduction and new technology rather than lagging a decade behind our competitors.
But before the fossil fuel lobby begins to argue that Australia always has had bushfires and there is no alternative to oil, two facts should be noted: first, the CSIRO expects a doubling in the number of days over 35 degrees by 2070; second, "Australian forest fires become impossible to control when the temperature reaches about 35 degrees, the relative humidity falls below 20 per cent and the winds are in the range of 10-18 metres/sec [36-65km/h or 20-35 knots]" (Bureau of Meteor
ology, Victoria).
The rise in days over 35 degrees means fire services will be increasingly in demand, while some State governments - such as Victoria - attempt to wind back budgets or, worse, privatise the services, and the Federal Government goes into deep denial over the effect of polluting our atmosphere.
From an average of nine days exceeding 35 degrees in Tatura (Victoria) at present, the Goulburn Valley fruit-growing town can expect 12 hot days a year by 2030 and 22 days above 35 degrees by 2070. It will be a disaster for stone fruit and a massive burden to Shepparton firefighting costs. The increased variability is likely across the continent, with Canberra also expecting twice as many hot days by 2070.
Even with the most cautious conclusions, as recently as May 1997 the CSIRO (in Climate Change, Climatic Hazards and Policy Responses in Australia ) described deaths from bushfires as "an increasing trend".
"The south-east coastal strip of Australia is amongst the most fire-prone in the world," said the CSIRO's Atmospheric Research Division. Despite the complexity of mapping climate projections onto the conditions for bushfires, the CSIRO is in no doubt that "the fire danger is likely to increase if the climate warms".
A NSW Fire Brigade spokesman, John Hoban, says that with the Carr Government's "quantum leap" investment in fire services, the Fire Brigade is prepared for a harsh bushfire season.
"We're probably the best equipped and trained we've ever been," Hoban said. But noting the fires in Indonesia and the first drought in the Papua New Guinea highlands in living memory, he said: "Who knows what's in store for us?
"Weather and fire are unhappy partners," Hoban said. "We look to guidance from the CSIRO and Bureau of Meteorology and listen to what the experts tell us. We've just got to get the job done."
The chairman of the British Royal Commission on Environmental Pollution and co-chair of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), Sir John Houghton, has won the agreement of 2,000 scientists and 100 governments - but not that of Australia.
Houghton says that if the 1992 Rio de Janeiro UN Conference on Environment and Development emissions agreements were met - we are way behind target - carbon concentrations would not stabilise for 500 years, so human changes to the atmosphere and climate are guaranteed for a long time to come.
The IPCC's work has been assessed by the most learned bodies in the world, including the Royal Institute of International Affairs in London. In the most recent RIIA briefing paper on climate change, Duncan Brack and Michael Grubb describe naysaying - denying that there is a problem - as "both irresponsible and doomed as a political strategy".
"Climate change will happen," wrote Brack and Grubb. "Now that the IPCC has completed the largest ever international assessment exercise, no-one who chooses to ignore its conclusions and implications can claim not to have been forewarned."
Instead of just denying the evidence, the Coalition Government has changed tack, now claiming that Australia is a special case. As far as the European Union is concerned, the only special case is that the Australian Government's (ABARE) figures don't add up. Mr Howard's October speech to the Australian Chamber of Manufactures was circulated and ridiculed at the European Commission, with officials saying their Australian counterparts, who had made a positive contribution until March 1996, appeared confused and unprepared.
The head of the European Commission's Delegation on Climate Change, Jorgen Henningsen, went further and said that of all the countries dragging their feet on climate change, Australia was the worst.
The Government's back-to-the-1950s approach guarantees lost opportunities. We have insignificant investment in wind and solar energy because the fossil fuel lobby is far too powerful. Instead of using the environment and taxpayers to subsidise coal and oil, we should be developing next-generation technology for export to our Asian neighbours. If we don't, others will.
How is it that the European Union produces 3,400 megawatts (MW) of wind power, India 820 MW and Australia 2.5 MW? Worse, the sunburnt country produces less than 2 MW of solar power and, according to the Environment Minister, Senator Hill, we are among the world's worst polluters, much of it motor vehicle greenhouse gases.
The cost of Australia doing nothing has been estimated at 3.8 per cent of GDP by the Netherlands-based Institute for Environmental Studies. Financial benefits from developing renewable power technologies are endless, and that is apart from the reduction in climate change, the consequent bushfires and agricultural impacts.
Perhaps after the next Ash Wednesday, when thousands of Australians are homeless and scores of civilians and firefighters are dead, we shall again hear the Prime Minister claiming it was unavoidable, or perhaps, as with climate change, it isn't really happening. Instead, he might listen to the experts and just get the job done.

NSW braces for new battle;: [Late Edition]

Author: LEONIE LAMONT and NICK PAPADOPOULOS

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/nsw-braces-new-battle/docview/363379748/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Fire authorities are preparing themselves for a new wave of bushfires as the weather bureau forecast rising temperatures that would last until the weekend.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=NSW+braces+for+new+battle%3B&amp;author=LEONIE+LAMONT+and+NICK+PAPADOPOULOS&amp;issn=03126315&amp;title=Sydney+Morning+Herald&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-04&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: MAJOR FIRES and SYDNEY FORECASTS joined to story.
Fire authorities are preparing themselves for a new wave of bushfires as the weather bureau forecast rising temperatures that would last until the weekend.
While milder weather meant most of the Sydney outbreaks were contained yesterday, bushfires continued to destroy thousands of hectares of national parks and State forests.
More than 150 fires were still burning throughout NSW last night, 80 of them uncontrolled, but the Rural Fire Service was confident most would be quickly extinguished.
Major outbreaks were reported around Merriwa, Muswellbrook, Singleton, andthe Hawkesbury. Other fires were raging north of Coonabarabran and in the Wollon-dilly shire near Nattai andLake Burragorang.
Last night, Commissioner Phil Koperberg of the Rural Fire Service said a spate of fires had started near Inverell, and there was an unconfirmed report that volunteer firefighters from Tamworth were being called away from the Pilliga blaze to fight fires back in their home shire.
The Rural Fire Service said it wanted to put out fires near houses before it gets hotter tomorrow.
Bulldozers were cutting containment lines in a bid to stop a fire north of Lithgow from joining another blaze at Yarramun Creek, which would threaten Bell and Mt Wilson townships.
Fires in Linden and the Jamieson Valley, where two volunteer firefighters were killed on Tuesday, were considered to be safe yesterday afternoon.
A giant trench, 50km long and 20 metres wide, was bulldozed outside the Pilliga scrub blaze, which has burnt out 175,000 hectares. The most serious front was moving towards Narrabri and Boggabri, forcing the evacuation of 10 to 20 properties.
Unlike the southern fires, there has been no weather respite, and it continues to be fanned by gusty winds and temperatures in the mid-30s, which will worsen until an expected change on Sunday.
Residents of Menai returned to their fire-ravaged suburb, where 11 homes were destroyed and up to 30 houses damaged. Eight helicopters water-bombed spot fires in the Sutherland shire, which has lost 3,100 hectares to fires.Fires were being contained yesterday in Engadine, Lucas Heights, Illawong, Alfords Point, Sandy Point, West Menai, and at Heathcote in the Royal
National Park.
The Insurance Council of Australia estimated an insurance bill in Sydney of between $5 million and $10 million.
Commissioner Koperberg said: "We suspect that byFriday we're going to go back into a fairly bad day withvery strong possibilities of strong north-westerlies, high temperatures and low humidity."The Premier, Mr Carr, visited Lithgow and Wallerawang, which were mourning their dead, and Menai.
He pledged the immediate construction of a $30 million bridge spanning the Woronora River, following advice from Commissioner Koperberg that firefighters were hamperedby poor access.

Vagueness is credo of High Priest of the Carbon Club Lobbyists on both sides of the argument have gathered in Kyoto this week for the crucial summit on climate change. Frank McDonald, Environment Correspondent, describes the cast of characters who populate this circuit: [CITY EDITION]

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/vagueness-is-credo-high-priest-carbon-club/docview/310242989/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Every United Nations conference on global warming since the 1992 Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro - and there have been eight such meetings so far - is populated by the same cast of characters. They haunt the corridors and the lobbies, buttonholing delegates to find out what's happening and to put forward their points of view. These characters on the climate-change circuit range across the spectrum from Dr Jeremy Leggett, science director of Greenpeace International, who wants action on the issue, to Mr Donald Pearlman, a US lawyer, and his allies in the Global Climate Coalition of oil, coal and motor industry interests, who always seek to block progress. A profile in Der Spiegel during the 1995 First Conference of the Parties to the UN Climate Change Convention in Berlin memorably described this publicity-shy lawyer as the "High Priest of the Carbon Club" and said his aim was to "ensure that climate protection negotiations end in the nevernever land of vague declarations."

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Vagueness+is+credo+of+High+Priest+of+the+Carbon+Club+Lobbyists+on+both+sides+of+the+argument+have+gathered+in+Kyoto+this+week+for+the+crucial+summit+on+climate+change.+Frank+McDonald%2C+Environment+Correspondent%2C+describes+the+cast+of+characters+who+populate+this+circuit&amp;author=&amp;issn=&amp;title=Irish+Times&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-03&amp;spage=11&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Every United Nations conference on global warming since the 1992 Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro - and there have been eight such meetings so far - is populated by the same cast of characters. They haunt the corridors and the lobbies, buttonholing delegates to find out what's happening and to put forward their points of view.
These characters on the climate-change circuit range across the spectrum from Dr Jeremy Leggett, science director of Greenpeace International, who wants action on the issue, to Mr Donald Pearlman, a US lawyer, and his allies in the Global Climate Coalition of oil, coal and motor industry interests, who always seek to block progress.
Not many people have heard of Mr Pearlman, though his influence has been enormous. He has never missed a meeting and is believed to have read every single line of well over 1,000 UN documents on climate change.
Clients of his Washington law firm, Patton, Boggs and Blow, include such industrial giants as DuPont, Exxon, Shell and Texaco.
A profile in Der Spiegel during the 1995 First Conference of the Parties to the UN Climate Change Convention in Berlin memorably described this publicity-shy lawyer as the "High Priest of the Carbon Club" and said his aim was to "ensure that climate protection negotiations end in the nevernever land of vague declarations."
Negotiations under the convention work on the basis of consensus: everyone has to agree on a text before it can be adopted. This inherent weakness in the process has been exploited over and over again by the fossil fuel lobby, and Mr Pearlman in particular, to weaken the wording of both scientific and political documents.
As one leading environmentalist put it, "He is there arguing over individual words in the text, watering down the science so there are more uncertainties . . . Having succeeded in this ploy, his lobby can and do argue at the next meeting and all the ones afterwards that the science is uncertain and therefore it is too early to take action."
He "systematically uses" delegates from the Gulf states, Der Spiegel said, to "undermine the credibility of scientists" at meetings of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. They "engage in endless hair-splitting" and, at one stage, a Kuwaiti delegate even submitted, in Mr Pearlman's handwriting, proposals to change the text.
The US fossil fuel industry, which Mr Pearlman so assiduously represents, has spent millions of dollars in recent years on what the Worldwatch Institute in Washington regards as a "disinformation" campaign to prevent President Clinton taking action on climate change.
Yet Greenpeace is not without allies. Its biggest coup, engineered by Dr Leggett, was to persuade significant elements of the world's insurance industry to climb on board.
What Dr Leggett set out to do was to create a counter-lobby, which would become as important as the coal and oil industry group in pulling the other way. He began talking to insurers, telling them that the thousands of claims from householders with subsiding houses built on London clay were "merely the tip of the global warming iceberg."
Paul Brown, author of a definitive book on climate change, notes that between 1975 and 1993 Britain's bill for subsidence totalled (pounds) 2.5 billion. Problems began mainly in the long dry summer of 1976 but were repeated in the 1980s.
Yet another crop of claims emerged as a result of the very hot and dry 1995 summer. The ground underneath these houses was quite literally cracking up.
Many of the damaged houses were Victorian which had stood on clay foundations for 100 years, yet over the spread of a few years thousands required major repairs.
No wonder insurance companies have introduced a differential premium for houses built on clay; this is "England's first global warming insurance premium," as Paul Brown called it.
It was Greenpeace's 1994 report, The Climate Time Bomb, detailing a huge number of natural disasters worldwide, that made the insurance industry sit up and take notice. In the US alone, 21 of the largest 25 insured catastrophes on record occurred in the past 10 years, and 16 of the 25 involved a combination of wind and water.
The league table for 1992 and 1993 included Hurricane Andrew in the US ((pounds) 16.7 billion), flooding in the US Midwest ((pounds) 8 billion), gales in the US, Canada, Cuba and Mexico ((pounds) 3.3 billion), Cyclone Iniki in Hawaii ((pounds) 1.7 billion), flooding in Belgium, France, Germany and the Netherlands ((pounds) 1.3 billion) and Typhoon Polly in China ((pounds) 1 billion).
Dr Leggett, who assembled insurance executives for a press briefing at the 1995 Berlin conference, said later: "The worst case for insurers is very bad indeed. I have now been personally told by people at the top of the industry, in Munich, Zurich, London, New York and Tokyo that climate change could bankrupt the industry."
The fossil fuel lobby's biggest ally is public apathy. Public interest in "saving the world" has waned quite perceptibly since the Earth Summit. The issue is seen by ordinary people as too complex and the solutions too difficult to contemplate.
But Chancellor Helmut Kohl put it up to us in 1995 when he said: "Preserving Creation and securing sustainable development is a task for the whole of mankind, a task which no one, no state, no economy and no individual, must shirk."

____________________________________________________________

The Greenhouse Follies

Author: By Henry S. Rowen and John P. Weyant

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/greenhouse-follies/docview/398750309/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Representatives of more than 140 countries are meeting in Kyoto, Japan, to negotiate a treaty limiting emissions of "greenhouse gases," chiefly carbon dioxide, which may cause severe global warming in the next century. The delegates will announce emission goals for 2010, unaccompanied by legislation for reaching them, which is just as well. If such legislation were enacted, the world economy would likely experience a recession comparable to those produced by the oil shocks of the 1970s. How seriously can we take these pledges? Consider that these are the same countries that pledged at the 1992 Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro to hold down their emissions -- and then did nothing about it. Instead, as the table nearby shows, all are heading for 2010 emission rates well above 1990 levels. Among the developed nations only Australia (a large coal exporter) is unwilling to play the game of posturing for drastic emissions cuts. But the developing countries, which see consuming more carbon-containing fuels as essential for their economies, aren't making any promises either. Some environmentalists assert that emissions can be reduced by such large amounts quite cheaply. They are dreaming. There simply is no way to cut 25% of our emissions without shutting down many electricity-generating and steel-making plants that use coal and without drastically scaling back gasoline use. Closing one in four of these plants and cutting oil consumption by one-fourth over the next decade means throwing away a good deal of capital stock. New technologies, such as improved fuel cells for autos and dramatically more efficient appliances, may eventually make it possible to cut emissions drastically. But few will be available by 2010. The automobile firm doing the most to promote fuel cells, Daimler Benz, doesn't plans to introduce its first cars with them until 2005.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=The+Greenhouse+Follies&amp;author=By+Henry+S.+Rowen+and+John+P.+Weyant&amp;issn=00999660&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-02&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Representatives of more than 140 countries are meeting in Kyoto, Japan, to negotiate a treaty limiting emissions of "greenhouse gases," chiefly carbon dioxide, which may cause severe global warming in the next century. The delegates will announce emission goals for 2010, unaccompanied by legislation for reaching them, which is just as well. If such legislation were enacted, the world economy would likely experience a recession comparable to those produced by the oil shocks of the 1970s.
The delegates from the European Union will declare that their goal is to reduce the industrialized nations' emissions 15% below the 1990 level; the Japanese will aim for a 5% reduction. The U.S. will be criticized as a laggard; it will aim only to match the 1990 level.
How seriously can we take these pledges? Consider that these are the same countries that pledged at the 1992 Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro to hold down their emissions -- and then did nothing about it. Instead, as the table nearby shows, all are heading for 2010 emission rates well above 1990 levels. Among the developed nations only Australia (a large coal exporter) is unwilling to play the game of posturing for drastic emissions cuts. But the developing countries, which see consuming more carbon-containing fuels as essential for their economies, aren't making any promises either.
Attaining even the U.S. proposal, the most modest of these goals, would be very costly. Getting back to 1990, as the Clinton administration proposes to do, means doing whatever it takes over 13 years to make Americans put out at least one-fourth less carbon dioxide than they otherwise would. That translates into a loss to the economy of at least 3% to 4% of gross domestic product, a proportion that could easily rise if, as seems likely, regulators fail to make the reductions in an efficient way. Higher unemployment would be a near certainty; so would inflation, if the Federal Reserve tried to compensate for the slowdown through an expansive monetary policy, as it did in the 1970s.
Some environmentalists assert that emissions can be reduced by such large amounts quite cheaply. They are dreaming. There simply is no way to cut 25% of our emissions without shutting down many electricity-generating and steel-making plants that use coal and without drastically scaling back gasoline use. Closing one in four of these plants and cutting oil consumption by one-fourth over the next decade means throwing away a good deal of capital stock. New technologies, such as improved fuel cells for autos and dramatically more efficient appliances, may eventually make it possible to cut emissions drastically. But few will be available by 2010. The automobile firm doing the most to promote fuel cells, Daimler Benz, doesn't plans to introduce its first cars with them until 2005.
Europe's and Japan's plans are no more realistic than the U.S.'s. True, Europe has the lowest projected rate of growth in emissions from 1990-2010 -- but that mostly reflects Germany's closure of the inefficient energy complex in the east and Britain's substitution of natural gas for coal. And the costs of reducing Japan's emissions would make that country's current economic troubles seem mild by comparison.
There is a cynical explanation of the implausible goals Europe and Japan have announced: They are counting on inaction by the U.S., the biggest producer of greenhouse gases. In July the U.S. Senate -- which must ratify any treaty drafted at Kyoto -- voted 95-0 in favor of a nonbinding resolution calling on the Clinton administration not to sign any treaty whose requirements do not apply to the developing countries. Knowing this, European and Japanese officials are able to pander to their environmentalist constituents now and point to U.S. inaction to get them off the hook later. China, India and others in the developing world will follow suit.
The Clinton administration, which is dispatching Vice President Gore to Kyoto, is posturing too. It has offered a meager package that will not do much by 2010: some kind of tax credit for firms that cut emissions, trading of emission rights, more research and development on energy technologies, and solar roofs on 20,000 government buildings. Total cost: $5 billion over five years.
The package includes good, bad and promising ideas. One that looks bad is offering tax concessions to encourage use of cleaner energy, a scheme likely to require a costly auditing system.
A more promising idea is setting up a trading system for greenhouse gases, similar to the current system that allocates rights to emit sulfur oxides among U.S. coal-fired power plants; it has cut costs about 85% below that of a nontrading system of control. Such a system cuts overall emissions while allowing the market to determine the most efficient way of accomplishing the reduction.
Ultimately we might see international trading of emission rights, though this idea needs a lot more work. Emission rights would have to be apportioned among nations in the first place, entailing negotiation on a cosmic scale. As economist Thomas Schelling argues, the $1 trillion or so in present value involved is simply too large for politicians to commit. And, in laudable pursuit of the least global cost, it could lead to huge transfers of money to less developed countries, which couldn't be used for anything other than energy projects. Still, the U.S. and other industrial countries might experiment by setting up trading systems domestically, with relatively nonbinding permit levels at the outset, with the aim of going international when the time is ripe.
Increasing R&D on noncarbon technologies is the only clearly good idea in the president's package. If global warming becomes severe, there will be an urgent need for such technologies. Most will take decades to develop and deploy on a wide scale; this is the time to start, and the cost would be far less than drastically scaling back emissions soon.
The oil shocks of the 1970s stimulated research on alternative energy sources. Some turned out badly, notably the nuclear breeder reactor and synthetic fuels, but others were more successful, especially the solar-photovoltaic programs. The president's science and technology advisers have recommended spending about $800 million a year more on greenhouse-related research, an increase that would bring such spending back about to its level in 1991. The chance of government failures could be held down by promoting private sector consortia, by keeping most projects small and by sharing costs with the private sector. But some government involvement is necessary, since private firms are unwilling to take certain risks on their own. What company would try to develop a new nuclear reactor?
The Rio-Kyoto enterprise brings to mind Ambrose Bierce's definition of a fanatic: one who redoubles his efforts as he loses sight of his goal. Environmentalists are damaging their cause by focusing on the unattainable while neglecting the useful and feasible. The strategy of committing to an emissions target and having nations pay whatever the bill comes to has things backward. Instead, these countries should be trying to identify useful actions with known costs while accepting whatever benefits in greenhouse-gas reductions result. More R&D fits this approach, because the budget can be controlled and the new technology can be used world-wide. So does starting some experiments in trading emission permits. These actions amount to buying "insurance" at a known cost against uncertain future risks.
The delegates to Kyoto will declare victory, but their claim will be hollow. But perhaps this meeting will be the last run of the Greenhouse Follies, followed by a process that accomplishes something useful.
---
Mr. Rowen is director of Stanford University's Asia/Pacific Research Center. Mr. Weyant is director of Stanford's Energy Modeling Forum.
---

Financial interests fiddle while our habitat burns: [Final Edition]

Author: Dyer, Gwynne

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/financial-interests-fiddle-while-our-habitat/docview/349101655/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: The haze is gone from Malaysia now, but the cabaret group `Instant Cafe' is still getting a lot of mileage out of it. They were playing a corporate function in Kuala Lumpur last weekend -- people who'd coughed and wept their way through the haze for all of September and October -- and the audience rocked with laughter when they did their song Haze: The haze is mostly smoke from the thousands of forest fires that are set in Indonesia every dry season: first you log out any commercially valuable trees, then you burn the rest because that's the cheapest way to clear the land for cultivation. The smoke from huge areas of burning forest drifts blocks out the sun and causing respiratory disorders. Without a serious American offer on cutting emissions, none of the other hold-outs at Kyoto will be under any pressure to yield, for the U.S. is the most flagrant polluter of all (four per cent of the world's population, 24 percent of its greenhouse gas emissions). So the best that can be hoped for at Kyoto is dramatic failure.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Financial+interests+fiddle+while+our+habitat+burns&amp;author=Dyer%2C+Gwynne&amp;issn=08373434&amp;title=The+Standard&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-02&amp;spage=B.7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The UN Climate Summit which opened in Kyoto, Japan yesterday will probably not end in a flaming row. Countries must not lose face, and so they are more likely to cobble together some shoddy compromise that is worth nothing. But a spectacular failure would be much better, for at least it might get the donkey's attention.
Or more precisely, the frog's attention. Environmentalists often compare human behaviour to that of frogs -- who, if you drop them into a pot of boiling water, will jump right out again and survive. But sit a frog in a pot of cool water, raise the heat gradually, and he'll sit there happily until he boils to death.
Are humans really like frogs? Of course they are. Take Malaysians, for example.
The haze is gone from Malaysia now, but the cabaret group `Instant Cafe' is still getting a lot of mileage out of it. They were playing a corporate function in Kuala Lumpur last weekend -- people who'd coughed and wept their way through the haze for all of September and October -- and the audience rocked with laughter when they did their song Haze:
"Come and visit Malaysia.
Come and stay for lots of days.
You don't need your suntan lotion.
You'll be safe from UV rays.
No need to sunbathe by the ocean.
Get dark by strolling in our haze."
The haze is mostly smoke from the thousands of forest fires that are set in Indonesia every dry season: first you log out any commercially valuable trees, then you burn the rest because that's the cheapest way to clear the land for cultivation. The smoke from huge areas of burning forest drifts blocks out the sun and causing respiratory disorders.
The haze was particularly bad in 1991, when the eruption of Mount Pinatubo added extra ash to the atmosphere. It was even worse this year because of the prolonged drought caused by El Nino. But it happens every year, and it will go on happening until the region's rain forests are all gone. (At the current loss rate of around three per cent per year, that will be around 30 years from now.)
Yet few Malaysians think they can do anything about it, because they know that the companies that are setting most of the fires in Indonesia have close links with President Suharto's government in Jakarta, and generally get their way.
They are also vaguely aware that destroying the forests raises the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere and contributes to global warming. But that problem isn't affecting their daily lives yet, and they have lots of present worries to keep them busy.
People in large industrialized democracies like the United States like to think they are different: better information, more open societies, a more educated public. But in fact they are equally captive to special interest groups.
The United States, for example, promised at the 1992 Earth Summit in Rio to cut its carbon dioxide emissions back to 1990 levels by the year 2000. Instead, U.S. carbon emissions are 13 per cent higher than in 1990, and Washington is now saying that it can't get back down to the target figure until 2013. What happened?
The Clinton administration knows what it should do. At a preparatory meeting of the climate change conference in Geneva earlier this year, the U.S. mobilized the world's big insurance companies, who proved that global warming was already hitting their balance sheets in terms of soaring claims for storm damage.
That debunked the `junk science' (paid for by fossil-fuel producers) that pretends global warming is just an unproven hypothesis. With the European Union offering emission cuts to 15 per cent below 1990 levels by 2010, and the U.S. government also apparently on board, success in Kyoto seemed within reach.
True, the Australians, who export a lot of coal, were arguing that there should be no common global target, just individual targets tailored to individual countries' situations (agree to that, and you will spend the next century in negotiations.)
Some oil-rich states were even insisting that if the world cut back on fossil-fuel use, they must be compensated financially. But it was clear that once the U.S. openly espoused a tough target for cutting emissions, a lot of the resistance would crumble.
What went wrong? Basically, Clinton belatedly realized that U.S. fossil-fuel producers, in alliance with other major industries that worry about higher energy costs, control enough U.S. senators to block any treaty that hurts their interests. So rather than fight a hopeless battle, he has chosen pre-emptive surrender.
Just as in Jakarta, the tail is wagging the dog. Many more Americans have an interest in curbing global warming than in the industries that cause it, but the majority is less conscious of its interests: the water in the pot is getting hotter, but only gradually. So the prospective victims exert less political pressure, and the other side gets its way.
Without a serious American offer on cutting emissions, none of the other hold-outs at Kyoto will be under any pressure to yield, for the U.S. is the most flagrant polluter of all (four per cent of the world's population, 24 percent of its greenhouse gas emissions). So the best that can be hoped for at Kyoto is dramatic failure.
The Europeans should stick to their 15-per-cent cuts proposal and make no compromises. They won't get their way, but that will at least ensure that the problem isn't shelved for five years after a cynical deal that leaves everyone free to do whatever they want.
Complete failure would at least make everybody come back for another conference next year. In the meantime, we should pray for weather so extreme that it wakes the frogs up.
Gwynne Dyer is a London-based commentator on international affairs

Title: Financial interests fiddle while our habitat burns:   [Final Edition ]

Publication title: The Standard; St. Catharines, Ont.

Pages: B7

Number of pages: 0

Publication year: 1997

Publication date: Dec 2, 1997

column: Gwynne Dyer

Section: Editorial

Publisher: Torstar Syndication Services, a Division of Toronto Star Newspapers Limited

Place of publication: St. Catharines, Ont.

Country of publication: Canada, St. Catharines, Ont.

ISSN: 08373434

Kyoto Failure May Be Best For the Planet

Author: GWYNNE DYER FREELANCE SERVICE

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/kyoto-failure-may-be-best-planet/docview/288815840/se-2?accountid=10226

World must change or its climate will: [Final Edition]

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/world-must-change-climate-will/docview/275617529/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: The debate over global warming is almost as hot as the global climate. Top scientists are convinced burning fossil fuels -- oil, coal and gas -- raises the levels of greenhouse gases. These gases - - carbon dioxide, nitrous oxide and methane -- build in the atmosphere, trapping heat that should escape into outer space. And so we slowly cook in our own juices. A new study says this year is the warmest since records were first made in 1860. Hot enough for you? How lucky do we feel? The European Community is convinced about global warming, enough to call for a 15 per cent reduction in greenhouse gases. Another group worth heeding is the insurance industry. Hardly a cadre of radical-chic greens, these business people believe global warming is causing unprecedented damage and rising claims.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=World+must+change+or+its+climate+will&amp;author=&amp;issn=&amp;title=The+Record&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-02&amp;spage=A.10&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The world is heating up, if not yet burning, but until Monday, the Canadian government was as content as Nero to fiddle. Then, as delegates from 150 nations met in Kyoto, Japan, to find a way to put a damper on climate change, Canada did the right thing and changed its tune.
The Liberal government is now calling for a three per cent cut in greenhouse gas emissions from 1990 levels by 2010. This is a significant change by an administration that until now stressed merely stabilizing emissions at 1990 levels.
The change is especially welcome since it signals the government, after dithering for too long, is serious about this issue and agrees the problem exists. People must know this. They will bear some pain before the Earth's wounds are healed.
The debate over global warming is almost as hot as the global climate. Top scientists are convinced burning fossil fuels -- oil, coal and gas -- raises the levels of greenhouse gases. These gases - - carbon dioxide, nitrous oxide and methane -- build in the atmosphere, trapping heat that should escape into outer space. And so we slowly cook in our own juices. A new study says this year is the warmest since records were first made in 1860. Hot enough for you?
Skeptics argue the case is unproven, pointing out that the Earth's climate fluctuates naturally and that reliable records are recent creations. So who should be trusted?
Perhaps we should just hedge our bets. The risk of doing nothing and creating a global disaster is far more serious than the risk of taking unnecessary steps that temporarily hurt economies. Do we want to bequeath to our grandchildren a wrecked planet devastated by floods, storms and farmland turned to desert, or a slightly slower economy?
How lucky do we feel? The European Community is convinced about global warming, enough to call for a 15 per cent reduction in greenhouse gases. Another group worth heeding is the insurance industry. Hardly a cadre of radical-chic greens, these business people believe global warming is causing unprecedented damage and rising claims.
At this point, Canadians, the world's second largest per capita producers of greenhouse gases, are finally getting badly needed clarity and direction from their leaders. Now the government has to tell us how we can get there by outlining its incentives, regulations and plans for alternative technology. We have been warned enough about a storm building on the horizon. We should act, while there's time.
Credit: Kitchener Waterloo Record

Until Payoff Is Clear, Haste Means Big Waste

Author: Passell, Peter

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/until-payoff-is-clear-haste-means-big-waste/docview/430902511/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: To the frustration of environmental activists, the still-distant risks from global warming have yet to grab the attention of Main Street. But to many economists, the difficulty in mobilizing public support to meet America's international commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to 1990 levels by 2010 may yet prove a blessing. For while some of the skepticism about the virtue of quick, decisive action is coming from the energy and auto industries, most independent experts also urge a long, hard look before we leap. William Nordhaus, an economist at Yale University, estimates that bribing or bullying the developing world to switch to energy-saving, carbon-sparing technologies -- things like insulating buildings and generating electricity with natural gas rather than coal -- would get the job done for one-ninth the cost of squeezing comparable emissions out of the developed economies. His computer simulations suggest that cutting emissions in the United States back to 1990 levels by 2010 would require a doubling of energy prices, ''more than the price run-up during the two oil crises,'' he noted. Economists also note that while the debate in Kyoto is about annual levels of emissions, what matters in terms of climate change is the accumulated levels of greenhouse gases. Alan Manne of Stanford University and Richard Richels of the Electric Power Research Institute, a research organization in Palo Alto, Calif., that is supported by the power industry, compare two paths to stabilizing atmospheric carbon at 550 parts per million, double preindustrial levels, around the end of the 21st century. With the rapid transition mandated by current international agreements, annual emissions would peak at seven billion tons around 2050. But on a cost-minimizing path, the emissions would peak at 10 billion tons but then fall more rapidly to achieve the same atmospheric concentration of greenhouse gas. Taking the faster route to the same end would double the cost, adding a trillion dollars to the ultimate bill. ''So much depends,'' Dr. Richels said, ''on what we call 'when flexibility.' ''

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Until+Payoff+Is+Clear%2C+Haste+Means+Big+Waste&amp;author=Passell%2C+Peter&amp;issn=03624331&amp;title=New+York+Times&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-01&amp;spage=F.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: WHAT, Americans worry?
To the frustration of environmental activists, the still-distant risks from global warming have yet to grab the attention of Main Street. But to many economists, the difficulty in mobilizing public support to meet America's international commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to 1990 levels by 2010 may yet prove a blessing. For while some of the skepticism about the virtue of quick, decisive action is coming from the energy and auto industries, most independent experts also urge a long, hard look before we leap.
To be sure, there may well be easy opportunities to slow global warming through bottom-up steps like better insulation and modest changes in agricultural methods.
But crash programs, most economists argue, are apt to increase the cost of containing emissions without increasing the benefits. More important, they question the logic of diverting vast economic resources from other uses without a better understanding of the payoff. ''The most effective policy won't be the most dramatic,'' cautioned Robert N. Stavins, an environmental economist at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University.
The economists' immediate concern is the difficulty of slowing emissions without support from China, India, Brazil and a half-dozen other big emerging economies. While Europe, America and Japan are heavy emitters of greenhouse gases, it's widely agreed that the cheap fixes lie elsewhere.
William Nordhaus, an economist at Yale University, estimates that bribing or bullying the developing world to switch to energy-saving, carbon-sparing technologies -- things like insulating buildings and generating electricity with natural gas rather than coal -- would get the job done for one-ninth the cost of squeezing comparable emissions out of the developed economies. His computer simulations suggest that cutting emissions in the United States back to 1990 levels by 2010 would require a doubling of energy prices, ''more than the price run-up during the two oil crises,'' he noted.
Just as costly as doing it in the wrong place would be doing it at the wrong pace. A blitzkrieg on emissions, compared with a more deliberate effort to pick the low-hanging fruit first, would require that relatively new carbon-emitting capital -- power plants, industrial equipment and vehicles -- be scrapped rather than replaced gradually. And it would force countries, companies and consumers to adopt exotic greenhouse-friendly technologies like fuel cells before they are fully worked out -- or fully affordable. No less important, a rapid transition would tie up capital that could otherwise be used to increase productive capacity.
A hundred billion here, a hundred billion there could add up to real money.
Economists also note that while the debate in Kyoto is about annual levels of emissions, what matters in terms of climate change is the accumulated levels of greenhouse gases. Alan Manne of Stanford University and Richard Richels of the Electric Power Research Institute, a research organization in Palo Alto, Calif., that is supported by the power industry, compare two paths to stabilizing atmospheric carbon at 550 parts per million, double preindustrial levels, around the end of the 21st century. With the rapid transition mandated by current international agreements, annual emissions would peak at seven billion tons around 2050. But on a cost-minimizing path, the emissions would peak at 10 billion tons but then fall more rapidly to achieve the same atmospheric concentration of greenhouse gas. Taking the faster route to the same end would double the cost, adding a trillion dollars to the ultimate bill. ''So much depends,'' Dr. Richels said, ''on what we call 'when flexibility.' ''
If the issues of where and when emissions should be curbed give policy wonks reason to pause, they pale in importance beside the core question: How much is climate stabilization really worth?
Sharp, rapid increases in temperature might transform the biosphere in catastrophic ways, conceivably threatening human survival. But the pace and amount of warming that the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change now views as most likely -- an average increase of about four degrees Fahrenheit by 2060, with an increase in rainfall of 7 percent and a one-foot rise in sea level -- suggest a different story.
According to the most plausible computer simulations, the economic impact on the temperate zones would be relatively small; increases in agricultural productivity could more than offset the added costs from storm damage and coastal flooding. Canada and Russia could be big winners, as their growing seasons lengthen and heating bills fall. Even the United States might come out ahead: Robert Mendelsohn, an economist at Yale, estimates that output would increase by $37 billion.
The picture is far more dire for the poor, predominantly agricultural tropics, vulnerable to flooding, drought and epidemics. But in a world of limited resources, and limited generosity, Thomas Schelling, an economist at the University of Maryland's School of Public Policy, argues that it would make more sense to divert the sums needed to curb global warming into investments that mitigate poverty in the developing world.
''They have more immediate environmental problems -- sanitation, congestion, disease -- that demand prior attention,'' he said. ''Their best defense against climate is their own development.''
Many economists who are sanguine about the likely consequences of unchecked temperature increases would still recommend buying some insurance against less likely catastrophe scenarios -- for example, the possibility that the melting of polar ice could liberate trapped methane and lead to runaway warming. But they insist that it would be irrational to throw big sums at risks this remote. Dr. Nordhaus, the Yale economist, said, ''I've seen nothing that justified increasing the wholesale price of energy by more than 10 percent,'' roughly a nickel a gallon at the gasoline pump.
In light of both President Clinton's reluctance to do much without the participation of the developing world and the resistance of Congress to any increases in energy prices, the hurdles to any consensus on swift action appear formidable. That will please analysts who see nothing good coming from on-again, off-again hysteria over climate warming. But it worries Dr. Nordhaus, who wonders how we will ever learn to walk without a few baby steps.
''Let's do something modest,'' Dr. Nordhaus urged, ''but let's really do it.''
Chart ''The Cost of Reducing Emissions''
While there is general agreement that heat-trapping gases are on the rise, there is little agreement about how much it will cost to reduce emissions. Studies on the costs vary widely based on a number of factors including: the emissions goal; when that goal must be achieved; whether rights to emit gases are tradable; whether taxes are imposed on emissions and how the revenue from such taxes are used; and the depth of society's desire to meet the target.
Some studies look at reductions from the top down, trying to predict how changes in one sector of the economy will effect everything else. These models generally predict that there will be some sort of economic cost. Bottom up studies examine the economy sector by sector, looking for ways to increase efficiency. These models tend to predict overall economic benefits. Here are examples of studies that illustrate each perspective.
TOP DOWN
ORGANIZATIONS -- Stanford Univ., Electric Power Research Institute
APPROACH -- Uses bottom up for where energy comes from and top down for the rest of the econaomy
GOAL -- Atmospheric carbon levels of 550 parts per million, double the pre-industrial level.
CONCLUSION -- The most important factors in keeping the cost of reductions down are phasing them in slowly and allowing trading of emissions rights.
COMMENT -- Richard Richels, one of the study's authors, says that some pure bottom up studies underestimate the hidden costs of switching technologies to reduce emissions. For example, he says there are more fuel efficient cars than Volvos, but consumers buy Volvos because of their reputation for safety.
Chart tracks annual emissions levels for stabilizing carbon dioxide concentrations at 550 parts per million, from 1990 through 2100. It also shows worldwide cost of stabilizing carbon dioxide concentrations, based on 1990 investment cost
BOTTOM UP
ORGANIZATION -- Five national labs of the Department of Energy
APPROACH -- Bottom up
GOAL -- Reduce emissions by 2010, if possible to 1990 levels
CONCLUSION -- Energy savings would offset additional investments needed to reduce emissions so that net costs to the U.S. economy are estimated to be near or below zero.
COMMENT -- The study looks at two methods to reduce emissions: promoting energy efficiency and imposing a tax on emissions of carbon.

Global warming conference needs 'act of courage:' Annan: [Final Edition]

http://ezproxy.cul.columbia.edu/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/global-warming-conference-needs-act-courage-annan/docview/275585860/se-2?accountid=10226

Abstract: Such controls over carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases could, in turn, begin to forestall the damaging rises in temperatures, sea levels and severe weather that scientists predict from global warming. At the 1992 Earth Summit in Brazil, the world's nations signed a Climate Change Treaty that, because of U.S. opposition, set only a voluntary goal: reducing greenhouse gas emissions to 1990 levels by 2000. The underlying principle of climate change is undisputed: Carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide and a few other gases, mostly from fuel combustion, are pervious to incoming sunlight, but trap the heat that Earth emits back to space.

Links: http://rd8hp6du2b.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Global+warming+conference+needs+%27act+of+courage%3A%27+Annan&amp;author=&amp;issn=&amp;title=The+Record&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-12-01&amp;spage=A.7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Representatives of 150 nations are converging on this city of ancient temples to negotiate a 21st-century insurance policy for the planet, a deal to control energy use to protect the atmosphere against global warming.
The talks are highly technical and complex, and the politics challenging.
"There are times when only an act of courage can spur progress in world affairs," UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan said in a statement wishing the conference success as it opens Monday.
If successful, the 10 days of negotiations could lead to shifts toward new-technology automobiles and fuel-saving driving habits, away from coal-powered electricity plants, and toward new farming and forestry practices.
Such controls over carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases could, in turn, begin to forestall the damaging rises in temperatures, sea levels and severe weather that scientists predict from global warming.
Powerful opposition has developed against early action, especially among oil-producing countries and U.S. coal, oil and other interests likely to be hurt.
Industry lobbyists are among the thousands of diplomats, scientists, environmentalists and journalists assembling in Japan's old capital.
At the 1992 Earth Summit in Brazil, the world's nations signed a Climate Change Treaty that, because of U.S. opposition, set only a voluntary goal: reducing greenhouse gas emissions to 1990 levels by 2000.
The underlying principle of climate change is undisputed: Carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide and a few other gases, mostly from fuel combustion, are pervious to incoming sunlight, but trap the heat that Earth emits back to space.
Environmentalists say that even a degree more warming could be damaging, flooding much of low-lying, overcrowded Bangladesh, for example.
And the worst-case scenario could be calamitous for everyone, said Michael Oppenheimer of the U.S. Environmental Defence Fund.
Illustration Caption: Black & White Photo: associated press Kyoto City Mayor Yorikane Masumoto leads a bicycle rally to appeal for environmental responsibility on the eve of the UN Conference on Global Warming starting Monday.
